reviews.text: + Tekken finally has a PC-port and it's fantastic! The entire version is objectively the best with fantastic graphics, short load-times and tons of peripheral support. This is a perfect example of a series transitioning to PC! If you like fighting-games, this is an absolute must-buy!+Fantastic mechanics that are fun for allTekken has a low barrier to entry, but a massive skill-ceiling. You can buy this game and have a fantastic time even if you have never played a fighting game before. For the serious player the game features insane depth and a lot to enjoy. Tekken 7 has changed things such as throw-breaking and made things generally more streamlined, but maintained it's complexety and depth. This really is the best Tekken has ever been. +Optimized rosterWhile not perfect, the roster is tightened up. Your favorite is most likely still in the game and the newcomers are generally good. Each character feels unique and I feel Namco has made good decisions on which characters to keep.+Hype as ♥♥♥♥ final bossJust play the story and see for yourself.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Lack of content in generalI would like to underline that this game has already been out for 2 years in arcades. While not the FR-version, the game has techinally been complete. This begs the question of what in the ♥♥♥♥ Namco has been doing for 2 years. Customization is a joke compared to Tekken 6 and there are very few modes. There is also no replay-mode or anything outside the basic ranked online.The story-mode is very short and the scenarios for other characters are just abysmal. These scenarios are basically a random fight with an in-engine cutcene that does the bare minimum of fan-service. Every Tekken-game before this has had far more fleshed out content story-wise in general. Also, the customization is especially sadening considering that there are so few characters and one would assume this means more options for each one. -Mediocre story-modeThe story-mode is short and nothing to really brag about. It has some cool moments (and Akuma), but it's basically a bunch of CG-cutcenes tied together with a terrible narrator and a hamfisted plot. The story makes no sense, but I can't really fault the game for it. Tekken has always been bonkers. However, compared to many other fighters it really falls flat and it has to be pointed out considering that the game offers very little other content.-No tutorials or help for newcomersThe game has absolutely no tutorial and it's honestly baffling. Tekken is not an easy game to get into. Sure you can mash buttons as Eddy, but there is only a question of time until someone bodies you. It's easy to feel lost in this game, yet the game makes very little effort to teach you anything. You are going to end up on YouTube and other sites to figure out combos, frame-data etc. and that isn't good. There should at least be something here to teach new players the basics.-Online has flawsAs of writing this there are several big problems with online that will hopefully be fixed soon. First of all, rage-quitting is a SERIOUS problem. There is basically no punishment for quitting and if a player disconnects on you, you don't get the win. This becomes an even bigger problem in Tekkens tournament-mode. If the host gets mad he can kick you immediately or outright leave to shut down the entire lobby. As a result, playing Tournament-mode is rather difficult.Connecting to other players is also very difficult as of right now. Connecting through the match-list is almost hopeless and filled with error messages. The best option is using warm-up and wait for a match to be suggested by the matchmaking system. However, this is also frustratingly difficult. It can take 3-4 requests before you can accept a request to fight that actually works. As a result you will often end up in games with 3-bar connections because the game has not been able to connect to the players that fit the criteria you searched for. Most of the time you will be told that "the connection to the opponent has been lost". You might think that this is your potential opponent declining your request, but in the majority of times it is in fact the game struggling to connect. However, this will most likely be fixed and when it happens I will remove this from the review.

reviews.text: If you want to buy this game, I have a few tips: First, watch AvoidingthePuddle on YouTube. He has a playlist of videos where he goes over the fundamentals of the game in probably the most entertaining manner possible. Generally just keep up with this guy if you want to follow the game.Second, get into the competitive scene. Watching professionals play the game is also pretty fun and educational as well.Third, pick a character and go with it. Tekken, at most skill levels, is probably one of the most balanced fighting games out there, and don't let stoners convince you otherwise. DLC characters are fun to play with but cost a bit of money, so maybe explore a bit of that character before buying anything.Finally, stay calm and be respectful. There are plenty of people in this community who will be rude inside the game and out. Keep your cool or else the game doesn't become fun. Also, make it a point to NOT message Harada or Michael Murray on Twitter.If you stick with it, Tekken can be a very fun and rewarding experience. There's so many intricacies to it that allow you learn something about it every time you play it. There are more people following this game now than ever, so now is the time to jump into it.

reviews.text: Before I start the review, please note that I played the game using the following equipment:With that out of the way, here is the review.Tekken 7...Tekken 7 runs well on my machine. The game runs 60 frames per second at maxed settings, in borderless fullscreen, at my monitor's strange screen resolution of 1680x1050. I've had absolutely no issues with running the game.My experience with Tekken 7's netcode has been positive. It's rare that I play a match with noticeable input lag. I live on the Canadian west coast, and I've played good matches with people in east Canada. Canada's a big country, so that fact and what I just wrote should tell you volumes about the quality of Tekken 7's netcode.You should experience good matches most of the time if you live in North America, Europe, or east Asia, places with a large population of Tekken players.Tekken gives its players so many options to use for offense, defense, and the neutral game that players can really just play however they want. You're never really locked into playing a certain way because you play a certain character. Characters in this game have dozens of moves (some characters have more than 100 moves!), so they're quite versatile. I know it sounds cheesy, but you can express yourself through how you play in Tekken.Thanks to Tekken's wealth of moves, techniques, and system mechanics, Tekken 7 ends up being a very open-ended game.Because Tekken's gameplay is so open-ended, Tekken ends up being about what great fighting games are about. It's about constantly evolving strategy and counterstrategy, precise spacing and positioning, technical skill, and 'mind-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥' (conditioning, baits, and reads), and not so much about 50/50s (situations where the defender must guess, from a restricted set of options, what to do to defend against an attacker's offense).Tekken's so open that sometimes you might even think it's too open. There are just so many moves you need to learn to deal with.You might call 'cheap' when you get hit by some moves you don't know how to defend against or punish, but once you understand how to defend against and punish those moves, Tekken really is a fair game. I've gone from hating fighting Eddy to loving fighting Eddy now that I know how to deal with some of his moves.Tekken 7's story mode is very short, and really isn't all that thrilling. For every minute of sick cutscene action story mode presents, story mode presents two minutes of boring narraration-driven exposition. It's a shame that the story is told largely in such a boring way—Heihachi's story is kind of cool.Tekken's arcade mode is standard fare and treasure battle is basically an endless arcade mode that pays out cosmetic rewards. There's little reason to play arcade mode, but Treasure battle is worth playing to unlock cosmetic items.And on the note of cosmetics, Tekken 7's customization mode is the best single player mode Tekken 7 has to offer. I say this with confidence as a degenerate Lili player. The customization options are lacking compared to Tekken Tag Tournament 2, but for the most part you can get your character looking the way you want him/her to look.Customizations have really enhanced my playing experience. Thanks to them, Lili mirror matches are also fashion shows in addition to just being fights.Tekken 7's netcode is good, but it's player match lobbies are no good. The lobbies are really buggy, often causing players to disconnect from the lobby, causing players to skip their turn for a match, or causing players to be unable to spectate matches. Tekken 7's lobbies come with plenty of waiting and frustration and really need to be fixed.The quick match experience is functional, and is thus my preferred way of finding matches online, but even that mode comes with a lot of waiting. Matchmaking can take a while thanks to the loading time between rematches being unnecessarily long. For whatever reason the game needs to reload the stage and characters it already loaded in the previous match.If you're new to Tekken, or fighting games in general, know that Tekken 7 teaches you absolutely nothing about how to play Tekken 7. It doesn't feature a tutorial so you're going to have to find educational material from outside of the game to learn from if you want to learn how to play the game.You can mash around and have some fun, but you're never going to experience the best experience Tekken has to offer if you don't evolve beyond mashing. You'd be forced to play smartly anyway if you want to experience even a little bit of online success: the low online ranks which used to be full of scrubby players are now full of killers. If you're new, you're going to get bodied.Heck, even if you've played for a while, you're gonna lose a bunch. Even with my ~200 hours of experience with this game I really don't know all that much about Tekken. I maybe know less than 20% of the moves in the game, so I often get caught off guard by some moves I don't know much about. I'm constantly having to learn to deal with new moves under stressful situations.Double heck, I keep getting hit by moves I know how to deal with anyway because my reactions are non-existent sometimes!Tekken's brutal.Don't even think about buying this game for its single-player experience. Tekken 7's single-player experience is sorely lacking. The story mode bores more often than it entertains, arcade mode and treasure battle mode bore quickly because computer opponents don't make for interesting or difficult opposition, and customization mode is really only relevant if you play online. I mean, what's the point of customizing your character if no one sees your customization?If you're interested in fighting people online, then Tekken 7 might a good investment. This game is packed with moves and techniques to learn and master, and is home to fierce competition. If you have the drive to "git gud" and have the patience to put up with losing a lot, then I think you might enjoy this game.If you already don't like fighting games, you won't like this game. There's nothing here that would make you change your mind about fighting games.If you already like fighting games, you'll probably like this game.I love this game (even though I'm not good at it!), hence this stupidly long Steam review.

reviews.text: To clarify, I've played a tiny bit of Tekken 4 on PS2 and Tekken 6 on PS Vita, but that's the extent of my previous experience. I barely played either of these and I just button mashed, so I'll call myself a Tekken noob and say that this game is my first 'real experience' in playing a Tekken game. I pre-ordered this game without knowing how well it will be optimized on PC, if the online servers will work, if it supports controllers, etc. To my amazement, Tekken 7 on day 1 tackled all of these.Constant 60 fps is vital in this game as framerate drops will affect button inputs. This game is extremely smooth to run on ultra settings whilst maintaining constant 60 fps (at 1920x1080 on a GTX 1060) though borderless windowed settings forces me to run at 3840x2160 for some reason, but this does not seem to affect system performance at all. Only drops you will see are the loading cutscenes where it will run at 30 fps, but who cares about that?Amazing. Simply amazing. Day 1 release gives you a whopping 37 characters to choose from (38 if you got Eliza as a pre-order bonus) with 10 of them being new characters. The characters all speak in their native language, so I found myself very confused when they all seemed to understand what each other was saying during the story (a great example of this is the dialogue between Nina, Heihachi and Claudio). However, this is by no means a downside as we don't have to hear horrible dubbed voices of foreign characters, but instead it feels more natural and fitting.Not only are there a wide selection of characters, but there are also 20 stages to choose from. The stages have different layouts so it doesn't feel repetitive. You'll have stages with and without walls, some which are octagonal shaped, others which are square shaped and even stages with multiple platforms that can be broken through by using certain moves. Each stage has it's own music piece composed to it and gives it a sense of uniqueness. Oh, and they all look great too.I found the story to be very interesting and gripping at times, but I also found it to be quite short. For the most part it's spending 5 minutes watching a cutscene, fighting someone and then rinse and repeat. Though I guess for a fighting game not much else can be done. I completed the story in a couple of hours in a single sitting along with the extra character episodes unlocked after completing the main story. I found myself hysterically laughing at certain character episodes (Paul vs. Panda and Lucky Chloe vs. Eddy are the two that come to mind) and it was just really fun overall. But as I previously mentioned it is VERY short.I gotta say, the gameplay is near-flawless. For a fighting game noob, I was able to quickly pick up characters I have never even played before and within an hour or so I would come to grips with their playstyle and how to use them. Blocking is done simply by holding back for mid and air attacks and down-back for low attacks, there is no button input required and it is as simple as that. Most characters have very easy 3 or 4 hit combos which is helpful when starting out with a new character. One thing I am not too impressed with however is the inclusion of 'rage arts'. I understand that it is included to help give players an edge when they have low hp, but it honestly just feels cheap. Not to mention that Akuma's rage art can not be blocked, but only evaded by sidestepping or jumping at the right time.Because who would ever dare to play a fighting game with keyboard and mouse? I play this game using my PS4 controller and seems to work flawlessly. The button layout however still shows the Xbox controller button layout, but this isn't an issue at all. I really appreciate the inclusion of custom controller input bindings so I can easily bind multiple buttons to a single button (LP+RP to L1 for example).The soundtrack is quite possibly the best soundtrack of any game I have ever played. There isn't a single track that I have disliked and I have found myself sitting in the character select screen and certain maps in practice whilst I do other tasks just so I can listen to the soundtrack in the background. Honestly even if you don't like fighting games, at least listen to the soundtrack and you will not be disappointed.It's honestly hard to fault this game, it is quite possibly the best fighting game of all time. I love every aspect of this game from the characters to the soundtrack. The game runs very smoothly so I have no issues with input lag and I just find myself falling in love with this game more and more each day. The only issue I have found is that you will sometimes lose connection to a host before you have even joined them, but otherwise online also works flawlessly with no noticable lag.

They claimed they implemented working rollback (Harada, the creator of Tekken has demonstrated he does not actually know what rollback is on several occasions). reviews.text: I highly recommend this game.Every once in a while I feel I find a game that is the epitome of its genre. Tekken is a fighting game in its purest form. If you are looking for a game to obsess over, Tekken can keep your attention for the rest of time. If you are feeling extremely competitive then this game will scratch that itch. Every character has a VASTLY different playstyle and each comes with their own sort of reputation. Nina and Kazuya players know how to get real serious. Yoshimitsu and Panda players know how to party. Law and Dragunov can explode at any moment and they'll keep you on the edge of your seat. King and Devil Jin players are ready to make a spectacle. There are so many martial arts styles covered like Capoeira, Sambo, Majiquan, Boxing, and recently Muay Thai and Wing Chun. A couple of warnings. The balance can sometimes be a little off. DLC characters sometimes come out a lot stronger than other characters and there's not much a player can do about that except try their best. Back in Season 2 they accidentally made Akuma (Yes, the guy from Street Fighter) a little too powerful and a couple people started pulling off 100% combos in tournament. More recently Season 3 buffed almost every character and there was a big power creep. Leroy Smith was released and was so good that they had to make a new spot on the teir list. The online can be pretty bad at times and there's not a lot that can be done about it at this point. Unreal Engine is fantastic but it has limitations like anything else. I haven't played much single player and from what I've seen it's not why you buy this game. You unlock every cosmetic (Except DLC) after 2,000 fights so don't grind for unlocks. That said this game is wonderful. When you do get locked into a good game with someone, Tekken gets very immersive! It's like playing lightning chess. Both players are making plans on the fly. You are both thinking about high/mid/low/grab/rage/(!) mixups, frame advantage, spacing/side stepping, the stage, character movesets, mental conditioning, recognizing habits, and just trying to outwit the other player. It's not over until the announcer says KO, you can come back and win even if you only have 1 HP left. The depth of this game is astounding. No other fighting game can keep your attention like Tekken. There's a huge amount of player freedom: characters often have multiple taunts, secret moves, silly moves like backflips and  that can do damage, so many fun stances,  This game has a steep learning curve that never really levels off. There is always more to learn and you can always get better. There will always be a new challenge to overcome. I play mostly online but there is a thriving global tournament scene. It's a mix of old arcade players and younger fighting game rookies. There are still new players all the time so don't worry about not finding someone that matches your abilities. You can always find someone in a Discord server ready to play. If you ever see me online just know that I'm always trying to clown around. I'll throw you over my shoulder into the wall to finish the round because I'm winning and I'm having fun.Edit: Season 4 is a huge improvement. They rebalanced some aspects of the game and it got rid of the unreasonable combo damage some characters were getting. Also the netplay got an update, and while some matches are still a stuttery mess, most feel like flawless rollback netcode with just a very slight manageable delay. The future of the series is uncertain, but I can say this is probably the best that Tekken has ever been. There are new players all the time so don't be afraid to jump in and start from scratch. This is by far the best fighting game I have ever played.

reviews.text: I previously had minimal experience playing fighting games but in July 2019 I decided to buy Tekken 7 for PlayStation 4 and can honestly say that it changed my life. Since then, I've also bought both the Xbox One and PC versions just so I could play against as many different people as possible. I've put in over 1000 hours of gameplay across all three platforms and have gone from being a total noob to reaching a peak rank of Tekken King (rank 33) with Kuma -- there are 37 ranks in Tekken 7, each one exponentially more difficult to achieve than the last as you must consistently defeat opponents within two ranks of yourself to rank up, but consistent losses to opponents within two ranks of yourself will cause you to rank down. The competition online becomes pretty hardcore at around rank 24 (Mighty Ruler), so any rank above that generally signifies a player highly skilled with that character. Never before have I spent so much time outside of a game looking to improve my skills by reading strategies online and watching videos of experts in an effort to become ranked as high as I possibly can.Tekken gives back as much as you put in and even 1000+ hours later there are still numerous techniques I'm yet to master and moves I'm yet to commit to memory -- and that's with just a handful of the 51 characters on the roster. There is never a moment wasted whilst playing as you're always learning something new and honing your skills. The way the momentum can instantly shift from a well-timed counter hit makes each match so dynamic and exhilarating, and it means epic comebacks are never out of the question.That's not to suggest that the game is flawless -- far from it. For example: the load times are lengthy (made more frustrating by the inability to instantly rematch), the user interface is rudimentary and dull, there are very few modes, there are no tutorials, and rage quitting is common as there is minimal punishment for doing so. The Rage Art, Rage Drive, and Power Crush mechanics are very controversial amongst the playerbase but I personally think they're great as they keep every round tense from start to finish.It's also perhaps worth mentioning that after enjoying this game so much I played some Tekken 6 and Tekken Tag Tournament 2 and can confidently say that, whilst still fun, they are nowhere near as enjoyable as Tekken 7 in my opinion. So there is definitely something special here; this isn't just an iterative sequel that I've only fallen in love with due to a lack of experience with the previous games in the series. I also played Tekken 3 and Tekken 5 back in the day but, again, never enough to actually get good at them.Tekken 7 is an absolute masterpiece and has become, without question, my favourite competitive multiplayer game of all time. I'm 30 years old and have been a hardcore gamer all my life but no other game has even come close to the enjoyment, adrenaline, satisfaction, and sense of achievement that winning a single close-fought match in Tekken 7 can give me. If you're considering this game for its single-player then there are certainly better options out there such as Mortal Kombat 11 or Injustice 2, but when it comes to competitive fighting games then Tekken 7 simply has no equal.Welcome to the King of Iron Fist Tournament 7. Get ready for the next battle.

reviews.text: or let me say this; When we think of old video games, our subconscious mind goes to childhood or adolescence games. Games that we dig into our memories to see that makeup half of our memories. Definitely one of those games is Tekken, which, with its release on Sony's first console, was able to attract a lot of fans and become one of the serious competitors for Mortal Kombat. Years pass, and these two veteran rivals have risen alongside each other. Two fighting games with different shapes and icons for fans, one targeting the East style and the other the West style. Of course, the presence of other fighting games such as the Injustice series has led Mortal Kombat's production team to target a wider audience.when that  has been released, it was time for Tekken 7 to show itself. The main question here is, was Tekken 7 as good as it looks?"Children begin their work with the love and affection of their parents, soon after judging them and finally forgiving infrequently."<< BEFORE READING: next paragraph contains spoiler >>The STORY of the game is narrated according to this quote. Where Kazuya Mishima's hatred of his father is well portrayed. On the other hand, the story of Tekken 7 will show the audience what caused the death of Kazumi by Heihachi and why Kazuya hates his father. The story of the game cannot be considered the end of the Mishima family's war and conflict, but it closes the case of the events between father and son. The story is told in the language of a narrator. A journalist who has started researching Mishima Zaybatso and G company and intends to find the reason for the destruction of his hometown. Tekken 7 includes a main story and a side story, in the main story, the events are narrated in three different branches, and finally, they are in the same direction and are well summarized. On the one hand, Kazuya, who intends to destroy Heihachi and avenge his childhood and his mother's. Akuma, on the other hand, enters the field. Someone who has promised Kazumi in the past to destroy Heihachi. Now that these characters are taking revenge, the Tex Force team is trying to find Jin Kazama and bring him back to Mishima zaibatsu<<END OF SPOILER>> in a fighting game, gameplay plays the most important role. That the game can satisfy the audience well in the combat system or other areas is the most important factor that any fighting game should consider. Therefore, Tekken 7 has shown itself well in this section. Most fighting games try to modernize, however, Tekken 7 is well-balanced between a modern fighting game and a classic fighting game. The presence of old combos, the animation style of the fights, and the movement of the players are all reminiscent of the previous versions, which are available here with new elements. The most important thing to consider is how to use Rage Art. In fact, Rage Arts are the special combinations of players that you can use. As your health bar approaches critical conditions, a red halo appears around you, signaling the activation of Rage Art. Now you can use serious buttons to inflict serious damage on your opponent. Other gameplay features that give the game a fresh look is Power Crush, which allows you to hit your opponent when you're being hit and stop their combo. The slow-motion feature has also been added to this version since the sixth version to once again illustrate the sensitivity of all-time kicks. Now suppose that all these combat capabilities and features will find their true meaning when they being used in great combos and continue hitting when your opponent is between heaven and earth and don't let your opponent get a chance to hit. You can also use the walls of the game environment to combine your shots and do more damage to the opponent. The availability of these features has not only not made the gameplay crowded, but has made the fights more precise; Find out exactly when you need to use your Rage Art or Rage Move, when to hit and when to hit your opponent harder, or when to use a combination of environments combo.Aside from storytelling, gameplay in both offline and online includes a variety of combat modes, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. In the offline section, the arcade mode of the game includes fights with AI. When I entered this section, I expected to see several fights for each character, but for each character, there are only five fights, among which Heihachi and Kazumi that are present in all the fights. In other words, you only have three fights in which the AI ​​characters are random and new. After a while, the arcade mode will make you very tired and you may not go to this section anymore. But no matter how weak the arcade mode, Treasure Battle mode compensates for it. In this part, you will fight your favorite characters with other characters in the game, and then you will have a series of special competitions with Heihachi, Jin, Akuma, and Kazuya.There are two things you can never get tired of in treasure mode. The first is the greater number of fights than the arcade section, and the second and most important is the availability of chests at the end and beginning of each match. Now, another difference between the arcade mode and the Treasure Battle mode is the game's AI (artificial intelligence). In the story section, you can determine the artificial intelligence and the difficulty yourself, but in this section, there are no such options. Therefore, we see the rank-based difficulty.The online part is another pillar of the Tekken 7 gameplay; Where players from all over the world come together to test their skills. The online part of the game consists of three different modes. The first mode of Player Match that you will compete with other players or you can create a lobby yourself so that the players can connect to you and play. In both Ranked and Player Match modes, you can hardly find an opponent, and if it is found, your ping is so different from your opponent that you are all over the game during the game, or you can't connect to the opponent's server and player at all. Now the only part of the tournament that you can easily play with others (of course, if we factor in ping problems). Of course, sometimes during the tournament, the host may lose and leave the game. Then you will leave the tournament and all your efforts will be wasted, and unfortunately, there is no specific punishment for the violators.One thing that has always stood out in the Tekken series is the game's graphics and game design. Thanks to the Unreal Engine 4 graphics engine, the development team has tried to strike a balance between classic and modern in the game's graphics. The struggles and designs of the environment and the characters all promise a classic Tekken game. Apart from that, Tekken 7's combat environments have a good variety, and some of them include two combat places that, if your fight lasts, you will see that the place you're fighting in, will be ruined by your hits and opponent falls and enter another part of the place. With all these interpretations, Tekken 7 came back after years of waiting for the fans of this series to make good moments for them again. An original oriental fighting game that has been around for about 20 years and has tried to add new elements to its audience experiences. Apparently, the game never intends to make big changes, and that could be good news for fans.

reviews.text: Muse Dash is a rhythm action game developed by Chinese studio called PeroPeroGames. Steam version is completed mobile port which share same price of base game.Muse Dash is like a warm place where you sit back and enjoy both music and visual. Subjectively, I was drawn colorful art design and stylish flashy characters (which remind me of anime like Panty and Stocking). The game has hybrid concept between side-scrolling beat ‘em up on the rail and rhythm beat which are executed very well.The control is tight and responsive compared to mobile touch pad. You simply control character using two keyboard buttons (which can be modified or set alternate keys via option). One key is to hit enemy notes at ground level and another one is to hit enemy notes on the air. It sounds simple, but also challenges sense of rhythm of player where you face variant types of note from common long note to invisible note. Dodging sawblade notes and utilizing your timing to maintain combo and character HP to the end of song.Similar to other rhythm games, the game has judge system (indicates input accuracy based on timing), but is more much simplified and forgiving as “Perfect”, “Great”, “Pass”, and “Miss” that will break your current combo and affect overall accuracy. The game will also enter “Fever mode” once player maintains amount of combo, allow player to boost score in short period and can be set as manual spacebar key.Your starter character is Rin. By completing any songs regardless of difficulty, you will gain user EXP for leveling up. Each level will unlock random troves used to unlock new playable characters (Rin, Buro, Marija), new elfins (supporting companions), and many beautiful illustration (allow you to customize loading screen). The process is random and varied for each user, but player will easily unlock everything at certain point.Speaking of characters, each main character has different 4-5 costumes, theme, and likeable personalities. Both costumes and elfins provide player benefit one way or another based on playstyle and specific gimmick. Some can match up with elfin to boost extra scores or maintain HP. Some can use to boost overall accuracy or lengthen judge area to the point you feel comfortable and familiar with beats. The system is friendly for casual players while keeping master challenge for veterans.The game offers 3 difficulties (Easy, Hard, and Master except for few default songs). Master difficulty only unlock when player completes “S Rank” on hard (90% accuracy). Higher difficulty contains more notes that synchronize most beats of the track or completely replace different sequences from Easy and Hard. It may sounds hard on paper, but as I consider myself as average player for this genre. It’s common for every rhythm games that you invest time for practicing to the point that it becomes muscle memory. Combine with strong visual feedback from beating wave of enemy notes and bosses at end of level. It’s such an addictive and satisfying gameplay loop that I genuinely enjoy everyday regardless of scoreboard.Muse Dash offers great variety of songs (both vocal and instrumental). For example: dubstep, eurobeat, EDM, Jazz, vlolin, vocaloid, pop, mystical, BMS, and other mixup. You may expect some Chinese vocal songs and some Japanese songs. But they are overall catchy and aesthetic in their own way. It also encourages me to dig into meaningful lyrics and discover more talented cover / composers. There are some familiar songs that share among other rhythm games (Arcaea, DJMax, Maimai, and more) such as “conflict”, “Destr0yer”, “PUPA”, “MilK”, and much more.The base game has total 52 initial songs (43 default songs, 3 Nanocore, 6 Budget is Burning) with $3 price tag served as standard version, provide full access of all characters and elfins to experiment. It’s worth checking without DLC to get a grasp how the game plays out.While mobile version has various bundles, Steam version has single DLC called “Just as planned” with current 132 extra songs (free 6 songs will be added every month). This DLC serves as one-time payment for long-term support if player really interests into the gameplay and music types. I personally think $30 price tag is reasonably worth considering amount of licensed songs the developers have to pay and generate notes for each song. If you’re still uncomfortable for a price and expectation which understandable in some regions, you can follow the game page and wait for DLC sale.Muse Dash runs on Unity game engine with friendly spec requirement and well optimization. I had no performance issue or FPS drop during 37 hours of playtime. Stylish and flashy UI, but easy to navigate between menus. Due to mobile design, you need to press ESC from main menu to exit the game.Aside from fantastic visual and gameplay loop, there are few cons I found that can be problematic to new player such as transition effect of Fever mode can be bad distraction. In few songs, enemy notes in some portions doesn’t sync perfectly to music beat or slightly offbeat especially on high level Master difficulty. However, you can adjust offset delay if the problem relates to your monitor. Same as background brightness if you feel like notes are blending to backdrop. Lastly, I notice register / delay problem of daily challenge at least on latest patch. Muse Dash is a rhythm game with its own identity. Solid gameplay, high replayability, and satisfying feeling of hitting beats as music enthusiast. It’s something I could enjoy from hard day and share experience with friends in Discord. Wherever you’re not familiar with rhythm genre or not, Muse Dash is another title that worth checking.

reviews.text: This game saved my life.I am 42.My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.Thank you

reviews.text: Muse Dash is a colourful rhythm game with a good variety in music and a satisfying gameplay loop.The game's music is overall "Anime", but they manage to mix it up. Some of it is more cutesy and dancey, while others take cues from jazz or swing, and others are a bit more hardcore or dubstep-y. I thought the quality of the soundtrack overall was really awesome, and I've had songs stuck in my head for weeks since playing this game.On top of that, I actually have just found myself gravitating towards playing the game a bit everyday. That's because of the great gameplay.It's simple, but has enough depth to it to make you feel cool when you nail a string of notes.So the way the game works, is you play with only two buttons. (This is because the game was initially designed as a mobile game) You press one button to attack at ground level, and one button to attack in the air. Then all you need to do is time your attacks with the notes that come your way, Guitar-Hero-style. The game mixes it up by having some held notes, some notes that turn invisible after a while, or some that have you button mash as much as possible. But the more interesting gameplay comes at the highest difficulty. There are 3 difficulties, easy, hard and master. Not all songs have all difficulties, and you need to unlock Master for every song individually, which you do by earning an S rank on Hard, which isn't as daunting as it sounds. The game does a great job at making all the notes make sense with the song, while at the same time mixing up the notes. So two verses in the song might sound identical, but play asymmetrically, and it's really interesting and fun.The game played totally fine on both my xbox 360 controller, and my keyboard. On PC controls, all keys were rebindable, while on the controller the entire left side of the controller controls one note, while the entire right side controls the other note, which I appreciated.There are scoreboards that drive you to better yourself everytime, and you can interestingly even sync up your save and scores with the mobile and PC version via online login.I really appreciated all of the options they provide you with. One of them being an "offset" that you can use to try and perfect your audio sync with the visuals, in case your monitor screws with that.Even more fun though, is unlocking new characters and elfins. All 3 characters have different stats that affect your scoring and playstyle, and they each have a bunch of costumes to unlock that each have their own unique and fun stats. Elfins are pets that just follow you in a level and give you passive buffs. You unlock all of this by simply playing the game and levelling up. This can be sped up by getting unique achievements per song, as well as daily tasks that refresh every 24 hours.Unfortunately, that's also the only way to unlock new songs. At some point I reached a dead end and had to go back and replay old songs before I could unlock and play newer ones. I found that a bit frustrating. Although it didn't take too long, and I would have replayed old songs anyway, it still was a bit annoying.The catchy music, great gameplay and charming aesthetic really made me fall in love with this game. A few more level designs would be great, as it can get a bit stale cycling through the same 4ish levels, but I'm hopeful they'll continue adding new content to the game following its launch, as they have in the past with the mobile version.Overall, I highly recommend the game to rhythm-game fans, it's up there as one of my favourites now.

This includes input drops on fast presses (several enemies very close together), random delays in inputs overall (up to several seconds), hits on some enemies straight up not registering, hits not registering for some time after "hitting air" (pressing key when there is no enemy to be hit), combos breaking after hitting a certain enemy in some levels... These issues make it hard/impossible to play harder levels properly, but also affect simple, slow levels.  It should've never taken so long though as the issue was apparently caused because they changed the name of the folder which stores user data.In case you decide to reinstall the game hoping for it to fix the issues - it won't do anything as the update was the size of the whole game, which effectively reinstalled it for you.

reviews.text: " As you may have known what happened to Muse Dash earlier this week. I hope the players are aware of the whole situation instead of just attacking the game and leave bad reviews. Keep in mind that PeroPeroGames released a statement in Discord stating that they have nothing to do with it and they have no political stance. X.D. is the publisher and a network in China, and X.D. (心動網絡) is the company that released the statement. " -RhythmGameMusic, YouTuber Please do not deliver the hate towards the developers of the game, and please do not bombard the reviews in a negative manner. It is reckless to show your disdain in this manner, as you are only hurting the developer and not placing blame on the publisher. It isn't as easy as to "self publish" a game, and we probably don't have insider knowledge as to why they simply couldn't self publish. While it is unfortunate that this transpired, please recognize that blind hatred on the store page is not the way to express yourself. Take each negative review with a grain of salt, if possible. Thank you.I originally bought the game on a small sale of about 20%, and I feel like I've been missing out on a game quite as fun as this for a while. I originally started out with an Xbox One controller, and most of the early stages are quite friendly to accommodate for players wanting to play on a controller. However, I would most definitely advise to make a transition to keyboard if you start off on a controller. Later stages and difficulties make it difficult to consistently hit your notes on time, though the ergonomic positives of playing on a controller compared to a keyboard are quite nice.As mentioned previously, this game has a diverse set of different genres in the game. From slow, low BPM songs, all the way up to the adrenaline-inducing, high BPM songs. Muse Dash has a great selection for any level of rhythm gamer, and the upfront price of the base game makes it quite an attractive rhythm game for those on a budget. Along your progression, you unlock many new songs and thus unlocking more genres and styles of songs which allows you to keep perfecting your experience as a rhythm gamer. As someone who has a history with mainly Guitar Hero, Muse Dash has great variety in the songs that are playable.Difficulty wise, I could only suggest that this game is easy only if you can get used to your control layout and get immersed into the rhythm and beat of a particular song. Having a control layout depends on different factors, but the optimal layout should be customized by the player themselves so that they can enjoy the game with relatively little problem getting used to the controls.  Rhythm and beat is difficult to get down on the first try of a song, but rhythm games are meant to be infinitely replayable and allow players to practice the song over and over until they eventually get their skill to a point they feel satisfied with. Don't feel discouraged when you do poorly on a song the first time; practice always makes perfect.Unlockables are aplenty in this game, and they can be obtained relatively easy. For every song you clear on a chosen difficulty, you receive a certain amount of experience points based on your performance and on what challenges you accomplish during your session. Early level ups offer pieces to illustrations that you can view and set as the loading screens in game, or materials that are needed to unlock different characters. After the mid level 100s, however, there will be a lack of incentive to unlock by this point unless you rely on new content that might be added in the future. But in general, unlockables are generally easy to obtain and only are cosmetic changes to your loading screens.There are three main characters, with an additional character with a single costume at the time of writing this review. The three main Muses; Rin, Buro, and Marija. Rin is the only accessible character to play with, but the rest of them can be unlocked later on with their alternate costumes also being unlockable. Every single character, along with their alt costumes, provide different skills and utilities for the player to utilize in a song. Elfins are also unlockable companions that also achieve the same uses for the characters, providing useful abilities that will be passive use in a song. Great selection of cute characters, and equally cute costumes.Honestly, watching a VTuber flex their rythmic talent in this game was enough for me to get this game and get back into a rythm game. Before a certain VTuber introduced me to this game, I have never heard of the game beforehand. After playing the game for the past 2 months, I can say that Muse Dash has been a phenomenal experience and it keeps delivering new content once per month to provide new experiences.I've been a bit caught up in trying to either Full Combo a song on its highest difficulty, or trying to aim for a spot on the leaderboards for a particular song. I didn't really think I'd take the game so seriously, but the thrill of playing a song so well can really get to you. It gets your blood pumping.I think the bottom line to why I bought Muse Dash, was because my absence from any rythm games got me interested to play Muse Dash. I'm happy to know that I can put my prior experiences to good use in this game. I'm really loving this game and all the favorited songs I replay. The base game of Muse Dash allows access to one full album of music, around 52 songs in total. For the DLC to cost 10 times as much as the base game, which is $3, seems like a skeptical purchase to some people. Even if you did the math to account for each unique song added from the DLC compared to the base game's 52-or-so songs, the DLC would only come up to around $13 in value when you compare song-to-count ratio (52 base songs: 227 DLC songs) . It is a steep purchase, and you essentially have to buy the DLC to experience the rest of the game's content. I would only recommend purchasing this DLC if you either can part ways with $30, or you could find the DLC on sale at any discount possible. But, the DLC has a ton more music to include and will always be added onto whenever the developers add in new albums with an update. So, kinda up to you if you can dedicate yourself to even more songs.+ Muse Dash is a big recommend from me. As a long-time casual rhythm gamer, Muse Dash was an easy pick-up for me to start playing.+ Play on either keyboard or with controller, whichever works for you.+ Music genres and choices are really good, and there is certain to be a song you'll return to whenever you boot the game up.+ Good unlockables, making the experience more fulfilling for players wanting a lot of content with their game on top of the base game.+/- DLC has a ton more content to play with, but a retail price of $30 makes it difficult to fully recommend it.- The "V-Sync" setting for refresh rates may hinder your chances of getting big combos, as there have been reports of the setting being prone to interruptions during gameplay. Additionally, the game may desync with the audio and obviously can cause players frustrations in keeping with the rhythm.[/b]

reviews.text: Muse Dash offers a cute and vibrant art style to go along with a simple and addicting two button style gameplay. The game has three base characters to choose from that you will unlock costumes and companions for in a token style system as you play. During songs you have to hit and avoid things on either the top or bottom plane as you continually run. There are three difficulties you can choose from for most songs allowing for you to enjoy regardless of your skill. There is a fair amount of varied content content in the songs and as you can probably tell from the store page where this game really shines is it's cutesy design and vibrant color scheme. Honestly the only gripe I have isn't anything major or deserved. There is a lot of content locked behind a paywall. At first it was 20 songs you would unlock if you bought it from what I remember seeing but there are even more songs added now. I've read how some would prefer to have a steam workshop but it may be hard to keep the charm and design over custom added songs. The dlc price is a bit steep but it's probably worth if you enjoy the game and they keep cranking out content. Just clearing the base content of this game took me around four hours and I'll probably go back to it every once in a while. I hope to be able to pick up the dlc one day and experience everything this game has to offer and I hope they continue to add more content. For now if you enjoy rhythm games; I can easily recommend Muse Dash for the base price seeing the great content you get. 𝕀𝕗 𝕐𝕠𝕦 𝔼𝕟𝕛𝕠𝕪 𝕋𝕙𝕚𝕤 𝕋𝕣𝕪

reviews.text: + Colorful environments with flashy characters,+ Music tends to go along the aesthetics of the game. It is energetic, classy and dynamic.+ There is a good number of mobs to crush, from enemies having different models to bosses.+ The game price is relatively low for the quality it presents. Characters have animations and are rich in detail.+ The sound effects are not an extra or queue for notes, instead, they complement the songs in the game.+ Lots of replayability with DLC songs. Some of them are free rewards once the player reaches a certain level.- The game starts very easy, which can be boring for some players.- Leaderboard requires a sign in into your google account in order to post your score.- Since the game is flashy and features vivid colors, playing on a room that it is not bright enough can be a bother.Muse Dash is a hybrid-rhythm game that successfully combines the elements of side-scroller with the fast-paced beats of a music game. It also features a lot of quality when it comes to details in its final product, as characters have their own animations and look. Enemies do as well, as the variety of mobs and bosses add a rich layer to the game as well as a vibe that goes between comedy and cuteness. In Muse Dash, players must hit musical beats which are featured as a sort of elements. These can range from robots to lollipops or starts. As they beat these notes, hazardous elements such as enemies traps or bosses that will spawn to obstruct the player progress and eventually create a sort of mini showdown after which they will retire. Early levels start off easy as a sort of practice mode, while later ones can be hard to beat on higher difficulties. There are three characters in the game, these are Rin, Buro, and Marija. Each of these characters has different costumes that each possess their own effects and will affect gameplay. For example, default Marija will make it so that when a combo is under 100, missing a note won't break the combo while default Buro becomes invincible during fever mode. These can be stacked with Elfin effects. Elfins are little creatures that will help the players by giving them more fever time, reducing damage and more.Fever mode is activated when the player fills up the fever gauge. This can be done quickly by successfully maintaining a combo. While in fever mode, notes give more score and the visuals change to reflect an even more energetic style. Fever mode can also be used to recover some health if enemies with hearts show up.Songs have a number below them in each difficulty. This number indicates how hard it is to beat the song on the said setting. The first songs are extremely easy, even on hard which will result in lots of full combos(perfects). However, once the player reaches lv 25-30, songs will start to become more challenging, especially on master difficulty. So, for those of you who enjoy those insane notes being stacked together, don't worry, they are in the game.What makes Muse Dash so singular is that it really goes out of its way with the aesthetics. Every element seems to complement each other rather than being the result of an addition. The characters are flashy, the enemies have lots of models featuring cute and fun themes, the songs are energetic, the visuals are vivid and the bosses show-up in style. It is like watching the game put on a show while playing it.Every detail is executed with the utmost cared. From Buro's facial expressions when she hits notes to costumes and sound. The songs are fast paced but the rhythm is always present and new enemies keep getting added as the player progresses through the song list. This quality resembles a certain extent, that of a AAA game.I would recommend players to play on hard mode, and then move to master. This way there is a learning curve of sorts for each song, while also adding some complexity to the gameplay. It can be sort of boring at first, but it gets much better later in the game.There are also multiple stages, from cities filled with robotic enemies to candy islands filled with pink palettes to a factory in space. The stages are a nice touch and they can keep the game from getting repetitive, as having the same background for all songs would be detrimental. The enemy models can vary in the same stage, this means that sometimes you can see certain types of enemies while in another song the mobs will be different, even if the stage is the same one.The game runs like butter. Most systems should be getting 100-200 frames with ease. Muse Dash is a game that can be both fun and entertaining to watch, and you are getting much more than your money's worth with the quality present here. The only thing I didn't like so much is that rather than featuring its own leaderboard, it borrows it from google which might look a little cheap.What makes this game special is that it does manage to keep the player attention after multiple sessions. Usually, a rhythm game will be bought and eventually forgotten, but Muse Dash makes the player come back to it whenever it is because of the side-scroller elements, it’s aesthetics or the characters commenting on the main menu. It is a rhythm game that tries to soar among its peers by adding lots of little details.What also makes this special is how fun it is. Smacking enemies to the rhythm of a song can be great for casual fun and some enjoyment. At the same time, getting that full combo or aiming for a place in the scoreboard can be challenging, this invites the player to revisit songs they had already cleared, and with the mixes of its elements, it becomes something to look forward rather than a task.Muse Dash is a fantastic game that features lots of elements, mixes them together and keeps elevating them. Its strongest point is it’s a presentation, everything looks nice and rich in detail. The song list is pretty good and it's always funny to see how the characters speak to the player on screen. This is a game that was put effort into it, and it was worth to do so based on the attention it has been getting. I recommend this to all players who want to try a rhythm game but don't feel too sure and to everyone who enjoys this kind of games.

reviews.text: TL;DR: The game plays out well, and the music is addicting. Characters, costumes, Elfins, and songs will continue to be put out for this game, which is really neat. For people who are still on the edge for buying the DLC songs, I am almost 100% sure that when they release new song packs, those songs will be included in the DLC; It sort of acts as a Season Pass. Absolutely get this game, and if you can afford it, get the DLC as well.This game is a total blast to play. People may turn away from it's simplistic controls and it's limited 2 lane mechanics, but the feeling of nailing a combo and popping that Fever at just the right time is just amazing. And the characters you play also add up to that experience, with each of them having unique animations for their personalities.The characters that they introduce are not only cute, but each costume that they get have certain abilities, such as increased Fever bar gain, or more health per pick-up. There is even a costume that lets you watch a perfect run of the song. There are also Elfins, little pets that you can bring during your song in order to give you another special ability to use.The only downside to this, is the way you obtain these characters and Elfins. You start off with one character and no Elfins, and as you level up, you collect items that will unlock a specific character/Elfin. Each character/Elfin needs 8 specific items to be obtained. This can become a grind, and after a while, you'll be replaying the songs you can do in order to gain the exp to level up. But you can see this as a positive too; at least they didn't hide any of the characters behind a paywall. (At least, from when I'm posting this.)The songs are very mixed, actually. Some are vocaloid, some are instrumental, and some are just regularly sung songs in Japanese or Chinese. These are actually pretty nice songs, and fit perfectly with the type of game this is. In the base game, they start off easy, and continually become harder and harder to complete, which helps players visualise their progress in something more than just unlocking songs.Unlocking songs works kind of in the same way that unlocking characters does, but instead of having to obtain items, it is directly linked to your level. Songs are unlocked each level until a point, then are unlocked every two levels. (Final one is an exception, needing 5 more levels after the previous song.) I only had to replay a song once or twice in order to unlock a few of the songs, which was nice. But the variety in songs gave me enough experience in order to expand my knowledge on this games mechanics.All in all, a very solid game, worthy of its praise so far. Keep up the good work guys.

reviews.text: Weeaboostone is a significantly better game than Moneystone. With how generous cygames is, having a viable ladder deck takes no time, and the gameplay isn't who gets the better RNG. There's lots of skill and counterplay, and TL;DR I highly reccomend this game if you like CCG's. That being said, the game does have its problems:Power Creep: the devs have stated they want this card game to be very high-powered, but balance is still important. I feel they still have a few lessons to learn in regards to card design and balance, and I'm very curious to see what the game will look like in a few years.Art Style: I'm really not a fan of anime, and the in-your-face sexuality gets to me. Some of the art is really cool, but if this game ever wants to reach a bigger audience, this probably has to be addressed. Don't play this game at workValue of Real-World Money: I'm the U.S., so this will be written with that in mind. The value of purchasing packs with IRL currency is extremely poor. The daily deal is great, but most people who want packs want to crack them here and now, myself included. Currently, there's a deal for what is essentially 76 packs for $80 USD, which I feel should be the default price, with like 100 packs for $80 being a good deal. This IS offset by cygames giving out free packs like pedos give out candy, but still.These cons are, I feel, heavily offset by the pros of the game. Very fun and unique gameplay, generous devs (have I mentioned this enough yet? Coming from Hearthstone this was such a huge, huge difference), quick balance updates, and card design that makes even control mirrors take no time makes this game one of the best digital CCGs on the market. Definitely a game to watch for the next few years, especially if the competition (read: Blizzard) continues to treat its customers like garbage.

reviews.text: If you're looking for a decent CCG, then you've come to the right place! Casual play. Competitive play. Card Collector. The game is able to provide all of this without the need to spend money.I have been playing this game since June 15th, 2016 and my biggest fear was needing to cash in to keep up with the meta. Thankfully, I never felt the need to spend money!The catch? Just log in every day and do your daily quests and in 3 months you could gain a whopping  rupees! That's 100 packs! That's 800 cards! In a month they give out 640 rupees + 6 free packs + 2 Arena tickets just for logging in!Maintenance extended? BAM. 5 more free packs!Special events? The new year's event alone gave everyone 1100 rupees (11 packs) just for logging in! For the one year anniversary they gave away a whopping 40 packs!New expansion? 10 free packs!New player? It varies, but you are guaranteed at least 30+ packs just for creating an account!Defeating Elite AI? Seven different classes, 200 rupees each. 1400 rupees!? When will the generosity END?What? Private matches with unique players give you 100 each? YOU CAN DO THIS 20 TIMES? 2000 RUPEES?Playing story gives you rupees (280 rupees)? Ascending ranks gives you rupees(100 each)? Arena runs gives you packs and rupees?You're guaranteed a pack even if you lose all 5 matches in areYOU CAN REROLL ACCOUNTS FOR BETTER LEGENDARIES? (Actually important, pls research more about rerolling)How can a game be so generous? Is it failing? Is that why they give away so many free things?. Shadowverse is originally a Japanese mobile game, the mobile game market in Japan is  competitive. Shadowverse in Japan is massively popular and even has TV commercials! You don't need to worry about the future of Shadowverse.Now, just talking about the generosity makes me run out of breath. Onto the most important part of a good game.Is the game fun?Yes! That is my answer. Why?Whoops, I guess I should start formatting a little better, right? Sigh. Sorry for hurting your eyes! Please bear with me. . .Whoaaaaa, it's been a while since I played story.Uhhhh, there's 7 different classes with 10+ missions each! Heh, I'm not going to spoil it though!  (It's also voiced in English/Japanese/---Korean.)Before playing multiplayer I *highly* recommend finishing all of the story to get a feel for all the different classes. All the free stuff is great and the story provides vital cards that are actually meta in ranked play.   A little joke for veterans of the game ;)This is also where you pick your favorite class! Every single craft can hit B3 rank with no real problems, just have fun and learn how to play the game! Though be wary of jumping into A rank, meta decks rule from then on!Unranked is the land of meme decks, all the non-competitive worthy decks roam the lands of unranked just to try to fish out the hilarious (usually inconsistent) win from their off-meta deck. This is also a great place to finish your daily quests for those sweet sweet rupees!Ooo, ranked play. A daunting task awaits you...not really. Everyone is considered a noobie until they hit A rank (others debate the real game begins in AA rank). reviews.text: This review is complicated to write for me and even harder to choose if I recommend or not so I've broken it down into two categories:1. Are you looking for a fun 10-20 hours of getting generous amounts of cards, the ability to build pretty much any deck you want completely f2p and enjoying an anime artstyle with interesting mechanics? Then yes, I recommend this game.2. Are you looking for a competitive in-depth card game where at the higher levels of play unique decks are possible and there's always a niche for creativity? Then no, I do not recommend this game. Since this is what I personally enjoy I'm putting this recommendation as No as a result.This wasn't always the case, I have 650 hours on this game for a reason. In the beginning Shadowverse was widely accepted to be horribly unbalanced and there were very clear good decks and bad decks. Then around the end of 2017 they released a new faction and something called Rotation mode. In this mode they simply only had in play the five most recent expansions. This allowed all the cards people had a problem with that dominated the meta to slowly be "rotated out".By late 2018 they had rotated out all of the "problem cards" and this was by far the best time to play Shadowverse. At this point my favorite class "Swordcraft" was considered to be the lowest tier in the game and I still enjoyed the game and climbed to the highest rank on the competitive ladder using unique decks and synergizing weird effects. At this point I roped in every friend I could find and put a bunch of money into the game even though f2p is 100% viable just because I wanted to support the development of the game.However this all changed when the fire nation attacked. Ehehe, just kidding but when the game was at its most balanced and there were no clear winners or losers Cygame released the "Rebirth of Glory" expansion in the middle of 2019. This expansion reintroduced a lot of the "overpowered" problem cards that everyone had issues with and ever since then there are very clear meta defining decks and cards and anything else became unplayable in high level play.Unfortunately rather than scaling back after a lot of community outcry, they continued to release even stronger cards in every expansion in attempt I can only speculate to be "If everyone is special, then no one is special". Unfortunately this just meant that mixing esoteric card effects were no longer anywhere near as effective as the overpowered cards they printed specifically to counteract the Pandora's box they opened. After playing through 3 expansions in the hope some semblance of the game I fell in love with would return, I finally stopped playing. I haven't given up completely and still return every expansion and look at the meta in the hopes that things have changed, but it's been 2 years now.

reviews.text: Alright seeing there's a lot of nonsense negative review I'll chime in to address a lot of misconceptions to those bad review. I find it annoying to see so many negative reviews with so little understanding of how the game even works (like giving a negative review just because they don't know how to mute the music in 2019, what the actual f- ?). I dunno if they're just memeing or actually serious but here's an  you should read about the game made by someone who played this game for a long time.  Absolutely not! With enough time and some grind, you can craft all the card you need. There's no exclusive card/feature you can buy with real money. The only worthwhile things you can buy with real money are cosmetics and pre-built deck which is an option if you want to immediately jump-start your card collection. Once again, these thing doesn't affect the gameplay and only there if you want to ease up your grind to get those key cards.Everyone is on the same playing field with game knowledge (i.e class matchup) being your real show of skill.Shadowverse is one of the best F2P CCG out there. Out of the gate, you're given one of each legendary card that exists up to Steel Rebellion expansion (looking at you  person). On top of that, you also get 50 free packs (10 packs from 5 of the latest expansion) after you're done with the tutorial. This will immensely help your card collection to create a lot of useable budget deck immediately. There's also a lot of in-game events such as collab and tournament that will easily net you in-game currencies if you just log in and play for a few hours. Heck, they even introduce a temporary card system that allows you to create a useable legendary card you need from now on. Lastly, there's daily mission you can do and clearing this will easily net you AT LEAST a pack/day.No, far from that. There's no high win RNG play you should worry in this game. The closest is probably a card named Truth Adjudication but even that is tied to how well you pilot the deck before playing said card. Anybody who relies on that card as a win-con is just asking for trouble.Keep in mind a little bit of RNG is okay since it makes the game unpredictable sometimes and Shadowverse is in the fine balance of it.Since there are two main formats in this game I'll address it in their respective format. But before we start , the dev  makes a monthly balance when they think needed. Sometimes they don't do it because their in-house data about win and pick rate doesn't support it but if that's the case then they will at least inform you about it. If it gets  the dev doesn't afraid to make emergency balance before the month ended. Now then...Rotation is a format where you can only use cards from the five newest sets. This is probably the most balanced format since the dev has better control over the meta. All cards in this format usually fall in-line in power with a few cards slightly above the other which is fine. Every deck needs some strong cards to be relevant after all.     Unlimited is a format where you can use ALL the card that exists in the game. Now as you can imagine, this is a tricky one to balance because with so many cards in the poll you can't expect a perfect balance in here. But because every class has access to it every class can be as powerful as they can be so that will balance itself.I'm not a fan of this format but as they say, when everything is broken nothing is broken.Alright, I think that's all the main point for now. If you have any more question feel free to ask it in the comment section. You can decide yourself to trust me on this one or all these nonsense negative reviews about the game. Shadowverse is a fine game and I think you should give it a chance if you're looking for an anime-style CCG. --------Some extra resource you can look if you want to know more / get started.  > New Player Guide from Reddit> A Public Shadowverse Discord Server

reviews.text: I highly recommend this game. I've read quite a few reviews criticising this game for its overly heavy RNG, and its "pay to win" nature, and i disagree.I picked up this game during TOTG (Tempest of the Gods, the latest expansion), and I've loved every minute of it (much more than 20 hours worth as this game lets you play on the same account on mobile). I especially enjoy the evolve mechanic, which allows the tempo of any given match to swing back and forth. The art is also gorgeous, although some may certainly disagree. And thats fine, because art is inherently subjective. But lets tackle the two big criticisms mentioned above.Overly heavy RNG: There's undoubtedly RNG in any card game. The main issue is the extent to which RNG affects the game, or the user experience. In shadowverse, apart from the inherently luck-based nature of card draws, there are indeed some cards like Jolly Rogers (who randomly gains 1 of 3 effects whenever he's summoned) that are heavily RNG based, but the presence of a few cards that rely on RNG doesnt render the game unplayable, or even bad. It gives the game diversity. If the majority or a substantial number of cards operate on such a basis, then there would certainly be good reason for this criticism. But there isnt."Pay to win" nature of the game: Lets put this upfront, there are powerful legendary cards in this game. If you put them in direct comparison with other non-legendary cards, they certainly look stronger. But to argue that the game is pay to win is simply ridiculous. Many legendary cards are expensive (in terms of mana cost to play), and take time to set up. They can also often be removed by various cards that outright destroy, banish, or transform enemy followers. You can play around them.And the developer Cygames is extremely generous. RIdiculously so. Upon playing a tutorial (which you can skip), you're awarded with something akin to 50 free packs. If you were so minded, you could open all of them, dust the cards that you dislike, and immediately create a cheaper version of a meta deck to climb the ladder. If you start playing right now (in June), you'll reap the benefits of double rewards for completing daily missions, and a plethora of free packs (in the upcoming days), due to the anniversary of Shadowverse.This game isnt perfect. But it is VERY enjoyabole, and doesnt deserve the ♥♥♥♥ that its been getting.

reviews.text: I've put over 700 hours into this game, I'm in Master Rank in both formats and have the Taker of Two achievement, so I'm not some salty new player or a bad player. That being said, this game has gone way downhill from the way it used to be. It's still artistically beautiful and there's still less RNG elements than Hearthstone, but the design has taken multiple bad turns and I'm very close to quitting this game completely. Here are my two biggest complaints-1. Power Creep Has Gotten Absolutely Out of ControlWe're at a point now where the ROTATION format, nevermind the Unlimited format with the far larger card pool, has cards such as 10 resources = Do 15 Damage (Anne's Sorcery) which is basically an auto win or a 5/3 Unit that can literally be played from the deck for free on TURN TWO (Flauros). These cards are not only stupidly imbalanced, but they inherently add RNG to the game because aggro decks can flat out get unbeatable nut draws and there is stone cold nothing the opponent can do, even if they play perfectly and have a reasonable draw. They've also recently introduced "once you play this you gain an effect that happens every turn for the rest of the match no matter what" cards which are also incredibly imbalanced and overpowered and have no counterplay. They're much like Planeswalkers in Magic: The Gathering- you're getting an effect that SHOULD cost resources for free every turn and it's way too strong. This problem is incredibly hard to fix too. Once they've introduced cards like this unless they were to go back and significantly change all of them there is no way around these kind of cards forever dominating the game. I see this problem getting worse over time as opposed to better and I think it's all downhill from here for the competitive metagame.2. Their New Card Pack Policy Is Seedy And Disrespectful To PlayersI've never seen any other card game (and I've played damn near all of them) do this, but Shadowverse's new thing is they'll introduce a "full" card set, make it available to players (and you MUST obtain the Legendaries and other strong cards from each new set when it comes out to stay competitively relevant) and then over a month later they'll introduce a small handful of new, broken cards (which of course includes multiple Legendaries) into the same set they've already released! This directly devalues all the packs you've already purchased of that set. This puts players in an absolute garbage position. You either buy packs of the new set right when it comes out, meaning you'll miss out on the broken cards in that set which will be released weeks later, or you wait until the second wave of cards from that set comes out but in the meantime you're not able to play competitively at the highest level because you do not have the new power cards from the set that just came out. Essentially, not only are they devaluing the packs you're purchasing but they're attempting to get you to buy packs of the same set twice. I find this really seedy and disrespectful to players and it feels like a shameless money-grabbing technique, which this game never used to have.Overall, I used to really, really love this game and I do, as of this writing, still play it but I can be objective and recognize major problems when I see them and this game definitely has them. We're not in "sinking ship" territory yet, and the game is still popular, but the quality and accessibility of the game have already gone down and will continue to go down and disaster IS looming over the horizon. I can't, in good conscience, recommend you start playing this game if you intend to play competitively whatsoever and I myself am likely to quit sometime sooner rather than later.
