reviews.text: *IF YOU ARE ON THE FENCE ABOUT PLAYING SHADOWVERSE* The Take Two (arena-style draft) mode played against a friend is COMPLETELY free, and you can play it as much as you want. This is the best way to play with some of the neat legendary cards and to get a diverse feel for some of the classes with the least amount of investment. If you at least have a little cardgame knowledge (enough to draft with a friend and have fun), then this part is at least worth every bit of your time to download it and try it out. Anyways, Shadowverse is neat little collectible card game with a few unique mechanics, low RNG variance, and easy to learn cards that aren't written in Lawyer's Prose but have a layer of finesse to them, on top of a very, erm, deliberate choice of artstyle. You start with a rather generous amount of free card packs at the start, and is riddled with ways to earn packs/arena vouchers/gold/dust through the achievements system. Each of the classes feels very distinct from one another, and have rather strong identities, along with at least 1 mechanic many class cards are tied to. As an example, bloodcraft's minions are often tied to Vengence, which activates when a player hovers at 10 health or lower, making health management very important to that class. One of the most interesting aspects to Shadowverse is its Evolve mechanic which serves to make the midgame rather vibrant and adds a lot of extra decisions to consider, even when you may have few cards in your hand.If you're at all interested in playing, I'd recommend giving it a shot and, at the very least, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around in the Take Two mode.The PC port is better than the phone/emulator, but is little lacking in some ways; the interface is largely the same as the phone one, but the art on the cards looks much crisper and clearer. It's a lot better than on an emulator, but could be improved upon. Make sure if you're playing for the first time to fix your resolution and you toggle the option for 60fps instead of 30fps.

reviews.text: TL;DR at the bottom if you want to skip things like discussion about statistic. Review updated to fix few typos and incorrect terms. Things to note: The 2000 hours recorded in steam is me as a semi active player. I have been playing since Wonderland Dreams (which around december 2017) and I've been playing on my phone as well.For short term, yes, i would highly suggest this game. It's free, beautiful, story is as fun as sunday morning anime (good or bad depends on you like sunday morning anime), with enough work you can master few classes.But! That said..As a long term player the game is.. let's say.. "Fluctuative".. and "Repetitive"Let's dissect it one by one:1. The game has lots of cards, but at the end of the day there are only few card combinations a.k.a decks that could even step on the meta. Basically it is an illusion of choice, yes you can create thousands of combination from those cards but at the end of the day, you can only make around at least 8 decks that could survive the meta (at least 1 deck for each class, and just variations of that decks), other few meme decks, and endless unplayable combination that can cause your demise early before you can have that non meta combo you've been dreaming about.2. Because at the end of the day, there are only few workable decks in the meta. You'll be playing against the same several decks over and over, just with different player or luck (Ranked or Unranked, Rotation or Unlimited is often the same issue). Thus the "Repetitive" issue3. And because the game is "repetitive". Slowly you get bored playing against the same 8 decks over and over and over, then suddenly "Oh woooowww!! new cards!!! it will definitely change the meta!! aahhh!! imma plaaay!!" but then.. few weeks passed, against the same 8 decks over and over again, you became bored again.. then suddenly "oh woooo!!! mini expansioon!! this previous useless cards became so good noooww  ahh!! imma plaaay!!" but then same problem happens again, over and over. Until there is another expansion, ad infinitum. Hence the "Fluctuative" issue.4. Is both conclusion and 4th issue I has. I think the root of the problems is because the way of the dev's way of using their own statistic. First, they care more about deck's win rate rather than usage rate. Thus we might have a case like in 1st April 2020 patch where there is a nerf to a deck's card despite the deck's usage rate is 4th on the list (5% usage rate while the other nerfed deck got 30% usage rate. But they both got win rate beyond 55%, thus what basing the nerf). Second, they mostly care more about "Addition" rather than "Upgrading" a deck or class, that's why there are lots of dead decks that are irrelevant and each patch it keeps piling on. "Oh these previously dead decks has low usage rate for now? wait for next expansion kay? and buy more packs mkay?" and after said patch, yes the previously dead decks that has low usage suddenly spiked up, but it spiked up so much to the point of it became the new meta, thus stomping out the previous meta deck instead of the previous and current meta deck can compete with each other. Third, they didnt compare deck usage data (heck even deck's win rate i guess) against its own class. They often compare usage rate only against other classes, thus the problem of many deck becomes dead or created "Repetitive" issue earlier. For example, compare usage rate or win rate of artifact portal vs puppet portal vs float portal etc. or spellboost vs earthrite etc. and you can see quite clearly what deck that has overwhelming win rate or usage rate pretty quickly.The fourth, the last, and maybe a suggestion against the issues is, the addition of player satisfaction data. A simple thing like "Did you enjoyed the match? Yes/No" so you can start seeing decks that has "Balanced" win rate but judged as "not fun" or "unfair" or a "Broken" or "Dead/meme" decks but judged as "fun" or "fair". For example: Roach deck, it is (maybe) statistically "balanced" but many people complained against it, so by addition of player satisfaction data you can see this issue as a workable data.Thus you can "nerf" or "update" cards to not just to balance the meta, but to also increasing the user's overall satisfaction.And a bit of tangent on my side and a footnote(?) perhaps? I think because of these issues, that is why the game has issue of low player retention. Many player's interest piqued by the game, but they didnt manage to caught their interest long enough to make them play the game in long term. Which is a bad thing for free-to-play game because they need high player retention so many free players became long term paying player. And the data here supports it as well.The game players kept going down until there is a card release patch or mini expansion to boost it again, then going back down again, ad infinitum. Just like my criticism about its "fluctuative"ness. But maybe the reason for this phenomenon might differ if you ask other long term playersTL;DR: The game is fun for a short time, I will not suggest a continuous play else you might get bored quickly. Try not to reach Master rank too fast, else you'll get disillusioned by the meta pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ quick. Play slow, play your meme deck, rank up slowly, and you'll enjoy this game much longer and might recommend it to your friends. Not like this ReviewerThank you for reading

reviews.text: "Like Hearthstone, but better" is pretty much the simplest way to explain this to most people. The game takes a lot of the core design elements from HS to make for smooth online play. Each player has their turn, there are no interrupts, etc. Where HS leans heavily on RNG and has questionable balance between classes, though, SV goes very light on the RNG has has multiple viable decks for all classes at all levels of play. SV also trades in a lot of HS staples like Weapons, Hero Powers and Secrets for new tricks like Countdown Amulets, Necromancy, Spellboost and the biggest mechanic of all: Evolve. Evolve is a game-changing, tempo-gaining mechanic that seems simple at first but has quite a bit of depth. You start the game with a few Evo Points and starting on turn 4 or 5 you can Evolve any follower you control which typically gives it a buff (usually +2/+2) and Rush (like Charge in HS but it can only attack other followers) but special followers will have other effects when evolved. Evo Points are POWERFUL and really set SV apart from HS and it's other clones. As for the business model, it's F2P and very fair. At least on par with HS, if not better. Newbies get a lot of freebies and there are login rewards, daily missions and monthly score rewards that all feed you a steady stream of cards. There is also a crafting system much like HS's whereby you liquefy cards you don't need and use your vials to create new ones. I'm quick to knock bad F2P practices but I have nothing to complain about here. Did I mention free friendly Arena matches? There are also free friendly Arena matches.Verdict: Try It! It's free!

reviews.text: is a strategic card game that has been praised over the years, it presents itself with strong detailed art and a lot of different archetypes that players can choose to find out the one that suits their own playstyle the most. With extra modes such as take-two and balanced experience with solid online experience, it is sure to stand out from its competition in some elements.Something that is not too mentioned about  is the extra modes that can be played. The first one is  in which players must build a deck out of two different options of pair cards. This makes for a very interesting arena-like mode with lots of rewards to earn by winning in it, and a good way to explore factions or develop deck building skills. It is a lot of fun to play a section of it and it feels like a mini-tourney. There are also complete tournaments with branches and  in which players make a deck out of booster packs and get to keep the cards they obtain save for rare ones.The cards in the game can be quite expensive to craft in terms of how to acquire them. Ranging from prices of 800 up to 3000 its can be downright ruthless to craft a single copy of some cards, let alone three of them make a more structured deck. Obtaining three competitive decks took around 50 hours+a bit of money buying some packs.The mechanic that made me interested in  was the  Evolution works as a sort of comeback mechanic in which players can increase exponentially the power of their cards by spending  points during a match. It adds some thinking into its linear gameplay and is a blast witness as the arts of the card change individually per evolution, which means each card has its own evolution unique art. That is some dedication put into the game. As with free to play games, there is a catch. Otherwise it would not be free to play. In  this presents itself in the form of choosing between time or money. The game is more enjoyable when you have good cards so obtaining them becomes a priority and while you do get some free packs when starting, it is not even remotely enough to build a good deck. The player needs to choose whenever they want to invest a lot of time to get rewards or pay upfront for pre-decks or packs. It is a very good game but it demands commitment from the player one way or another.Monthly balanced patches keep the game in harmony with the meta, while there are some hiccups in some of the fixes to some cards, it does a solid job. Featuring to types of formats,  and  The first limits the cards that can be played to the last five sets while the latter allows players to build decks with any card of the game they might own.  is a perfect window for new players to be introduced to the game.There is a gacha presence in  and that is that some alternate  are locked behind huge pay-walls. They don't change anything gameplay-wise but have their own animations and tend to look better in some areas. To pull one of them, you have to get their card from their specific booster pack with a change of around 0.5% to pull them out. This makes pretty much unattainable unless you buy 100 to 400 booster packs for each, making them a gacha money aspect to the game. The aesthetic of the game is very beautiful, featuring  that are animated and have multiple skins while the card artwork has been carefully detailed. The  card are in particular just eye candy to see on display in the field, which makes them prized possessions and amazing when you pull one. The story of the game also features good artwork that helps picture the image that the characters give. Featuring detailed backgrounds with fine line-work and facial expressions is a delicacy to the eyes.The biggest weakness presented with  compared to its peers is that the game is very linear. Factions play the same routine and stick to similar decks, to the point where it feels that there is not as much room for creativity in contrast to other card games. You pick a faction and use their mechanics no matter the deck, which makes gameplay, not as tactical at times, and players online seem to use the same decks almost all the time. The story certainly is one of the things that impressed me when playing the game. It starts out as simple and linear but quickly becomes a series of developed plots in which the player chooses a character and sticks with them. Each character deals with a particular theme and narrative and some examples of these can be: dealing with conflicts between what right or wrong in a gray world.  seeking strength by pursuing powerful opponents which are perhaps a reflection of his vampire nature, a thirst he cannot satiate or  who wants to accomplish his goal of vanishing certain individuals yet doesn't know the meaning of companionship and the power of emotions.It is very complex and the character you choose will shape how you perceive events in the story, you can play all characters to your heart content but I recommend just beating each chapter with one character at first. The more you play it, the more interested and invested you become in its fantastical narrative and the worlds that are explored through it.The game runs perfectly on a GTX 1060 with no issues, it is locked to 60FPS. When first launching it, it will require to download the data thought it's own client. The story allows to skip chapters should they become too difficult for the player but won't give out the rewards, being there as an option to come back to certain specific encounters.What makes it special is that each faction plays in their own different specific ways. Some examples can be how  specializes in card draw and making their cards cheaper to play while  plays around with the comeback mechanic of evolution more closely, unlocking powerful abilities once their health is low and aiming to eliminate their opponent in a single strike. They each define what type of deck you will play and what goals you will develop during the match to secure your victory. is a game that is worth your time if you are looking for a new card game to play, it features excellent art with an interesting story and while it's gameplay is less tactical and more linear compared to fellow peer's of the same genre, simplicity can have its own set of charms. I recommend this game to those that enjoy card games and to those that would like to explore one, as it is very newbie-friendly and easy to learn. You will need to commit to the game, but the rewards are worth that commitment.

reviews.text: The game was a very solid free to play friendly CCG that was easy to get into.  I no longer believe the game is easy to get into due to dramatic increase in deck cost and greed of the publisher pushing mini expansions that only hurt free to play players.  The recent changes since the switch to a rotation and unlimited format modes have made the game significantly worse every expansion due to bad card balance, lack of nerfs and most of all an inability to balance the difference in win rate for players going first and players going second.  These are common complaints for any CCG and it would be easy to just write the rest of this review off based on it.  However, a little history is in order before your write this review off.First off Cygames, the publisher, previously had been nerfing cards every single month to attempt to balance the game. This worked out reasonably well and there was always a feeling of progress towards a balanced game.  One they often achieved towards the end of an expansion but it was never perfect.  Since the format change nerfs are far less common and when they do come they are months after the cards were generally recognized as oppressive.  An example of this being the most recent card change nerfed cards that were considered oppressive a week or less after released. However, they were not nerfed for an entire expansion and months into the next.  That alone is a bad sign but in between every month they released statistics and comments showing the deck the cards enabled had an oppressive win rate and was the most populare deck.  Instead they have tried reverting nerfs and buffing cards to affect change which has not worked well, has been very inconsistentl applied and only seem to focus on the unlimited format balance.Secondly, before the format change every single faction had a playable deck with many factions having 2-5 viable tournament or ladder decks.  Since the change many factions have not had a single viable deck at all in the Rotation format since the change at all or only for a very brief window.  The ‘meta’ of any specific expansion has gone from 10-15 or so decks that were viable to 3-7.  The terms playable and viable are quite debatable but in this context, I mean you could reasonably expect a 50%+ win rate on ladder with average luck and match ups.  The problem is that even if decks could on average achieve a 50%-win rate they would often have drastically one-sided match ups against the Tier 0/S decks that were the most popular on ladder.  It is very common to have a deck have a 48-52% win rate against 90% of match ups but a sub 40%-win rate vs. the two or three most popular and oppressive decks.  If a deck is near 50% against every other deck except the 2/3 meta decks that are 40% of the ladder it’s not viable because with average match up luck you will no longer have an average 50%-win rate.  When this is true for many decks it indicate that 2/3 factions are over tuned relative to the remaining factions and should be nerfed. but this is no longer happening regularly. Which leads us to the arguably worst problem with Shadowverse currently.  The difference in win rate between the player going first and the player going second has been heavily in favor of the player going first for almost a year.  The publisher recently mentioned that players going first had win rates of 53.2% across all deck archetypes for the rotation format with a 51.3% rate for unlimited.  They acknowledge this a problem but took no action to adjust any cards balance.  The key to focus on here though is that the ratio is imbalanced badly in aggregate at the 53.2%-win rate.  This fundamentally means that there are many matchups where the ratio is far, far more one sided.  We have never had official numbers, but many player self-reporting tracking sites have had many oppressive decks having win rates for at 60%+ for many match ups going first even if the average win rate was ‘only’ 54%.  If this deck is 20-25% of the ladder and you get unlucky going second 7+/10 games, a 17.19% change, you are not having any fun playing the game.  You are losing often simply because you went second.Finally, card games are defined by the mix of skill and random chance and that is what makes them enjoyable.  Everyone can accept losing because their opponent had the perfect god hand, or they did not draw a single playable card for 5 turns due to mana cost.  That is part of the nature of card games.  The problem Shadowverse has is far too many games result in you losing regardless of any action on your part due to simply going second or heavily one-sided match ups and the natural bad luck in card games.  This is especially seen in the pro tournament scene for the game.  Before the change to formats it was common to see the same faces in the top 10 positions in tournaments for multiple regions.  Now it’s just random faces every week with 1-2 previous names if they got lucky.  Which is the problem with Shadowverse.  Winning or losing is far more about just luck these days than skill.  It’s gone from being a competitive game to a CCG version of Mario party.  Fun to play or horrifically aggravating with nothing in between.

reviews.text: Having played this game for nearly 2 years (570 hours on Steam and estimated ~200 on android), reaching top competitive ranking in all formats and having spent quite a bit of money on the game, I can no longer recommend it to anyone that's looking a decent competitive experience.  While Cygames has always adhered to the phiolosophy of quick games and powerful enders, there is only so much one can take of auto-losing to often unpreventable cards. While they have definitely improved with the latest expansions (by providing some more counterplay options, or making previous ones more playable), they haven't really stopped printing dumb cards that put a hard limit on the length of the game.  If you are looking to play the "control" style, then look elsewhere. In addition, the vocal parts of the community scream bloody murder should anyone suggest that games should be able to last more than 10 turns. Apparently the game is not designed to accomodate anyone with an attention span beyond 5 minutes.  The best part of the game remains that you are greatly rewarded for playing it regularly. If you keep up with your dailies and events, you will likely not need to spend any money, and be able to play the meta decks for most factions, although not immediately.  Being able to play you account both on Steam and on your phone/tablet (both iOS and Android) is also great, but that is hardly an innovative feature these days.

reviews.text: Been playing this game from the beggining, been watching its degradation the whole time. I like CCGs and played quite a few of them, so it was very pleasant to get into an anime one for a change. Lots of waifu material, trying out classes and decks and so on. I'd want to say that somewhere on the way the devs took a wrong turn balance-wise, but truth is - there was never a good meta, 2-3 cancer decks always stomped anything else, classes' mechanics were underused to the point of many decks staying the same for years, also - the majority of decks are just played on-curve, without any decision making and thought process involved. And when sometimes devs took initiative, it always resulted in new disgusting forms of FotM cancer, which plagued ranked for a while, until players' activity drops and cancer finally gets nerfs. Now this isn't anything new for CCG or any other form of multiplayer competitive game, but the devs also acquired a taste for money and became insanely greedy, which is obvious when you look at it from a long run perspective. They've upped competitive decks' costs tenfold in terms of in-game card crafting currency; they've upped an amount of deliberately printed crappy legendary cards to dilute card pool; they've introduced a "mini-extortion" system - an innovative scheme of emptying players' coffers two times for the same expansion pack by adding even more high-price cards in the middle of an expansion, directly in the pool of a said expansion, so you'll never get them unless you're willing to spend much more currency; and finally - they went full on with the scheme of "pushing" some classes every expansion, so you'll spend all of your currency at a current FotM, which will become obsolete in a couple of months. And as an additional consequence of this - if you like a particular class and main it over others, prepare to be urinated on at the every expansion, when it becomes unplayable.The one thing that they've introduced to balance this bullshittery out a little are new unstable currency grinding techniques, which eat a lot of time every day and may (or may not) give you resources to keep up with insane rise in prices. That isn't even my personal salt - as a veteran player, I happen to have a significant amount of savings and a way of not becoming poor, but how new f2p players are supposed to cope - I don't even want to know.In the end, considering all of this, we have an overpriced CCG with nice artwork, primitive mechanics and dull meta with poor deck choice, which eats a lot of your time every day and offers little in terms of fun. And I almost forgot to mention - it serves as an advertisement platform for other projects of this company.

reviews.text: It was fun but my god does the balancing get to me. I played this a lot when it was new, but with the introduction of these other expansions the game has just become exasperating. When I lost before, I used to think "oh looks like I made the wrong play" or "maybe I can try this combination of cards instead" (given just normal or decent cards) and then transition that into reasonable success. It didn't sky rocket my wins, but I felt progress and that was rewarding. Now, I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't have that this or that OP card? ♥♥♥♥ you, you lose. Set up a reasonable defense or fun win condition?  Choo-choo, here comes the meta train to make it irrelevant.  This isn't to say that the game was so much better before or that there haven't been improvements.  It's gotten a lot better, but at a cost: I feel helpless. When I lose, I'm left thinking "if only I had that new card from X expansion", not "I could have played that better".Verdict: Play if you're willing to dump money everytime a new expansion comes out or go F2p and save everything for a single working deck that will last awhile.

reviews.text: I'll preface this by saying that normally I don't go out of my way to write reviews about games but the latest set of decisions by Cygames has been bad enough that I'm inclined to write one. To start with, Cygames decisions about the art, the straw that broke the camel's back for me. I started playing this game because when I tried it out I saw the evo art for some of the cards during the tutorial and actually enjoyed the fanservice. So I went and looked over what the other art in the game was like but noticed something strange in later sets, in that the fanservice was substantially less then in earlier sets. It was at that point that I found out that while art was still being taken from Rage of Bahamut, one of Cygames's other games, it was now being censored. And in more then a few cases the censorship was rather ugly like with the card Runie Resolute Diviner (examples here:  ) Aside from fanservice, crosses would also get removed sometimes in spite of being in artworks of priests who one would assume would carry such things. At no point in game was there any indication that this was being done, why it was being done or was any choice given to use the uncensored and better looking art. However up until the the update on the 27th of October, Cygames had never gone over old artworks and censored them. Now it has done so and gutted some 150+ artworks in the process. The art I joined this game for is dead and with it any remaining reason I have to stick around.The gameplay meanwhile has been on a downhill slope of extreme powercreep where a new Rotation expansion wipes out the bulk of the decks from the previous expansion before it too gets powercreeped into oblivion. As a result the cost of decks has gone up in both formats, be it the formerly cheap format that was Unlimited and in Rotation. Once expensive decks used to be the sole remit of ramp dragon with even that class having a cheap alternative deck but now even a "cheap" deck requires 2 sets of lengendaries, the most expensive rarity of cards in the game and the average deck will run many more. The closest to an attempt to reverse the trend in price increases was temp cards allowing you to make a copy of a single legendary and it comes nowhere close to succeeding. It's also substantially changed the character of the game, with gameplay from even as far back as Chronogenesis not even having a passing resemblance to how the game plays this expansion in my opinion for the worse. Old archetypes like Ramp Dragon or Midrange shadow in unlimited are dead and practically impossible to revive due to the extent of just how badly the game has been powercreeped. Transparency about balance is practically non existent, the only time the devs actually share statistics on which decks are doing well is when nerfs come out (and even then you'll only get the statistics of the decks being nerfed) otherwise you get a canned statement about no decks doing outsizedly well or having a high play percentage. This leaves the only way to attempt to gauge the meta being to keep up with tournaments as these are the only place where one can get some idea of what's good and the picture these paint is far from encouraging. This would not be so bad were it not for the fact that unlimited has for a good deal of time been functionally abandoned when it comes to balance in spite of there blatantly being decks that saw an oversized play and winrate throughout it's existence such as midrange shadow and artifact portal and warped the format around them.In game events meanwhile are lackluster and in some cases more of a source of frustration then anything else. Grand Prix, the most common in game event consists of of playing 5 matches with the same deck often in the exact same format against the exact same decks as you would in a regular game, rendering the event effectively glorified ranked just with some extra rewards. What few other grand prix formats exist are crippled by bad balance resulting in certain classes being blatantly stronger then their competitors and rendering them unplayable as a result due to the in game cost to actually play the format making it a net loss to attempt to play them while worse yet being heavily dependent upon RNG, such as in the case of the Gems of Fortune game mode wherein the cards one has to work with from game to game are entirely different but the mechanics by which one gets said cards blatantly favors certain classes.Bluntly I would not recommend this game unless you are willing to tolerate being given deliberately worse versions of art that Cygames can and will decide to make even worse later down the line while also having gameplay that is both extremely repetitive and progressively getting both more expensive and less enjoyable.

reviews.text: I'm going to compare Shadowverse directly to Hearthstone since that's probably where most of the interested players are coming from. Warning: This is pretty longThings SV does better:1. MUCH more variety than Shamanstone. We all know that Hearthstone is at an extremely low point right now- that's why competitors like TESL, GWENT, and SV are doing so well. All the classes in SV play differently and they all require different tactics to beat. Yeah, there's still the generic Zerg and Ramp class, but SV focuses a lot more on control and combo decks; Going aggro against Urias will get you slaughtered as he's able to push out stronger minions at lower health. But at the same time, going full on control against Isabelle may not go so well since she gets stronger the more spells she casts. You'll have to find a nice medium to do well.Something I really like is how you'll sometimes have to do something for the first part of the game, and then adopt a completely different strategy late game since that's when certain decks are at their strongest. I'm a particular fan of Luna's playstyle where certain cards grant her a secondary resource (shadow) that'll be immediately spent if you play certain other cards. The fact that it's immediate is nice since it makes you plan multiple turns ahead: yeah, you could drop a minion on an empty board this turn, but you'll automatically burn through the shadows needed to perform combos later on. In which case, the best decision is to pass the turn- something that is VERY rarely optimal in Hearthstone2. You don't have to play on curve every turn. Since your cards can have different effects based on which turn you play them on (like in my last example with Luna for example) as well as the order you play them on your turn, always playing on curve is not a smart decision. Curvestone players have the lesson of always needing to play on curve beaten into us; if you're stuck between two options in Curvestone, the best choice is almost always to just match the number of mana you have to the numer on the top left corner of the card. This Curvestone playstyle removes a lot of the thinking behind the game, which turns into a match of who can play more minions. A thinking card game like SV is a refreshing breath of air. 3.  waifus4. The animation is gorgeous. Some cards in SV are animated, which is basically the Hearthstone equilivant of golden cards. Most of the golden animations in Hearthstone are pretty meh, with the exception being the dragons and a couple of legendaries. But every animated card I've seen in SV has been absolutely beautiful: the colors all pop out and the transition from background to foreground is done seemlessly. 5. The story isn't exactly deep, but I was surprised by how much I found myself caring for the characters. Everyone has their own personality, hopes, and fears and if you dig past the bright colors and chirpy emotes and sound effects, it's actually pretty dark. A little girl having delusions of her dead parents and copes with their deaths by trying to kill everyone she meets? A man accidentally kills his friend and puts himself through self exile to protect his loved ones? A women tries in vain to resurrect her dead fiance after he's murdered by their mutual friend? The addition of a minion henchmen who reveal people's darkest fears and another who tempts the characters by promising them their heart's desires adds a surprising amount of depth to the characters of a free anime-esque card game 6.  Evolution lets you regain tempo really rapidly if you're starting to fall behind. You can smack a single opponent minion for massive amounts of damage in one turn, which in turn forces you to plan your moves ahead of time7. The BM is actually hilliarious in SV. If you play AI, they'll sometimes sarcastically emote how they'll ever deal with your minions, before dropping a board wipe. Or they'll emote a BM right before smacking your face for lethal. It's actually pretty funny and the way that automute works in SV is also better than HS. In Saltstone, you're muted for a certain amount of time depending on how often you're emoting. Whereas in Shadowverse, you're only limited to the number of emotes per turn. 8. Smaller board size. You can only have a total of 5 cards on the board and this includes minions, artifacts (like from TESL and MTG. Hearthstone doesn't have it), and effects that are only activated after a certain number of turns out in play (think something like a reverse overload: you pay X mana now and Y turns later, Z happens). This means you to spend more time deciding which cards to play to optimize your board.9. ARENA MODE IS FREEEE!! Kind of. Things HS does better than SV:1. Better menu UI. It's obvious where everything in HS is and how to access them. It took me 5 whole minutes just to learn how to open my cardpacks. 2. HS doesn't censor your decknames. Why is this a thing in SV?? How am I going to offend someone with my deckname that no one else can even see???Conclusion: If you're sick of Hearthstone, it's worth checking Shadowverse out. The story is surprisingly good, it's more control oriented, actually requires thinking, and most importantly, it's free! If you're not a fan of SV's artstyle (perfectly understandable), I suggest checking out TESL.

reviews.text: TL;DR: Shadowverse is an impressive game, and probably the best candidate so far to be in actual competition with Hearthstone. It has interesting mechanics and is reasonably polished. The story mode is cool, even though it's unfinished. I have no idea about the "meta" but that's something that will change over time anyway. Overall, recommend any fan of CCGs to give it a shot.Unlike all of the other Hearthstone-inspired games coming out, this game actually has an interesting setting. The characters are cool, and the cards are cool. This may not be important to everyone, but it's definitely important to some people, and it's important to me. I can't stand the thought of playing a game like Elder Scrolls Legends with its super generic western RPG setting with the same stuff we've seen thousands of times. This is the main reason I gave this game a shot in the first place.The game borrows heavily from Hearthstone, which is fine. Instead of Hero Powers to balance out RNG, we have Evolve, which is a much more powerful mechanic, although I find it a little boring. Amulets (basically like Enchantments from MTG) are a welcome addition, and the ones that count down by 1 each turn are cool. However, I find being limited to 5 minions on the board to be a little too restricting. I have a feeling this was a decision made in consideration of mobile, but it can't really be changed at this point without significantly changing the balance of the game. What I do like about it is that it allows for some more powerful effects, like "Fanfare: Give +1/+1 to all followers." without potentially snowballing if you have a huge board.The artwork is quite good, and HiDPI compatible. The boards are cool, but they make the actual game very difficult to look at. There needs to be much more contrast between what is in play and the background. This is probably my #1 complaint about the game. The visual design of the Hearthstone interface is much more suited for the type of game this is.Please add an option to switch between Japanese and English voice acting. I'm sure the English cast is talented, but it just never sounds natural for people to read these scripts translated from Japanese. Speaking of which, I used the unofficial method to change to the Japanese audio, and I gotta say, the translation is pretty weird in some places. The text doesn't match what is being said at all, and the changes don't seem to make sense. It's not stuff people wouldn't understand or anything like that.This game is  a direct port of the mobile version. I think significant work should be put into making it better for PC users. I imagine they are just trying to see what the size of their audience on PC will be before committing too many resources. I hope that's true. Here are some of the issues I have:I think this game is quite entertaining and has potential. It has some unique mechanics and hero ideas that differentiate it from a sea of Hearthstone clones. reviews.text: This is a very solid digital card game; if you’re new to the CCG world and Hearthstone’s Warcraft theme doesn’t interest you too much, Shadowverse is a great alternative. It’s addictive and fast-paced, it has nice art, and it’s pretty easy to get a lot of free packs. If you’re a Hearthstone veteran, this is definitely a Hearthstone clone to the core. The presentation, the card crafting system, the game mechanics (Battle Cry is now called Fanfare, Taunt is called Ward, etc.), the mission log, the card rarity tiers, and so on are all 99% the same. Heck, it even has an Arena mode. I think it’s still worth playing even if you’ve played Hearthstone, though; it has just enough unique stuff going on that it’s different in interesting ways. I’ll write a bit here about how Shadowverse is different from Hearthstone, so that you can differentiate between them and see what you think.- Shadowverse does have a few mechanics that you won't find in Hearthstone. One of the game's unique mechanics is the ability to “Evolve” your units. After a few opening turns, you'll get a small number of Evolve points that you can use on any of your units in the field – when a unit Evolves, it gets a stat boost, it sometimes gains an additional power or triggered ability, and it gets to attack on the same turn that it entered the field (a.k.a. Haste or Charge). This adds a nice extra level of strategy to the battle, because you have to consider whether or not your opponent is going to pop his or her Evolve and ruin your plans.  Every unit even has alternate Evolved art, which is a nice touch.- I was never super-attached to the Warcraft universe (though I loved Warcraft 2 back in the day), so I prefer the anime art and setting of Shadowverse over Heathstone. Shadowverse's art is really good – some of it is too “~~kyaaaaaa~~” for my taste but for the most part it looks great. The best art in the game is reserved for the character portraits of the major character classes (I especially like Erika, the Swordcraft hero) and the legendary cards. There are quite a few animations in the game as well. When you use the Evolve power, your character will leap out of his or her emblem and do an animated flourish that looks awesome. The English voice acting is a bit cheesy at times, but it's not that bad...honestly, the English voices are actually quite solid. If you can use Japanese voice mode, though, that's much better.- It’s quite easy to get free packs. When you start the game for the first time, you’ll get about 40 free packs from both the standard card pool and the latest expansion. I got a few nice legendaries, and I was quickly able to craft a couple more. While playing Hearthstone, I felt that the path to getting packs was a bit of a slog...Shadowverse is much more friendly about giving you packs and making legendaries that much more accessible.- One of the biggest and most welcome differences from Hearthstone is that Shadowverse has a story mode! The story stuff here isn't going to set the world on fire, but it's a really nice supplement to the multiplayer game. If you like card games with a single player mode or you just want to get in some AI practice with a bit more context to it, this is going to be right up your alley. Every class gets its own story, and playing through the story nets you a few story mode-exclusive cards. Some of these story mode cards are really great and can form the foundation of a good deck, so make sure that you take the time to play through every story.- Hearthstone is definitely more polished all around. It has that Blizzard sharpness to it that most other studios just can't fake, and Shadowverse is no different. Shadowverse started life as a a mobile game and it shows. The interface is a little clunky and awkward. This isn't a huge deal and Shadowverse is very playable...it's just not as user-friendly and easy to navigate as its high profile competition.- While Shadowverse might not have Hearthstone's polish, the online matchmaking here is actually *excellent*. It's really easy to find a game, and I never encountered any lag. It seems like the community for this game is pretty big and growing larger, which is great. My only complaint is that a surprising numbher of people would rather concede than play out a match and see what happens. It's like, come on...you've still got 10 health and 5 cards in your hand. See what happens!

So while I'm going to uninstall it after saving this revised review, I still think it's worth a try for those who like CCGs. It's free, after all, and they are pretty generous with the cards, even though you'll never get enough free cards to be competitive.

reviews.text: - Cons and Pros last paragraph Super important note: If you think you like the game and can see yourself playing it for the long run, I recommend rerolling to optimize your experience as a beginner. First, download the mobile version and keep rerolling. With each reroll, open your new account's packs and share it on the games' official discord for opinions on your legendary cards and if they are worth keeping, or should just reroll for another chance. Note that rerolling is not possible on steam unlesss you're planning on creating a steam account for each reroll.Pretty awesome game. it looks bland and generic at first, but it gets better the more you understand it and the more you dive deep into it's mechanics and gameplay. You find yourself getting attached to some cards, for example. there's a story that is funnily boring at first. but it gets intense in many parts and keeps you engaged with it's characters, plot and twists. VN players will enjoy this free experience I'm sure.The devs throw so many packs for new players 50+ just for creating an account, and more packs just for doing story and beginner quests. after finishing them all, ( would take two to three days maximum depending on your speed) you'll eventually open around 100+ packs. the game isn't p2w at all, and doesn't require a penny if you play it consistently, just like any other CCG tbh.PVP will teach you the game slowly and how many cards works and what not. You get Ranked rewards for winning. Meta decks will require some work to be able to craft them. You get a lot of Vials ( to craft cards ) that you can work with and grind for to be able to craft Meta cards. Or simply open a pack and pray for a certain card you're looking for. Meta state of the game gets boring sometimes, normally repetitive depending on the format you're playing in. Rotation: players can play with the last 5 expansions released, Or Unlimited: players play all the expansions available in the game.Pros:- many classes of leaders to choose from, each with their own playstyle and unique cards.- Tons of rewards that keeps coming for new/old players- with each new expansion, players get 10 packs for free, and 5 more packs 2 months after the release of a new expansion, Grandmasters get another 10 packs.- you're most likely able to create a Meta deck right from the beginning to be able to grind and start your journey with a strong deck. (Depends on your luck) Cons:- Like any CCG game, if you take a month or two or freaking three months break without playing, the game punishes you hard, because powercreep exist. most old cards (not all) will be dominated by new cards. leaving you with an old deck that's not worth much And can't win you games anymore. Also, daily quests\logins are going to be your only source of pack openings, missing them isn't fun at all.- The Meta can get very repetitive at times, it's gotten a little better now, but still, repetitiveness is awkwardly there, not as boring as before that's for sure. and it's extremely repetitive when playing the Rotation format since people are forced to build decks from the last 5 expansions only.The game is worth checking out, but certainly not for everyone, and despite it's flaws it still is a fun game.

reviews.text: I've played Yugioh competetively, Magic the Gathering casually, and a little bit of Cardfight Vanguard just for fun, for many years now; so shadowverse claiming to be the #1 online CCG in japan caught my interest quite awhile ago. A Fate collaboration event finally got me to install and try it. At first glance, Shadowverse is a beautiful card game with great voice acting and fantastic card/character art for even the most basic cards. The option to craft cards is a great addition too (though with a pretty inflated price) so if rng keeps screwing you over with card packs you can eventually get the card you want. However, despite having a tutorial explain each faction's playstyle and a very generous free 50 card packs for completing said tutorial, Shadowverse is not newbie friendly. Any new player will get utterally wrecked in online play, and there seems to be no type of matchmaking or trueskill algorithm to make pairing more fair. This makes completing missions (which are mostly, win x times with this faction) difficult to complete making it harder to get more card packs without spending real money. I went ahead and spent quite a bit of money to get some prebuilt decks to help aleviate this thinking I would be playing this game for quite awhile, and it didn't help much; I really regret my purchases. I found out soon after why; there is very little balance to this game. Each faction has several cards that have insanely op effects that pretty much win you the game. Example would be an amulet that summons other amulets that declare you the winner in 3 turns unless you banish the amulet (theres very few amulet banishing cards and they usually cost a fair amount to cast, destroying the amulet just grants the effect anyway), or a unit that spellboosts YOUR ENTIRE DECK 9 TIMES, which means your opponent can cast high cost spellboost cards for 1 to 0 orbs or do high effect damage for little cost. If your opponent gets these cards on the field your pretty much done. There are no hand traps, no opponent turn player activatble effects, no graveyard effects, there is no way to stop these cards. Even some of the normal cards would be considered op in other games, such as one that transforms all your followers on the field into flaming rats, or just straight up destroys your entire field. Really? All of them? Did Bob Ross come back and give you that idea? Turn all your problems into flaming rats? It's not even all that expensive to cast either. Normally I wouldn't have a problem with these kinds of cards, there are other crazy op cards in other card games as well. But the fact that there is no way to stop these effects like in other card games is what breaks the game for me. It basically boils down to, survive long enough to draw your win condition card, and thats it. There is very little alternate strategy, and because of that I honestly can't recommend this game. Even if you find yourself liking the game anyway, dont spend any real money. It's not worth it. The only reason why I'm still playing this game is because I'd be wasting my money otherwise.

reviews.text: When playing this game I can't help but comparing it to Blizzard's popular card game, Hearthstone.The basic is the same, it's a card game on its core. But let's break it down by categories to get a better judgement.Hearthstone and Shadowverse apply the same concepts, mana/energy points to dictate the game, dropping minions and utilizing spells to win the match. The difference however, in Hearthstone you have hero powers, and the latter has another layer to influence the nature of the board - card evolution. I really can't pick which one is better, as either mechanics seem suitable for respective games. I personally think it's unique to each game and we ought to respect that. At the end of the day, it's a matter of preference.Being CCG, there's basic way to collect cards. It's all the same on both games, disenchanting/liquefying will earn you materials (dust/vial) while crafting/creating will deplete your mats and earn your card. You can earn more by opening card packs.Blizzard win when it comes to character selections, however. It comes with nine heroes with its each unique traits, as opposed to Shadowverse's seven heroes.Conclusion: Hearthstone wins ever so slightly.Frankly, Blizzard's multi million dollars resources really shine here. The graphic, voice actors, the story telling, background music really show their worth. The graphic is crisp, rendered by Unity engine, arena is beautifully designed, each detail is drawn meticulously. Graphic options are limited, though only fullscreen/windowed and quality. But eh, I can run it 60 FPS flat, so yeah.Shadowverse is also voiced and have more animations, but many of them are cringe worthy for being too cliche (for me anyway). Well, you know, anime style, although I like anime like Steins;Gate, CLANNAD, Gundam, Naruto I still can't swallow it. Graphic also has less depth and the arena is bland, not even eye catching. It does run on 60 fps for my machine, but has less quality as a whole.Conclusion: Hearthstone wins.In this part, Blizzard win hands down no contest. Shadowverse has too many quirks, even navigating my card collection requires me to wait for 2-3 secs just to flip the page. In HS, this issue does not exist, loading is only when you open the menu, the rest is smoothly navigated once the initial loading is done. I reckon the infrastructure is simply superior, since HS has many servers and definitely better network support.Conclusion: Hearthstone wins.Both games include single player and multi player. In Hearthstone it's called Adventure and Tavern Inn to practice. Adventure can be purchased with gold, but you'll gouge your eyes out trying to purchase the wings with gold only. Sometimes Blizzard hand out part of the package for free, but you'll be hard pressed to appreciate it - since even in my eyes it's no more than marketing tactics to entice people to buy whole wings. As for Shadowverse, SP mode comes for free, with all heroes have their own background stories. And yes, it has AI mode. More details below.Conclusion: Shadowverse wins.As free players, disregarding environment and meta, you'll appreciate that Shadowverse hands out freebies more often than Blizzard. Just completing tutorials will earn you plentiful of packs, and from what I have seen, they also handed out more freebies be it through events or special occasions. Blizzard? Very stingy. They do give freebies, but very limited. Gotta do with basic decks, folks!Conclusion: Shadowverse wins hands down.Big question, is SV gonna die soon?Nah, I don't think so. It's not as massive as Hearthstone, but it's because (probably):1. Anime-ish. God forbids anything related to anime to be massively popular.2. The developer doesn't have Blizzard's resources to promote their game e.g making this e-sports or cross advertising on 5 million subscribers MMORPG aka World of Warcraft. This leads to 3.3. Lesser technical quality than Hearthstone....but I think it's going to stay for foreseeable future. Hearthstone, though, still wins by landslide. We all know how vigilant Blizzard are when maintaining their games. See Warcraft 3 and Diablo 2 which is still updated after decade.Conclusion: Hearthstone wins by miles ahead.How this game could be improved? Adding achievements and trading cards would be easy and nice addition, but  is critical while adding contents should be done on regular basis. Blizzard have proven their track records by adding multiple expansion packs, while this Cyagames still need to face the test of time. We'll see.And it's fun just by opening those card packs. Believe me, it has some digital drugs attached to opening card pack mechanic. :))

reviews.text: (originally from josealdos but it summarizes perfectly my view on the game and the state it is in)A big part of the issue with this game is that every deck in this game is turning into a variation of "combo." It's essentially combo decks fighting other combo decks so you don't get the self-balancing "rock paper scissors" aspect you see in other games (aggro, control, combo, midrange, etc). In this game, the line between deck types/archetypes has effectively been blurred. Control (in a pure sense: controlling the board, running your opponent out of resources, stuff like that) doesn't exist in this game like it does in others because there just aren't good control tools in this game.Shadowverse has always been a quick game with powerful finishers. As time went on, this aspect of the game got worse and worse. Basically Sword was one of the few remaining "pure/respectable" classes that didn't really have a "combo." That's now gone. Strong effects/evolves also have very little tempo loss.This makes me just not want to play the game anymore at all. Unlimited is awful and even worse than Rotation. The game is interactive in the sense that you are racing for your win condition. There is very little interactivity in the sense of you doing something against your opponent. It's more like solitaire. Your draws and accelerating your win condition are the only things that matter.This is why I'm waiting until the 5th anniversary. If they don't do anything major for a large anniversary like this, then I'm gone. The amount of things to do and gamemodes in this game is just laughable compared to like hearthstone & legends of runeterra.edit: This affects the singleplayer content to a lesser degree and the solo campaigns are pretty well done, so if you are a pure solo player the game might be recommended.Also the matchmaking in PvP is bottom of the barrel and seems to only randomly connect people instead of actually searching for a decent match (not skill-based).

reviews.text: I've been playing this game for a while. It used to be good, but the last couple of expansions have been slowly killing it. Top-tier decks have been getting more and more expensive, often requiring multiple legendaries, and by the time you scrounge together enough vials to make the deck you want, another expansion has already been released and you're back at square one. For the Dawnbreak expansion, Cygames has split the expansion into two pieces, which in my opinion is a pretty transparent money-grab so that people have to spend more per expansion to get the second batch of cards that get released, regardless of what people say to justify it. Assuming this is the new normal, that means that every two months, you will have to collect more new cards to keep afloat with the Rotation meta. Not even the extremely expensive MTG is quite that cruel to its playerbase.The game used to be pretty good about not being a scummy mobile gacha game, but they've completely abandoned that premise lately. Emblems, sleeves, and alternate leaders are locked behind ridiculous paywalls and exclusive events. Normally, I wouldn't care, but these kinds of business practices just leave a bad taste in my mouth. Instead of working on game balance and QOL changes, they seem to only worry about coming up with creative ways of separating people from their money. They could easily put all this stuff in a store and just let the whales finance their operation like every other "F2P" game, but there's something particularly sinister about preying on people's gambling habits.As for the games themselves, a lot of games are decided by your starting hand and whether you go first or second, more so now than ever before, and the devs seem uninterested in changing this. Playing aggro and going second? You lose. Playing a combo mirror and you go first? You win. Because of how almost every win-condition in this game is designed to be huge burst damage or an OTK, going first means you get to play your win condition before your opponent, which means you always want to go first.Take Two has become a slot machine of picking the best classes and hoping to get the auto-win cards that will breeze you to 5 wins. Gone are the days when you could draft an interesting deck with a class of your choice and have some fun games. The rewards for Take Two only give you a profit if you go 5-0, so playing Take Two indefinitely is practically impossible without sinking money into the game or farming quests.And Unlimited...Most of my cards are from the first couple of expansions, so I tend to play more Unlimited than Rotation, but the format has become pretty much unbearable. Cards like Roach, D-Shift, Daria, and Ceridwen are warping the format to unplayability. Even though almost the entire playerbase has been complaining about these cards for years, Cygames is intent on letting the power level of these cards remain unchanged to plague the format for however long we have to suffer through them. Cygames even had the bright idea of hosting an Unlimited tournament, which was just a torturous gauntlet of Daria decks. Seriously, on the last day of the tournament, I played against six Daria decks in a row.A lot of the things I used to enjoy about this game (the minimal RNG, the generous F2P nature, the variety of decks and playstyles) have basically disappeared at this point. I'm getting the impression that Cygames is losing control of their game, and doesn't quite know what to do to turn it around.I put a fair amount of money into the game when I first started, and felt like the initial investment was worth it. You didn't need to sink hundreds of dollars into the game to be competitive. But as of right now, the money you would put into this game has diminishing returns. I would either go completely F2P, or limit yourself to a very small amount per month (around $5-$10 per month). The expansions come out way too fast in Rotation for you to keep up, and Unlimited has become far too stagnant for your old collection to be worth building up (unless you really enjoy playing Daria or Roach Forest, for some ungodly reason).Another freemium game with potential bites the dust, I guess.

reviews.text: EDIT:Well, it's been quite a while since I posted this review, and to their credit, the developers have made some solid steps in the right direction.  Not the least of which that they finally (FINALLY) broke down and started nerfing problem legendaries, which many of us feared was against some internal, unwritten policy.The last expansion was pretty decent, aside from the wildly overtuned Prime Dragon Keeper, which has since been brought into line.  Without killing the card completely.   Which is another thing I do like: when they nerf, it's clear they at least INTEND to try and keep the card playable but fair, even if they don't always hit the mark.  Compare to Warsong Commander's 'soul of the card' nerf in Hearthstone.  Brutal.So yeah:Pros:-WAY more generous than its other main competition.  Dozens of free packs just for sighning up!-Cute Waifus.-Overall superior class identity and interesting mechanics.-Real attempt to support unplayable but interesting cards, and seen in the rise of Atomeme.-Willingness to admit mistakes and address them without overnerfing.Cons:-Heavy push for games to end fast, often resulting in lopsided, aggro vs aggro metas.-Every expansion seems to pretty much break the game at this point, and only a month later on their scheduled balance pass does it get better again.-Kinda sleazy practices with the slot-machine class skins . . . though they are only cosmetic, I guess.-Basically almost everything conceptually wrong with Hearthstone, though to a lesser degree.I still play the game from time to time, but you really gotta make that call for yourself.  For all its faults, it's still way better than Hearthstone.  And that's something.ORIGINAL REVIEW:One of the most shocking and saddening turnarounds I've ever seen in an online game.  How could it go so wrong, so fast?A couple of expansions ago, I left Hearthstone for good in favor of Shadowverse, and at that time my opinion of this game was extremely high.  Now, it's only marginally better than Hearthstone was at its worst, and that's saying something.Horrifically broken legendary win-conditions (in only a few classes, of course, to ensure nearly no diversity) have essentially power-creeped the evolution mechanic itself into irrelevancy, giving whoever goes first a massive advantage.  Games are far too close to coin flips at this point, where if the player going first has a good hand, they are nearly unbeatable.I will continue to look in on this game, as the developers have promised frequent balance passes (unlike a certain other popular card game), and if these issues are fixed, I'll be certain to change this review to a recommendation, since the base game WAS excellent in my opinion.  And could still be again.But as things stand now?  Stay away.  If you're really intrigued by the oodles of freebies and cute waifus, maybe make an account and gather daily login rewards on the chance that they fix this mess, but actually playing the game at this point is just too frustrating.But that's just, like, my opinion, man.

reviews.text: Sick of Heathstone with its ever-increasing barrier of entry and difficulty of keeping up with the meta? Spending hundreds/thousands of dollars on a game, only to be rewarded with higher pack prices, and a forced meta they decide with every expansion? Or maybe you just aren’t a fan of the RNG “clown fiesta” that most matches become. To be fair, I used to love the game. Blizzard took a lot of elements I liked about Magic: The Gathering and did away with some things I disliked, and made a really great game. I’ve played off and on for months at a time since open beta, and have had some of the most fun I’ve had in a game while playing it. With all of the money I’ve invested in it, I’ve been pretty bummed out by recent design decisions along with some of their commercial shifts. So much so that I uninstalled the app from my phone and haven’t logged in on desktop for quite some time.Enter Shadowverse. Before I offer my opinions on the game, I should also say that I also played a lot of Rage of Bahamut on my phone (the order I was in was ranked #5 in the world competitively). To be quite honest, it wasn’t that great of a game mechanically, but I was hooked – mainly on the social aspect and the artwork. I stopped playing a bit before they shut down their servers in North America, but I was pretty sad to see it go. So along comes this offering from Cygames. I was surprised to see they had repurposed (and preserved) a lot of the art from RoB. As a huge fan of it (I’m still an anime nerd, after all), I was immediately intrigued. I soon discovered the game plays a lot like Hearthstone but also has some really interesting design choices. Things like being able to evolve followers (minions, creatures etc.) at certain points in the match, making them much stronger and in some cases activating certain abilities. It has a lot of mechanics that you’d expect in a game like this (ambush = stealth, storm = charge, fanfare = battlecry, last words = deathrattle and so on). There are class-specific cards that can only be played with that leader (hero, basically) and a pool of neutral cards that can be used in any deck. The cards you get can be liquefied (dusted) for vials that you use to create the cards you want, with the rarity determining their respective worth. The meta on the ladder is pretty healthy at the moment, and there are a myriad of ways to build decks within their respective archetypes. The classes all have distinct mechanics akin to Hero Powers that differentiate them from one another, making their identities really stand out. They also have a pretty engaging solo story mode for each class you can play, allowing you to earn rewards while learning how the play the class. This makes it a unique digital CCG while remaining intuitively familiar.Where it really shines though is its F2P system. While not as generous as say, Eternal, you are handsomely rewarded for your playtime and efforts. You get a ton of free packs as a new player (10 from each expansion, if I'm not mistaken), and a lot of tickets for packs and gold to buy them with as you play the various solo and multiplayer game modes. I don’t play a lot of Take Two, the Shadowverse equivalent of Hearthstone’s Arena, but its reward system is also nice. You’re provided 4 cards in a 2 pairs at a time, and you a pick a pair of them until the deck is complete. As with Hearthstone, these aren’t yours to keep, however (unlike Eternal’s drafting system). You then play a 5 match game – 5 matches total, win or lose, and are rewarded at the very least a ticket for a free card pack. You can play this mode by entering with tickets or gold you earn throughout the game. If you’re any good at it, it may be more profitable than outright buying packs themselves (I personally don’t play it that much is I have a hard time evaluating the best choices to make.). With all of that said, they are a business after all, and developers need to get paid, so pretty much all of this can be bought with crystals, an in-game currency you can buy with cash. I’ve spent a bit on it, but its reasonably priced, and considering the fun I’ve had and the amount of time I’ve been playing, I figure it’s worth it.I didn’t touch on the ladder ranking system (it’s pretty grindy, but the rewards are worth it), the rest of the MTX available for purchase, or some of the other features in the game because those are worth checking out on your own. If you’re over Hearthstone – or even if you completely love it (or perhaps you have never played it all, but enjoy CCGs like MTG, Hex, Eternal etc.) this game is definitely one you should consider trying out.

reviews.text: I've played since the very beginning and have many many more hours from mobile, and as much as I'd love to recommend this game...they manage to continually destroy every fun and interactive aspect of it over and over. Just when you think the meta is settling and the cards are balanced, some form of gamebreaking nonsense that no one enjoys gets (re)introduced. Do you like getting hit in the face for limitless frequently unblockable damage? Do you like losing turn 1 because the enemy had a 1 drop and you didn't? Do you like losing mirror matches every time you go second? Do you like not being able to predict your enemy because their cards have a high chance of costing 0 depending on highroll? Shadowverse may be for you! Seriously it may sound like salt but every single game is a coin flip (that's as long as you're using one of the 1-2 meta approved broken decks...otherwise you'll never win). When people say there's strategy and planning involved in shadowverse it makes me laugh...those players just don't understand they have consistently good luck. The most strategic thing about Shadowverse is the mulligan phase...and even that is obviously left up to chance. As long as you draw your OP legendary before they draw their OP legendary, congratulations, you've won! While yes this is a card game and is inherently luck based, please take my word in that Shadowverse leaves the player with a particular feeling of helplessness and the decks all basically autopilot themselves at this point in time.Strategy and planning in this game died long ago...you will get steam rolled every time you decide not to partake in the particular archetype that Cygames has decided to ram down the community's throat. Right now that's ramp dragon with a hint of mysterian ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sprinkled on top...but don't worry...maybe the class you like will get it's abhorrently broken time in the spotlight. If you're anything like me though, you won't even want to touch it anymore upon seeing what an OP cluster♥♥♥♥ they made it into.

reviews.text: Don't let my hours on record fool you as I've spent more time on the mobile version. This is a Hearthstone clone that pretty much surpasses Hearthstone in most aspects provided you don't mind the anime asthetic. It has something for everyone. There's a fair payment model which allows those who pay money to advance faster while also giving you plenty of ways to earn card packs for free without it feeling like a complete grind. There are some interesting mechanics that can really add to the experience like evolving monsters which boosts their stats and sometimes activates secondary effects. In my experience, there is much better game balancing than most of the competing online CCGs, Hearthstone included. The game also has a single player story mode where you play through the perspective of different characters whilst simultaenously allowing you to earn more cards to use in the multiplayer modes. It won't win any awards for the writing but it does keep you engaged and is suprisingly deep for what was originally a free to play mobile game. ¨Bottom line, if you're looking for a deep CCG or just a fun way to kill time, you have nothing to lose by checking this game out.

reviews.text: I've played this game for over a year and I'm a master rank player forestcraft main though I've played all the crafts a fair bit; I'll break this review into 3 sections: gameplay, how does it as a f2p game, and overall.On gameplay: I think shadowverse provides an unique and solid experience as a CCG with enough twists and variations to seperate it from others similar games:Pros: -The Evolve system adds a lot of depth to the game despite being very simple at 1st glance, imo.  -Most of the crafts have a few different varieties of playstyles in any given expansion which I feel allows the game allows the game to have fairly diverse and interesting meta game choices about what to play. -The devs have been pretty good at nerfing decks that become too good without nerfing them into the ground generally speaking and avoid kneejerk reaction nerfs typically and have gotten better about tuning of cards released in new expansions. -Story does a decent job at teaching you the basics of the game early on and offers some interesting challenges later into it.  -Rotation literally saved the game in my view since the meta felt was going down iffy path without it. -Rotation has so far keeps healthy variety in balance between aggro, combo, and control decks. -Can not lose letter rank ups to make ranked not overly punishing in super frequent promotion/demotions; though you can be demoted from number rank ups be warned. Cons: -Unlimited at this point in my book sucks since it's pretty much aggro, roach, & DShift everywhere with control decks almost not existing in it; I'd avoid it if you want to have fun imo. -1st/2nd turn can feel really worse than the other at times due to meta shifts (ie if aggro or combo is OP then turn 1 tends to feel OP or if control is OP then turn 2 tend to feel OP) -Not all decks are accessible to beginners to play or build due to complicated win conditions or cost of vials needed for the deck. -Ranked is all completely blinded best of ones which is pretty different from tournament formats for better or worse. -In take 2 some crafts tend naturally really good (looking at you sword) or really bad (looking at you rune) in the format which hurts the variety of the mode a bit, imo.  -Sometimes your favorite craft will just really struggle with a particular meta which can feel bad (though you can always play something else).On F2P: I think this game is probably one of the best done f2p games in terms of balancing what you can acquire and rate you can acquire things as a free players because of rewards systems:Pros: -3 Daily quests means ussually 1 pack per day at least if you do them all 3 as pvp ones. -Good amount of rupies given for 1st time clearing vs elite AIs. -Monthly reset on ranked rewards which don't depend on your rank reached, but rather how much you've won overall.  -Vial sysem is fairly generous I feel allows for reasonable crafting of cards you fail to pull from packs. -Free 10 packs given every expansion typically.   -Take 2 can reward packs if you do well  -Some good one time rewards from missions -Offers some alternative leaders for low cost or free -Possible to make viable budget decks for most classes -Rotation is great since reduces number of cards to worry about. -Any nerfed cards recieve full vial value temporary to compensate players.Cons: -Story rewards are pretty minimal of the most part -Some of the dailes can be rather long to complete and you can only reroll 1 daily of 3. -Getting the alternative leaders from packs is super RNG, and I'd say cost on avg 8~10k rupies per leader which is quite a lot for a free to play player, but they are just cosmetic.  -Getting the item to force animate a card of your choice is really costly for a free player. -Legendary rates are bad in general  -Some decks depend on a lot of legendaries -Unlimited can be scary for new players due to costs and range of expansions needed for decks. Overall if you'll looking for CCG with a japanese art style, that's more generous to f2p than other CCGs, or some depth and variety with a reasonable PVP ladder I'd highly recommend given the game a shot.
