reviews.text: I have played this game since steam release and have about 1700 hours on steam.I am Grandmaster rank which is the highest possible in this game.While the game might seem pretty in terms of graphics with fairly simple and intuitive gameplay, especially if you are familiar with Hearthstone, I would not recommend this game unless you are very enthusiastic to play card games with anime artstyle.I will list the good and bad points of the game trying to keep this a short as possible.+ Fantastic anime style artwork + Game mechanics have potential for fun gameplay+ Unique playstyles for 8 available hero classes+ Variety of cosmetics and hero skins + Lots of free packs, arena tickets, various promotions+ Game is considered to be less RNG than Hearthstone+ New card sets released every 3 months+ Monthly balance checks and nerfs if needed+ Large prize pool of money in tournaments+ 2 different formats for constructed mode: "Rotation" ( available cards for the format are from basic set and 5 recent expansions/sets) and "Unlimited" (cards from all sets available for use) and arena format-Game became a lot less f2p friendly since release.It is no longer possible for f2p players to get full collection and it became hard to keep up with the meta ever since developers added mini-expansions to the sets - additional cards are added for every set after 1-2 months since release which is a blatant shameless cash grab as the mini-set includes golds and legendaries - the most rare and expensive to craft cards. As a casual player you will not be able to keep up with the sets.-Game can be extremely frustrating. This applies to most card games but this game is special in a certain way.Developers of this game Cygames are known to mess with various algorithms of their games such as changing percentages for getting certain pulls from packs (in one of their other games) which was scandalous enough to pass a new law in Japan, and possibly adjusting winrates for this game to make statistics look good. In this game the win/loss rates of the matches are weird at times  - one day you can get huge win streaks and the other day it will be impossible to win with the same deck which is mathematically improbable to say the least especially since this happens on constant basis. Do not bother taking this game seriously and do not pick it up if you have anxiety or do not want to get frustrated and angered on daily basis.- Unlimited format is a mess. Some decks in the game and expecially in "Unlimited" are poorly balanced and warp meta in such a way that certain archetypes are simply unplayable which limits design space, possible choices of decks to play and ultimately the fun you get out of playing this format. Some decks in the format are uninteractive and unfun to play against - "D-shift" combo deck removes your followers with spells and cycles cards until they assemble a combo to kill you on turn 7-8. Sounds fun to play against, how about a mirror match of two such decks?- Events and promotions are boring and a drag to play. "Chest event" requires you to grind the game for a lot of hours to get all daily chest rewards, Grand Prix is stressful, unoriginal (just an in-game tournament of sorts with constructed decks) and takes extra time too.- Very stong cards. You can run 3 copies of any card in your deck and most of the time one strong card will determine the outcome of the match as some cards  (especially legendary or gold rarity cards) can be disproportionally stronger in comparison to other cards. This makes the game more RNG prone as the luckier player who draws such cards is a lot more likely to win a game than a more skillful opponent who does not.- A lot of highroll decks, often times in the meta decks appear that you cannot win against if they draw the right cards and which lose pathetically if they do not draw the right cards. Matches are like coin flips decided on draw against such decks.- It is likely that this game will take a lot of your time and it will probably not be a relaxing experience in case you are looking for one.- Art style is good but not for everyone. - Reports you send in-game are ignored by the devs- Not possible to message in-game friends- No new arenas or background music have been added in a long time. - Game is popular in Japan but rather obscure in the westAll in all the future for this game looks bleak. I would suggest for you not to waste time on this game and find something else to play. If you are a masochistic anime fanatic like myself you might enjoy the game for some time, eventually you will be forced to spend money on this or burn out or just resent the experience of playing this game.

I have read a lot of complaints about campers, so let me assure you, I am one of those campers. Hunt: Showdown allows for many a play style, like rushing in with a shotgun, duelling with pistols, or sniping from far away. I have played computer games for nearly 40 years now, I'm 55, and I cannot (and would not want to) compete with the Fortnight Kiddies (like my sons...).So I will continue playing, I will continue sniping, and I will desperately try to push my KD past 0.60 - a task of herculean dimensions.Update: I have to correct myself - I'm not a camper, I'm a sniper. reviews.text: At 666 hours, I feel able to give a reasonable-enough review for folks looking into this game.Hunt is unforgiving.  The first dozen or so matches (maybe 5-10 hours) will be complete shocks and chaos.  Their tutorial is not great; if anything, it teaches you how NOT to play the game well.  But if you have a friend who's familiar with the game, or if you watch a few streamers/YouTubers, you'll quickly get a feel for this game.It's fun, edge-of-your-seat, brutally realistic action (as in, one bullet from someone you don't see or hear ends your match).  It's a game about stealth, movement, and strategy.  The weapons all feel well-balanced.  You can kill just as effectively with your starting guns (if not better) than the final-unlock automatic rifles and semi-modern tech handguns.Crytex listens to the community, they don't craft cheap DLC to belch out (I've bought most of it) just for the money.  There's arguments that some skins are "PAY TO WIN" because they might disappear into the forests better.  I find this is generally untrue for seasoned players, and feel like the devs are working ahrd to keep the community happy and the game thriving.If you are the type of person who got this far looking into Hunt - I think you're probably the kind of person who would enjoy it.  Give it more than 1-5 games to get used to it.  Remember, you don't win - you just live to die another day.

reviews.text: This is, simply put, my favourite game. There's nothing quite like Hunt out there. It's a difficult, challenging PvPvE game. You play as a bounty hunter tasked with killing a high value target in an area infested with some sort of dark magic. The only problem is, you're not the only hunter out there. You collect clues to locate the target, you kill the target, you banish the target.... then you have to escape the map with tokens proving it's you who killed it. Maps can hold 12 players, which means there will be 10 more people who are intent on stopping you leaving with that bounty. And almost everything you do can be heard by everyone else on the map, meaning you have to move as quickly as you can, whilst going as quietly as necessary. The gameplay loop is incredibly satisfying, with the right balance of risk and reward. Most things you do in a match earn you an amount of cash to take to the next lobby, where you can then either save for a rainy day, or buy higher tier equipment for your next loadout. But, anything you die with is lost to the bayou - hence the risk. If your hunter survives, they get experience and you can use that to buy some traits that make them marginally better for the next run out. This system sounds like a "win more" system, where success leads to a higher probability of success on the next run, and so it seems inevitable that the good get better equipment to be even more effective - so how can a new player break in?The answer is quite simple; all equipment has a situation where it's the best choice. The starting rifle has a larger magazine than most other guns in the game and shoots more quickly, so favours closer quarters fighting. The starting shotgun has the longest one-hit-kill range of all the shotguns. Ultimately, playing to your loadout's strengths and being better than your opponent has a FAR higher contribution to your success than the exact equipment everyone loaded in with.The barrier to a new player is therefore not an insurmountable equipment difference, it's learning the game. There are (currently) three VERY full maps, each of which is absolutely crammed with minutiae. It's about knowing how to move around compounds without triggering sound traps quickly. It's about knowing which directions you're actually vulnerable from. It's about knowing which sort of gun can shoot through that wooden wall you know they're crouched behind. It's about knowing that when the shot sounds like THAT, that means it's this specific gun and how far away they are. The burden of knowledge you have to accumulate to become proficient is very high. It's this burden of knowledge which is the thing you, as a potential buyer, have to consider. Are you prepared to get shot from places you don't understand for 20 hours? Are you prepared to be surprised by what their equipment did? You will likely die a lot before you get good. But when you DO become proficient, there is nothing like this game. Nothing replicates the thrill of you and a partner (or two) methodically outmanoeuvring another team and taking them down. Another (major) point in the "pro" column is the developer team. They are extremely active with the community, and listen to and implement suggestions from the community very proactively. They are continually improving the game and adding loads of content. I have bought a lot of the (cosmetic) DLC, purely to support the team, as I have gotten way more out of the game than the price I paid to get in.Despite every other shooter I try, I keep coming back to Hunt. As long as there are other hunters to go up against, I think I might never stop.

reviews.text: This is an OLD REVIEW that has been updated to the full release version of Hunt: Showdown. Many things have changed, and the review is horribly outdated, so I have done my best to include all of the new updates in the review.- The atmosphere of the game is amazing. You can really get immersed in the world alone, depsite the lack of NPCs or voice acting.- Graphics to this game look fantastic, even on low settings.- Weapons feel good, shoot good, and make you feel powerful with each shot. Also includes bullet speed, and one-shot headshots up to reasonable distances depending on ammo type.- A leveling system, complete with weapons, perks, abilities, and consumables to unlock and equip, and a near-endless variety to pair and test out together.- Lots of weapon and character variety. From rifles with bayonets to silenced revolvers. From a noob cowboy with plain pants and a shirt, to legends wearing black dusters covered in skulls, trinkets, and scars.- Enemy AI variety is good, making you adapt to their fighting styles and how to counter them effectively. Some enemies rush you mindlessly, but others will sit back and try to take you out at a distance. The AI is simple, but effective at their job.- The sound design. From the crunching of glass under your feet, to crows taking off when people are too close. The way the barn creaks when you take a step. The distant gunshots and being able estimate how far they are by the sound. Everything revolves around sound, and the sound is beautiful.- Weapon balancing. Every weapon this game is viable. The later weapons may be more powerful, sure, but you have a reduced ammo pool and ammo replenishment compared to earlier weapons, longer reload times, longer pauses in between shots, and a higher price point. You want to be able to keep an enemy suppressed for days? There's a weapon for that. you want to stay calm, and pick them off with a single, well-placed headshot? There's a weapon for that. You want a single-action revolver with a stock and a short range scope? There's a weapon for that... for some reason.- Random gameplay. Not in the bad way, either. One game you might not hear a peep the entire round, but the next, gunshots are ringing out from every single direction. You never truly know what's going to happen when you drop into the bayou.- Having an objective. Oh my god, having an objective. It's what separates this game from PUBG and Escape from Tarkov. Having that tangible, ever-present quest in-game, that requires multiple steps to complete most times, makes the game into more than a PvP experience. It's not something that you can be sneaky about most of the time. You have to reveal to EVERYONE where you are to complete your objective.- The price. This comes down to personal preference, and whether or not you like the amount of content so far. 2 different levels with multiple areas to explore, different times of day, 3 unique bosses, and a metric ton of challenges and weapons to unlock through gameplay.- The coop. While it is insanely fun, it can be a real pain if you join with a random partner over and over. There is also the choice of playing with group of 3 rather than 2, but can be opted out of if you would just like to play in a duo. This depends on whether or not you have someone to play the game with, and I would highly recommend picking it up if you have a confirmed partner to play with.- The bosses. The bosses themselves are great, but the variety isn't, with only 3 bosses to go after. This depends on whether you really care about the boss fights, or whether it's the PvP and world that interests you.- As far as I can tell, you need a beast of a rig to run this thing properly. It doesn't mean that you won't be able to play, but you'll be confined to playing on lower settings. Not a huge loss overall, but some people are all about dem gwaffics and framerates. The game seems to be getting more and more optimised with each update, so it'll hopefully only get better from here.- The community. I'll go into detail on this later in it's own section, because it's a tough one to cover in a few sentences.- The loading. Loading screens are long, which is understandable, since the map is massive. The in-game loading of objects and enemies, isn't. Having a hotspot be completely void of life, then spawn in 3 tough AI enemies 30 feet away both ruins the immersion and your planning from time to time.- The solo play. While you are dropped in without a partner, other people can still join with a partner, putting you at an obvious disadvantage, making solo play quite difficult. You do get a bonus for doing this, but it normally won't apply to you, since you'll end up dead. Not impossible to do, but takes a lot more skill with a meagre offering to balance it out.- The updates. Every update normally causes some type of havoc, whether it be textures getting broken, rewards not loading properly, or server disconnects. Every update seems to play around with something unintentional, which is probably thanks to the spaghetti code that's held together with masking tape and wrapping paper. Expect a few... weird... occurrences to pop up from time to time.- The learning curve. If you don't have an experienced teammate to play with, there is a lot of trial-and-error you will be doing, and you will be stomped into the mud. Over and over. I would definitely suggest watching tutorials or videos on youtube on how to actually play, because there are quite a few concepts that aren't explained anywhere in-game. When should you shoot AI? How does poison work exactly? Why did someone throw a lantern at my "dead" friend? This isn't Call of Duty. You won't know everything, and it will be the death of you. Shrug it off, grit your teeth, and jump back in for revenge.This community should  be avoided for the first little while. While they can be helpful, a large amount have found the mentality of "This game has been ruined by those filthy  gamers" due to new updates from the devs. It hasn't really been "casualized", but has been made different from what it once was. Balancing is a fickle thing, and some people would still rather have the game be reverted back to the 0.6 update, or even the 0.1 alpha.Every single corner of the reddit, steam forums, or elsewhere, are going to be coated in people complaining about how base mechanics and weapons are overpowered, while others claim that they're underpowered. Burning a downed hunter (which slowly removes him from the match unless his teammate revives him in time) is vilified by a lot of people in this game. They cite it as an unfair and stupid tactic, labelling the people who do this "insta-burners". Then you have the crowd who oppose this idea, saying "Is there any reason to not give yourself an obvious advantage over your opponent?".There's also a lot of hate surrounding the "camping" in this game. This game with have hectic, tense moments, where you run and gun your way through the woods to extraction. But... you'll also have times where the gameplay slows to a crawl, because 2 teams refuse to move. The team inside the house knows that, with their shotguns, they'll be at a disadvantage if they leave their cover to take on the rifle users outside, and the team outside realises the opposite. Therefore, both teams sit on their hands for ~30 minutes without doing anything. This gameplay scenario is looked down upon from every angle, but it's because people want the other group to make a mistake. Both teams are technically making the right decision. you decide on how you want to play, not the community.Overall, despite its flaws,the game is surprisingly stable, and surprisingly fun, for those who can run it. I would suggest picking it up, but I would also suggest picking it up with a friend, or be prepared to get destroyed your first few games.

reviews.text: This game has always looked interesting, but i'd read about the hardcore playerbase destroying everyone else and kind of put it on hold to play other stuff. Recently i finally made the plunge, and it's been fantastic. The beginner experience has not been nearly as bad as i expected, and we have killed teams and extracted with bounties plenty of times so far, and it's always exhilarating.Hunt: Showdown is a badass design package with very clear vision behind it. The visuals are gritty, gloomy and monstrous, with amazing 3D design and 2D art for things like perks. The gameplay is relatively slow and methodical, and you gotta weigh the value of your actions like shooting and running before you perform them, while still keeping pace. This is pronounced more by the long reload times, and the amazing audio design. Everything you do makes noise to varying degrees, which makes you a player magnet if you decide to run and gun or ♥♥♥♥ up and make noise by accident. Sound in this game is your best friend and your worst enemy, and learning how to use it to your advantage is super cool and will improve your chances the most. There's a lot more to say about this game but there are plenty of good reviews out there. I'd recommend checking out  for a solid impression. I'd love to see the playerbase grow and the franchise expand, so this is just me trying to peddle it to you. Big recommendation.

reviews.text: Seriously, this game has ruined me. It is in my opinion, despite its issues, one of the best multiplayer shooters of all time. The gameplay loop, the tension, the tactical options, the gunplay, the graphics, the stress, the thematics, the teamwork, the freedom of playstyle, the attention to detail, the skill ceiling and THE SOUND DESIGN all just blend together to make the most unique and wonderfull gaming experiences I've had in my life. The developers really have their ear to the ground and do their absolute best to balance and serve the community to the best of their abilities. This feels like a love child, and it is nurtured. I recommend this game to anyone who is even remotely interested, and I promise it will deliver if you are up for getting beamed in the face during your ever so expanding learning experience. The playerbase is growing with every month and it fills me with joy, as this game really deserves all the love it gets. Don't get me wrong, its a HARD ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. But it is truly worth it. I just passed my 1300 hours of playtime and I don't see myself stopping anytime soon.If in doubt and if not, go for the head and have fun. SOLID 9/10

reviews.text: Genre - FPS Western Horror Battle Royale with Strong PvE elementsI got this game to try out my new PC and played a few missions solo. Now about 50% of games I have played have been with evenly skilled teams and some of my team mates have not been complete d***s. However,  50% have been quite the opposite, and this is where the game falls down. Someone shooting you as you soon as you spawn, camping at the top of stairs with a shotgun, or at the extraction point killing you 1 second away from safety. Make this game more frustrating than fun.When you get a 'good' game though, this ticks so many boxes, so I am giving it a thumbs up.However, I think the only way to make this game great would be to add a co-op PvE mode with optional bots. So casual players like myself can choose to have fun and not frustration.

reviews.text: Steam keeps on bothering me to write a review for this game so here's one , i guess.You might have heard this ' there's nothing like it on the market ' description of Hunt : Showdown and frankly i must admit that it is mostly spot on. This game is pretty unique and intriguing mix of PVE and PVP within setting which i frankly doubt i ever really saw used in a video game before. We are talking about end of 19th century Louisiana  mixed with paranormal horror activity.If you would take a super brief look at Hunt's gameplay loop one could mistakenly assume that it is a battle royal game and while there are few similarities between the two, Hunt has a really original and unique gameplay loop i have never seen done before in a video game.Core idea here is that you enter a map , which is 1km x 1km square , either alone , in a duo or a trio of hunters and your main goal is to look for clues to locate a boss , kill him , banish him and extract with a bounty. Sounds simple enough , right? But that is there fun actually behinds. Besides having to contend with PVE part of the game , that is various kind of AI controlled zombies ( for the lack of better word ) , number of sound traps like injured animals ,crows ,caged chickens and dogs ( of whom all make loud noises then disturbed in turn giving out your location and even direction you are moving in ) , you are also not alone in a pursuit of that bounty. That is there PVP part of game kicks in .Even  though this is  PVPVE game , PVE is here only to slow down you rather than being a real threat. Real threat comes from other players who also have same goal as you. Real 'meat' of this game is PVP and while you can choose and avoid PVP all together , you will not have much fun while doing so. Bosses , again , are mostly there to funnel players into the same area to initiate PVP fights.PVP is rough and tough in Hunt. From what i understand earlier in it's life it was even more hardcore , but even at it's current state this game is not for faint hearted folks. Kill times are low , weapons are mostly single shots so each shot counts ( fitting the settings and time period ) and while on a surface this could look like a simple point and shoot situation there are dozens upon dozens of systems and things to consider in each firefight so you will need tens and in some cases hundreds of hours to really start to feel what are you doing.  I wont lie to you , for first 20 or 30 hours i was pretty much cowering behind stuff in each firefights in essence being a glorified decoy for enemy players while my team mate hopefully was doing something less useless.  Hunt can be really stressful with steep learning curve, perma death ( losing your hunter with all his/her equipment you spent so much money on ) and never knowing who has your in their scopes while crossing open fields but it also can be so very rewarding when you survive a final server wide gunfight on your last bullet and out of healing items. Even 140 hours in some of the firefights leaves me with my heart pounding which is a rare occasion after playing video games and FPS game for more than 25 years now.There are of course bunch of technical issues, questionable decisions from the dev team and other negatives associated with any competitive online game so be aware of that before you decide to enter Bayou .

reviews.text: After "testing" the game for about 100 hours i want to write a review, first of all i went into this game with quite a hype, so my expectations were pretty high and i have to say it lives almost completly up to my hype, lets start with the prosGameplay: many people say its a new take on the battle royal genre, i'd say thats 20% true, hunt tries to be its own game with other goals than battle royal games, the focus is highly on pvp but you can avoid that and go for the pve experience if you really want to, which sadly results in less xp but i think thats a fair trade Graphic: its a crytek game so yea, the graphic and details, specially for a 30€/$ game are id say almost insane ( but it has a con to it which i will mention later)Map and enemies: the map it quite big, i didnt expect a witcher 3 map in terms of size but the map in hunt is still big enough for the type of game and for you to feel like you'll need hours from point A to B, but the details in this map, holy, this map is so detailed that i've never seen a map where theres so much love and detail in every corner, sure there are some areas where you can go under a roots but thats rare.For the enemies? they are pretty detailed to, even so detailed that its almost kind of disgusting if you take a closer look at them, flesh falling of everywhere, rotting skin hanging from their body revealing bones, hives growing out of the ribcage busting it open, maggots that eat the skin and so on, there aren't to much enemy-type at the moment and most of them only have small detail changes ( hives wear different dresses ) but im sure if time goes on they will have a good variety like they have with the basic zimbies (grunts)Hunters: like with the map and the enemies, the hunters are pretty detailed too, besides different skin colors they have different clothes, which all look super detailed even on medium setting (<- this coming up as a con. later )Weapons: there aren't to much weapons at the moment but if you read it to this point you know whats coming, they are all highly detailed in terms of look, functions and soundnow i want to adress the cons of this gameOptimization: as much as i like to praise the graphics, they are a bit of a con too, the optimization in this game at the moment ( there was a perfomance patch so it is a bit better now ) isnt that great, if you dont have a highend beast of a pc you wont get to play this game on highest settings with stable 60 or even just 30 fps, most people will have 30-60 on low to middle settings with the average pc Balancing: well i had to come to this point because the balancing even tho its quite good, has its flaws, most and foremost the difference between tier 1 and tier 3 hunters, i dont mean that its op that tier 3's have better camouflage because thats fine, the difference in loadout, perks* and  starting hp is what makes it hard for tier 1 and 2 hunters to keep up if you're not a highly experienced player, weapons, for example  the autonagant (rarely used due to its price) is a close to midrange monster and you wont have any chance fighting someone who has this weapon and knows what he does, that means that there are hunters who use this weapon (1 in 30 games, pretty rare) and wipe the whole server and the price (999$) doesnt really make up for it because its quite easy to make that money if there noone left *Perks: some hightier perks are slightly imbalanced, most perks are  unlocked at low levels and most of them are almost essential for your hunter, but stuff like the fanning perk ( lets you fire a singleaction revolver in a way higher rate of fire, google fanning for more infos )are unlocked pretty late but they could give lower tier hunters a bit of a advantage and they could keep up with higher tier weapons Shooting mechanic: at the moment the shootouts are more or less a "who can run faster from right to left"-fiesta , in a game this slowpaced, there should be a downside to moving while aiming, but as it is right now, your weapon sways just a little and its quite easy to get hitssome minor cons: AI movement is quite stale, they walk from point A to B and only leave their route if they're alerted, im no programmer but i think its possible to implement a point C and then switch up the way they walk maybe? just a thoughtthe realod of some weapons bothers me a bit, im talking about the specter ( pumpaction shotgun ), the dolch (autoloading pistol) and the mosin nagant ( bolt action rifle ) they all lose one bullet uppon realoading, the perk "pump-jockey" is a fix for the specter but to be honest, if you have the perk equiped your hunter will take the unused round and put it back in because without the perk it gets tossed away, i kinda think the perk is a bit unnecessary, for the other 2 guns, well theres no perk you'll always lose one round uppon realoading, im mean technically you could pick them up and put them back in but yea, just a minor thing thats bothering me, not gamebreaking or anything well as it stands right now, the game is in a pretty solid place, its a hardcore not really forgiving game that takes some inspiration from the battle royal games and makes them harder, its a really fresh wind in the shooter genre with only cod bf like games or battle royal, all in all i can recommend this game

reviews.text: I went into this game completely expecting to not be to of my liking and refund it, but I am overwhelmed on how fun this game is.Why did I think I wouldn't like this game? I primarily play Arcade Shooters like COD, where I just charge in guns blazing for kills and if I die its fine, I respawn. I also do not enjoy BRs because you spend a lot of time scavaneging to get killed by a sniper in some corner. Hunt not only has that high risk and reward, but the death is perma i.e you lose your hunters and gear when you die.So why did I end up loving this game?I will be honest, the first few games was brutal and if its your first time in this genre, it will be for you too. I was playing this game like I play COD, see a guy and then charge hoping to land a kill. You CANNOT play this game that way and it was stupid of me to play that way. After the first few games I realized, the game's main foxcus is not the shooting, its your tactical gameplay. I was not happy that the gunfights were so short, but then I realized, it's supposed to be that way coz the game is not about the shootout, its about how you tactically reach to that shgootout. Gun fights are not supposed to drag out, the stealthily creeping up to your enemy and landing the pefect shot is what is supposed to drag out. The perfect game play is you and your team mates spending a lot of time to get the perfect position and kill your enemy with one shot. That's the fun part. Once you realize that, you will see how fun the game isThe sound design and accuracy is undoubtedly one of the bests, so you gotta be careful to not step on branches, glasses or scare off the birds coz the enemy will not only know of your existence but will also know where you are coz the directional audio is very accurate. Every step, movement, bullet matters and you have to treat it that way. It doesnt mean you cannot change your playstyle, for ex there are double pistols, shotguns, melee etc that you can use for a more action packed gameplay, but even that you have to plan out well.Hunt Showdown plays a very specific way and it outshines in doing that. I highly reccomend this game.

reviews.text: Hunt Showdown is not a fair game, and that´s Ok.Hunt is not designed to be a balanced shooter in the traditional sense. Games like Valorant, and Counter Strike with their limited maps and short rounds are designed for teams of equally powerful members fighting each other. Hunt is different. Balance in this game is achieved by the player and not by game mechanics or gun stats. The cheapest weapons in the game all have their place and are effective in the right circumstances. Because of the freedom we have in each game it is up to you to create those advantageous circumstances for yourself.If you are engaged in a fair fight, than both players have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up.Where an overpowered weapon becomes truly OP in games that force you to engage in relatively even fights, Hunt provides the freedom to change the odds. Weapons are not balanced against each other. But that is ok, because how you can play can shift the balance in your favor.Pick weapons and consumables that suit your style. Set traps for enemies. Engage at ranges favorable to you. Ambush opponents. Don't be afraid to disengage. Reposition frequently. Patience and preparation are rewarded and situational awareness is king. The most accurate player in the game can't beat you if you kill him before he sees you.The fact that the lowest scum like me can kill a good (very good) Player with a Winfield or Sparks-Sniper simply by being patient and observant is the best part of the game. Matches feel like you are legitimately hunting someone. Every action you take has consequences. I've run from many 3 vs 1 fights after screwing up the headshots. No one can kill you if you're out of sight.Don't wanna go up alone against 3 Players or against a Avtomat? Go for a long distance. Ambush them, shoot them while they're climbing ladders, reviving or healing, shooting something else or reloading.Fairplay has no place here you are a Hunter (Bountyhunter) not the good fairy.And that's why I love this game!

reviews.text: is an early access first-person shooter with Battle Royale style gameplay ( though; it's hard to define its genre) whose mastery of tension, theming, and tactical components has birthed a game where every match is as exhilarating as the next. wants to make you think like a hunter, and incorporates as many of our senses as it can. Unfortunately, our hands are occupied with the mouse and keyboard so we’re left with sight and sound and my god has  nailed it in this respect.The combination of a highly reactive landscape, excellent visual information, and sound design that’s so crisp I can hear my opponents picking their nose from 20 yards is masterfully executed enveloping a player into the game. This is the area where I think  separates itself from many of the other  or first-person shooters.To put this into perspective I’ll set up a metaphorical scenario. You are crouched outside a building and you suspect someone to be nearby. Here’s a list of some of the things you are likely to hear: crows, duck, chickens, dying horses, caged dogs, and all monsters will make noise when you get close to them. If the other person is not being sneaky, crows and ducks will also fly away, giving other visual information. You could also hear: footsteps on different terrain, doors opening, engines, hanging bottles that chime when knocked, and broken glass. There are so many audio cues that you can hear, perking your attention. This is what gives the player a feeling of real empowerment, making them feel like a tracker as they stalk their opposition using the endless number of audio ques.’s sound design also allow for an eerie, dismal atmosphere to set in.Moments of intense combat puncture through the sombre ambience, screams and cries from hives carry across baron fields and morbid yards, and the silence is peaceful yet tense. With tuned ears, about any noise you make can turn you from predator to prey; from a hunter to the hunted.This is a game that on a surface level looks like a Battle Royale style game but plays .You have something on the line, your hunter, your gear, and the bounty that you so rightly deserve. The potential of losing all of that makes you question every door and every window you come across. The tension this creates is immense, your heart pounds knowing there’s another hunter in the next room. You can hear him, which means he can hear you. It plays out like a strategic game of chess, you move into an advantageous position, the other hunter does the same putting you in a mental checkmate. You have no idea what gun he has, if he’s alone, and if his partner is soon to arrive. You either have to take him on or leave him and hope someone else does the dirty work for you.Teamwork encompasses many aspects, but it begins with selecting your team.There are many ways to play:- Solo queue.- Queue with premade group.- Queue with 1 random.- Queue with 2 randoms.Hunt: Showdown uses , that other teams may be able to hear.It is not disrespectful for a teammate to not respond, and  of the possibility of other teams being nearby.The pinging tool is widely used, both in premades and random queues. This allows you to point at whatever is under your crosshair and share it with your team only. Other teams cannot hear or see pingsSo using the pinging system is a very good way to communicate. sees you playing as a bounty hunter in the  swamps, sent to hunt down and collect bounties that have been set on ghastly horrors. In a match your goal is to find clues to locate a monster lurking in one of the map’s compounds, kill the monster, and banish them back to whatever hell it came from.There’s a catch though, there are eight or nine other players that are trying to do the same, and will stop at nothing to retrieve that bounty all for themselves.Even if you can do the impossible and banish the beast you still have to escape with the bounty in your grasp. introduces a thematic natural way to condense players into one area using an objective style system, you will need to find three clues to deduce where the bounty is dwelling. With each clue the number of possible places the monster is hiding narrows.This leads the players to a smaller area where chances of encountering other players is greatly increased but does not force players together like  or  does, which feels more realistic.So, you got the bounty and got out alive.You will get rewarded with an in-game currency that you can spend on better weapons, tools, and consumables. Your hunter will also gain experience based on activities you have done throughout the match allowing you to unlock and equip different perks.If any consumables were used you will need to restock on those consumables, and if by chance you lost a health bar you can replenish it.Well I’m afraid to say that  is no longer with you.All of his equipment, tools and guns, all gone.Take comfort in knowing that his memory will live on in your . There is a separate counter for experience points (bloodline) and will allow you to unlock improved guns, perks, etc., similar to how a  game would. This permadeath mechanic adds so much tension into every second of hunt. No one wants to lose all their stuff, ever.Losing a character is one thing but permanent scarring of a hunter can also occur. If you get gunned down during a heated gunfight your partner can pick you up but it will permanently lower your character’s health by one bar. This can be recovered by spending perk points between games, but it should not be taken lightly. Additionally, if you catch on fire due to another player’s attack or an environmental effect you slowly begin to burn. If the flames are not snuffed out you could also permanently lose a health bar.Until you are level 15, everything comes for free.And when you hit level 16, one out of the four hunters you get each game, will be free (and all the equipments that comes with him too).If you're looking for something absolutely new which isn't just a mindless FPS this might be the game for you. Very intense and strategic.If you just run around and shoot, in most cases, you will get shot or get killed by players, zombies, dogs or any other monster.Sneaking and communicating with your partner is the key to success (unless you play the "Solo" gamemode).It's still in Early Access and has some issues but there are regular patches that fixes them and overall performance has improved. This might be my Game of the Year 2018.I already spent 40+ hours and even if there are only two large map (for now), it's not getting boring yet.Gameplay: 95/100Audio: 100/100Environment: 100/100

reviews.text: When I first played this game, I tried it alone; through training and after I lost my training wheels, and it . I would sneak around and either wait on other players as they killed bosses and attempt to pick them off (and fail) or I got into gunfights and lost.Then I tried matchmaking with random duos - half the time high or fellow low levels wouldn't bother playing due to my immediately obvious low level and skill (some kind of incentive for experienced players to take a low level player into a match might help there, @devs), but the other occasions when an experienced player took me along - . Up to twelve players in a match, but you  as the game will not tell you. Everyone spawns on the edges of the map, but unlike battle royale-esque shooters, the prominent factor that drives players together is not a zone that forces them to interact, it's the promise of risk vs reward. To get the in-game rewards, there are many AI enemies to face off against, including 3 variants on a boss battle. Up to two of the bosses can be present in any one match, and players are tasked with finding clues to track them down.  Killing the bosses isn't enough, as they drop 2 'bounties' that must be extracted for maximum gain. Each player can only carry 1 bounty of each type, encouraging (at minimum) each duo to aim to kill one boss, grab a bounty each, and extract. There are limited areas to extract, and everyone on the server can see where they are.However after killing each boss, there is a process which delays the players in picking up the bounties, and also displays the boss' position to the rest of the server. As soon as the bounties are picked up, the players' positions are displayed to the rest of the server. Start 'banishing' the dead boss to get the bounties? The server sees where you are. Pick up the bounties? Not only does the server see where you are, but they might be able to reasonably guess which exit you are taking. If you have the bounties, you play a mind game in fending off other teams whilst getting out safely. If you don't have the bounties then you are hunting other teams that  have the bounties by guessing their exit, assaulting them head on whilst they wait on the 'banish' phase, or attempting to ambush them somewhere in between it all. Better yet, you sneak up on another unexpecting team and wipe them, negating competition early on!: Your gunshots, or triggering aspects within the game known as 'sound traps' (e.g. a flock of crows is startled by you, flying off loudly) will alert other hunters to your location. If you ever do come head to head with another team, then are they flanking you when you can't see them? Given that teams can range from 1-3 people, when you only killed a single player, do they have a buddy? When you and another team both banish at the same time, but they don't pick up their bounties, are they coming for you? There is a constant, tense stream of questions you ask yourself as you play. There is so much detail in each map, and within the interiors of the buildings. The game is dripping with lore and the aesthetic of the weird west, and it is really enjoyable to experience. Hearing another player's character breath as they wait in a bush a few feet from you (via the wonders of binaural audio design) is a tense feeling you don't often experience.It's stressful, you will likely die and lose your stuff a lot. HOWEVER, do not let this grind you down, you learn a lot from failure in my experience. A low skill player can still kill a high skill player with starting weapons. A new player can still outwit an experienced player if they are smart enough. There is definitely a steep learning experience to this game but there is a high skill ceiling and experience that I haven't experienced in any other title in this genre. I have not even hit the first prestige rank so I make no claim to being an expert with this game, but I do my best to take new players under my wing in a random matchmake and teach them the basics that I had to learn myself. When I play in a team and we click, and some beautiful gunfights come together: win or lose, I have a lot of fun.

reviews.text: This is one of those games that I wish you could choose a middle option between Recommended and Not Recommended for. There is nothing out there like Hunt, so it's just hard to tell at first glance whether or not you'll like it. Me, I picked it up because I really dig the 19th century horror aesthetic. I really thought it was a very different game when I got it, and it took a long time for me to understand what it really is all about.I recommend it only on the condition that you do some research about it first. Watch a stream, read some reviews, check out the Reddit, and then buy the game only when you're absolutely convinced you're in. It'd really help if you can convince a friend or two to play with you because 1) communication is key, 2) having friends to laugh with will ease the anxiety and sting of losing a hunter. Otherwise, either try to join sub-communities (Twitch streamers' Discords) or prepare to play with randoms who can be really cool, really bad (even worse than my .68 KD self), really try-hard, or really unresponsive.--------------------------------------------------Hunt's a PvPvE game where you roll a hunter, set them up with items and weapons, and then go off into one of two (soon to be three) maps. Your objective is to find the boss monster located in one of the map's many compounds, kill it, and get out. On the way to your goal, you will run into a small variety of mobs and, if you're (un)lucky enough, the other players on the map.There are only ever at most 12 players in a match. Because the maps are large and everybody has the same objective, this means people are getting funneled toward the same point. So, fights can get real chaotic. The thing that makes this interesting is that guns hit very hard and fire very slowly (except for one or two exceptions that make the folks on Reddit reeee). The name of the game is patience and deliberate tactical decisions. One bad move can knock you straight back into lobby. To make things even more nail-biting, your hunter dies permanently, and rolling a new hunter can cost you.So, in the face of all of this, what do you do? Learn your guns, learn the maps, learn to "see with your ears", and be patient. 250 hours in, and I'm still doing all of this.Most reviews on this game will likely point this out. The low TTK, the slow-firing guns, and other mechanics all come together to make a very punishing experience. If I'm not mistaken, map design is centered around making sure you're never truly safe from enemy shots. Sound plays a major role in the game, so you have to learn how to move effectively and quietly, or else you'll have hunters springing ambushes on you. Each gun in the game has a unique look and feel, adding an extra layer of complexity to an already dense game.So, avoid this game if you don't think you'll have the time needed to learn it. You won't have fun if you're not getting better. Having a friend teaching or learn along with you will make the process of learning the basics a lot less painful.Hunt Showdown being a multiplayer game, one has to be wary of how predatory the microtransactions (because there always are) can be. Good news: there is no pay-to-win. Bad news: all of the DLC hunters and guns look really freaking cool.The game is also pretty generous with its premium currency. You get a small amount per game--something in the range of 1-12 depending on your performance (kills, objectives, etc.). It adds up over the hours, so you can definitely make a case for saving up to get that one skin you want.As with every game with a large player-base, your mileage may vary. Hunt isn't HUGE, mind you, but it's big enough that most players will be entirely anonymous to you. So, of course, there are jerks and bigots and try-hards and trolls. They are definitely in the small minority, but a glance at the game's Discord can make the community seem unwelcoming. You will see a lot of people asking for 2+ KD players with 300+ hours (I'm at 250 with .68 KD :s).But, really, the Hunt community is pretty cool. The nicest, most welcoming folks can be found hanging around Twitch streamers. The more experienced players tend to be so beyond caring about winning (they've been broken) that games with them are some of the most chilled out experiences I've ever had. Your best bet as a new player will be to go into the Discord or a streamer's chat, and and just introduce yourself as a new player looking to learn the ropes.By the way, matchmaking is elo-based, so prepare to end up in games where you're totally outmatched just because you killed somebody with higher KD.I adore this game, but it took me about 40 hours for it to really click with me. Until then, I stayed for the aesthetic, atmosphere, and that sweet feeling of running out with the bounty. After that 40 hour mark, I was hooked. By that point, I had prestiged for the first time (it can take a lot less time if you win a lot). This is the first time I've ever prestiged in any shooter, and so the snowball started rolling.There are some times where I'm utterly demoralized. Other times, I'm riding on the highest high I've ever felt in a video game.

reviews.text: Talk about an atmospheric gameplay experience, Hunt Showdown is a gorgeous horror shooter stealth game with the sole intent of having the players immersed in a chilling western environment where each single match could be the last.Right off the bat, this is not a game that belongs in the oversaturated Battle Royale market. No. Hunt Showdown is a very unique arena shooter that involves both PvE and PvP. In fact, the remarkable aesthetic and art style are breathtakingly amazing. Combined with the absolutely fantastic sound design, the world presented is awe-inspiring and scary beyond imagination.With only 1 opened world map, 2 bosses and only a handful of enemies, there just doesn't seem to be a lot of variety at the moment. The gunplay, on the other hand, is marvelous! Though the combat is slow paced, the shooting is one of the best aspects of the game, making you really concentrate your fire when needed.All the many details implemented, such as the different weather style, unnerving sounds (damn twig snaps), and even the user interface, make it a special kind of horror. All throughout the match there is never a death count or actual indication of what exactly is going down. You might hear gunshots in the distance thinking people are duke it out, but you won't know the outcome. That makes for really good tension.It feels to me like Hunt Showdown could end up being a niche title, not a bad thing, because even though the progression system is very rewarding, the perma death element ( meaning that once the hunter you've recruited gets killed off, they stay dead) might not be everyone's cup of tea.Honestly, Crytek have a lot to improve here, especially when it comes to the performance, but it has the potential of being a very solid multiplayer game. Give it a try!

reviews.text: Hunt: Showdown is a competitive first person shooter, based in an overgrown, beat down Louisiana. You will be facing off against 8 or 9 other players depending on whether or not you brought a companion. These other people and yourself are all scouring the map for clues that help you narrow down where the massive monsters are lurking, waiting for you to Hunt them Down. Other players are not your only imminent danger while you’re traversing the land, there are hordes of monsters around every corner.  The game does an absolutely incredible job of immersing you and giving you a constant sense of tension. There’s hardly a lull in the sounds of this world, you hear dogs barking, crows flying, zombies walking, gunshots blasting, and the majority of the sounds have an actual reason for happening. You have to be constantly be paying attention to where and why you are hearing things, were those crows from an enemy running through them? Is that zombie grunting because it just got attacked? You will always be on edge wondering these things, but not because the game is trying to trick or scare you, it’s always providing accurate information of what is happening, you just have to learn how to interpret it correctly. Before you enter into a match you are given some options, you have a few Hunters to choose from who each come equipped with different weapons, tools, or passive abilities to aid you on your mission. If the Hunters do not have exactly what you would prefer to use, you have a set amount of money that you can use to gear your character the way you would prefer. As you level up and collect bounties from your matches you will earn more money that you can use to bring better equipment in the future. However you do not get to keep your Hunters and equipment forever. If your Hunter is killed for any reason during a match (other than a game crash) then they will be permanently lost along with anything they were carrying. This certainly can be harsh for newer players, but the developers are constantly working on ways to help ease new players into the experience, without ruining the hardcore aspects that the main playerbase loves. Crytek are utilizing the Early Access phase of their game much better than the majority of games I’ve followed. They are pushing out updates nearly every week, with major content being added at least every month. Even just since the game started in early access it’s performing significantly better, they’ve eliminated hundreds of bugs, added a massive amount of gameplay features, equipment, passives, a new map, the list goes on. Hunt: Showdown is absolutely a very passionate project for Crytek, and they are doing everything they can to listen to the community while trying to build the game that they’re envisioning. Hunt: Showdown is a hardcore, PvPvE (Player VS. Player VS. Environment) game that focuses on hunting down AI boss targets and escaping the match alive. Matches consist of 10 players, either solo or duo, and are limited to an hour in length. You will choose and equip a character before you enter the match, and you are able to loot weapons from other fallen players. During the match you have the ability to see “clues” at every compound on the map that all other players will also be drawn to. As you activate these clues it narrows down sections of the map and eventually shows you exactly where your boss target is, currently it can either be a large pig butcher abomination or an incredibly quick, massive spider made of human body parts. If you manage to defeat the monster and escape with it’s bounty alive, you are given a large chunk of currency that you are able to better equip your hunter in your next matches. A quick play mode was also just recently added that shakes up the typical formula a bit. You can only join it with random characters, but they’re completely free, and it’s entirely focused on PvP rather than the match being about killing a boss. The UI functions well with few bugs, however some sections of it can be a bit confusing. They are constantly changing and improving it, but sometimes they leave areas of it untouched when they have features planned that will completely change the purpose of that menu. I have had few issues with it, but it’s certainly not perfect yet. As for the controls, they may feel a little strange at first. Particularly the way you fire your weapon or use tools. Your character wont fire his gun just by pressing the Left-Mouse Button. You have to first hold Right-Click to raise your weapon, this will let you hip-fire by pressing Left-Click, or if you would like to be more accurate, you have to continue holding Right-Click then tap Shift to aim down your sight, then you can Left-Click to fire as you would be used to in other shooters. It seems weird at first, but you’ll find it works well for this style of game. All keys are also easily rebindable in the menu if anything isn’t to your liking by default. Crytek are known for their impressive visuals in games and they certainly do not disappoint in Hunt: Showdown. The game looks absolutely outstanding on any graphic settings, and their thematic choice holds up very well for the gameplay. There is a large amount of detail in every area, dense forests, murky swamps, haunting churches, and no part of it seems out of place. There are a large amount of graphical options to tune the game to your liking and to improve your performance, and they are still working on implementing even more. The game’s performance is not great yet, even on a very powerful machine, but they are constantly making adjustments with every patch. One other important thing to note, is the game still does not have a field of view setting, which will certainly turn off a lot of people who would prefer to play on a higher setting. Amongst all of the many things I love about the game, I honestly believe the audio may be my favorite part. It may seem like a strange thing to say about a videogame, but the audio truly is what ties the entire experience together. Crytek have tried very hard to make sure every aspect of the game keeps you on your toes, feeling the tension of the area around you, always forcing you to be as aware as possible. Every patch that comes to the game improves aspects of the audio as it’s not all perfect yet, but overall it absolutely is the most important thing driving the immersion of this game. The audio is also constantly relevant to gameplay, players can give away their position by crunching on branches or broken glass, gunshots can be heard from across the map if you’re not careful about what weapon you’re using. As the game advances they are also adding more ways to use the audio to play mind games on your opponents such as throwable decoys that imitate a gunshot sound where they land. I believe the audio will always be one of the most important aspects of the game and something that will continue being a driving force for the tension and ambiance. Hunt: Showdown is one of the most unique first person shooter games on the market. Due to its hardcore nature and it not being finished it has yet to find a massive playerbase. However it provides something that almost no other games do, an incredibly immersive player vs. player experience that continues to be thrilling and tense even after having played it for hundreds of hours. Crytek have done a very good job improving the game thus far, and I am certain that when they believe the game is finished, it will be one of the best first person shooters ever made.

reviews.text: I've been following Hunt since the game was first annouced, but only recently decided to take the plunge. A fairly small community and unforgiving gameplay being my priamry reasons for holding back as long as I did.I can safely say my doubts were proven wrong, when I watched the latest content update reveal and saw the developers were really passionate about supporting the future of the game. The game mechanics make the world feel alive and the interaction between other players intense and exciting. AI controlled enemies only further add to the intensity of the gameplay and provide more ways of interacting with the world.Speaking of the "world", the graphics are absolutely gorgeous. People have complained about performance issues but personally I've had very few. It really is very polished when compared to most early access games. The atmosphere is amazing and the amount of detail across the environments is evident everywhere you go. Both interior and exterior locations have received a lot of effort to make them feel real. The enemies look and sound scary and really belong in the horrific setting of the 1895 Louisiana wilderness. The gunplay is another amazing aspect of Hunt. Weapons are fun to shoot and firefights are intense if not brief. The more you play, the more you unlock and consequently the more risk you take when you play a match. If you die, you lose everything you're carrying, except for xp and cash earned. This is the trade off for bringing more powerful weapons into the match and is a great way of balancing higher level players against newer ones.I could go into so much more about Hunt but I think you really need to play it to understand how enjoyable it is. I'm not usually someone who likes battle royale type games or perma death, but Hunt is something new altogether. Give it a try if you have any interest, it won't disappoint you!

reviews.text: I'll be making this as informative as possible for any potential buyers out there, so please bear with me. This game is regarded as a hardcore, niche shooter that began as a PVE (Player versus Environment) title that was converted to PVP (Player versus Player) with PVE elements as the Battle Royal fad picked up steam. *My suggestion at the start is; don't buy it yet, but keep an eye on it.* The ultimate purpose of each match is to locate clues to triangulate a npc boss placed randomly around the map, kill it, banish it to hell, then grab a bounty token as proof of the kill and finally extract to three randomly generated locations on the outskirts of the map. As you attempt to fulfill this task, you'll likely engage some NPC enemies as they've heavily populated the map and have converged on various settlements. Not only that, but you're running the risk of engaging with other players, and then killing them.  The AI enemies exist to redirect players, force them to give away their position by combat, serve as an unconventional warning system to nearby players and lastly to complicate existing shootouts between players. Mind you, they are actually deadly and can easily kill you if you're caught in a pinch. Fortunately for you lot, they're stupid. First things first, no weapon in this game operates on a hitscan mechanic but on an actual projectile system. Hitscan mechanics are very popular among shooters, as you only need to place your crosshairs on a target and pull the trigger to deal damage. Hunt's true projectile system requires you to know the speed of your ammunition type and to lead your shots appropriately to fight effectively. Hunt places an incredible amount of emphasis on sound, as players make noises no AI can replicate and are the only things capable of triggering sound traps. It could be argued that you'll hear your opponents before you see them, so ambushes are highly likely. Your goal is to get the bounty, but killing players often takes precedent.Regarding soundtraps, they're everywhere. Gatherings of crows and ducks which get spooked if a player gets too close, to dying horses and caged animals which break out into a frenzy should you approach. Shards of glass scattered on the ground, hanging kitchenware, bottles, horseshoes and chains. The cries of the AI enemies if they detect a player. The sounds of players grunting as they fight the AI. Simply moving around makes noise depending on the surface upon which you travel: dry dirt, mud, wooden planks, fallen branches, metal roofs and water. Gunshots will ring out from incredible distances, with certain guns being more noticeable.There are five projectile speeds in the game, technically six. Starting from slowest to fastest, we have: Thrown items, Crossbow bolts, Compact, Shotshells, Medium and Long. It could be argued that thrown items don't count, but I've placed them here for informative purposes.  Learning the relative speeds of your ammuntion type and the weapons that utilize them is the foundation for combat. Generally speaking, you'll start the game with weapons using shotgun shells and compact ammo. Crossbow bolts and medium ammo using weapons are unlocked rather mid to late bloodline, whereas long ammo weapons are mostly late bloodline options.The Bloodline is one of two leveling mechanics Hunt features. It is your direct account level, and governs the unlocking of weapons, traits, cash prizes and hunter tiers. Hunter tiers used to provide substantial benefits, a Tier 3 hunter would have 150 health compared to a Tier 1 possessing 100. This was removed a while ago, so now higher Tier hunters only bring cosmetic changes and potentially better equipment and traits when you hire them. The second leveling mechanic is the hunters themselves. If you successfully extract from a mission alive, your hunter is rewarded experience based on what you did in the mission and levels up. Leveling your hunter gives you more perk points, which are used to purchase traits for your hunter. Your bloodline simply unlocks the trait, but you must level your hunter and then purchase the trait. This is locked to the hunter himself, and if he dies they're gone forever. You'll need to level another hunter in order to purchase the trait again, or get lucky in the recruitment phase and hire a hunter already featuring the trait. This mechanic empowers those who survive, making them more resilient to the environment or more deadly outright with the proper traits.-With the implementation of the quickplay mode, players have the opportunity to play at no risk in an actual battle royal. You rush to find 4 items of interest, and then if you're the first to get 4 your goal is to survive. The longer you're alive the more money you'll walk away with, even if you die. If someone beats you to the punch, you'll need to kill them and take the objective for yourself. This mode allows low leveled players to potentially get and use endgame weapons and traits. However, you can take these weapons into the original mode only if you win the quickplay mission. This means that skilled players can easily get strong loadouts for free, with the added benefit of the contraband status on your equipment. With quickplay, money is no consequence, since playing the mode exclusively results in free money and bloodline experience; with the added benefit of a No Risk High Reward loadout should you win. I'll wrap things up here with what I feel is the outright cons. -The game is incredibly unforgiving to new players. Combat against players is very different than against AI, therefore trial and error is the name of the early game. Doesn't help that low rank gear and equipment is laughable in comparison to everything else.-An actual practice range isn't in the game, it's on the roadmap for the future but that means you're on your own. Basically it means that you'll learn to swim by jumping off a boat.  -A while back compact ammunition provided low rank players with the potential to kill higher ranked players with a headshot at long range. High rank players complained to the point where the devs nerfed the ammo type to prevent long range sniping, meaning that high rank hunters can one tap you from a distance in which you'll need to hit them twice. This was regarded as a nerf to skill, by some players.-The community is rather hostile to new people on the steam discussion forums. This is a niche, hardcore shooting game. Any suggestions to make things easier for newer players or to make the game more appealing to a wider audience usually gets shot down quickly. -Unoptimized game across many different rigs.-Suffers from low player count, you're often put into empty games or repeatedly matched with the same/higher ranked players.-Quickplay provides a zero risk way to quickly get money and Bloodline ranks, compared to the main Bounty Hunt mode.-Matchmaking is based on two key points, Hunter Kills/Deaths and Bounties extracted. If you play a bunch of empty games and extract several bounties you'll likely be matched with players with large amounts of kills. Bounties being extracted equals a material advantage.-Existing playerbase is divided by 7 regions, then 2 game modes, and lastly 3 different bounties on the base game mode, Bounty Hunt.-Currently there isn't much of a temptation to prestige in this game outside of personal challenge and promises of unspecified future rewards. The result is players reaching rank 100 and just sitting there forever, at rank 100 you gain a constant cash flow and retain access to all items. -There's rumbling in the distance in regards to the Dev's stability; they're apparently shifting from adding new content to optimization for several months out. In conclusion I stress the following: Don't buy it yet, but keep an eye on it.EDIT: They're bringing in premium currency and microtransactions. It looks like it'll be cosmetic for now, but we all know how slippery a slope that is huh?

reviews.text: is a hardcore, Multiplayer FPS PvEvP game with amazing audio, a rather unique setting, and hands-down, the most infuriating gunplay I’ve ever had the opportunity to try. How come I’m recommending it? Well, you’ll have to read the rest of the review to find that out.::So, I’ve played Hunt for 191 hours at the time of writing this review. I’ve had the privilege of having many of my friends interested in this game so I always had a party to play with. It’s been a great time and frustration all in one package but, .HUNT: Showdown is a pretty straightforward game. Collect the clues, slay the monster and, extract to cash-in their bounty. The problem is, extracting alive with the bounty is not going to be easy as there will be up to 11 other players and they’re all hell-bent on doing the exact same thing.The best thing about this is actually the lack of information about other hunters. You will never know if you’re alone in a server or how many hunters are there. The game will never tell you if another hunter died, has another teammate or if they’ve left the game. The only way you can make sure that someone is dead is if you personally kill them.More often than not, you’ll have to force your way out of the zone and battle multiple enemies to cash-in your bloody prize. On the other hand, if you’re the one who’s stalking other players, clever use of stealth, the game’s amazing audio design, positioning, and your tools will help you take your target(s) down and claim the bounty for yourself. That’s why it is generally a good idea not to be stingy when it comes to your hunter's equipment and loadout, before accepting a contract.Make sure you can take the hit and live through so,  as they’re the best way to quickly deal with the monsters without alerting other hunters to your presence.You could also bring dynamite sticks and bundles, Molotov cocktails or frag grenades. There are various trip-mines, barb-wire spools, vials of poisonous gas, and  jars with venomous insects. What you bring is completely up to you, but keep one thing in mind - .Your hunter, his guns, tools, and consumable items – they'll be lost forever. You won’t get the money back, and you don't get the opportunity to retrieve them. Starting all over again is the only option.Hunt: Showdown's gunplay feels uninspiring, and somewhat inconsistent at times.  of Hunt: Showdown.Pretty much all of the game’s rifles are little more than copy-pastes of another. Sure, they have slightly different statistics like effective range and damage values, but most rifles rifle and handguns in this game feels very similar.On top of that, weapon stats are kind of arbitrary.A point blank shotgun blast will occasionally forget to kill the target, while shots from far away can do wonders.All of the rifles need precisely two body-shots to get a hunter to 0 HP which means that, no matter what rifle you pick, you will need the exact number of bullets to kill a hunter. It also means that every hunter with a single-shot weapon is likely to follow the exact same playstyle: tag the target once with a rifle from a distance, and then close in to finish them off with a pistol.Hunt also has several rather interesting weapons. Namely, those are crossbows and, unsurprisingly, they’re my weapon of choice. They’re hard to master but if you manage to do it, you’ll get to wield a frightening weapon and become a deadly, silent stalker.An upper body show with a crossbow will take down any player from up to 47 meters. Sure, you have to consider the bolt’s trajectory, the movement of the player, compensate for the projectile’s arc, and keep in mind that it won’t pierce any surface, but should you hit them, they're either dead or bleeding heavily.There are also variations of the crossbow. One launches explosive bolts that detonate on impact, the other packs a shotgun shell which will trigger after landing a hit, dealing both the bolt and the slug damage and lastly, the not so useful poison crossbow - the less said about this one, the better.Then there are weapons like the , a pistol with a shotgun shell at its core, perfect for close-quarter encounters or when an enemy manages to corner you. Guns like  rifle which is a hybrid of a sniper and a shotgun, more experimental weapons like the ridiculous  or the Mosin-Nagant Avtomat...An if that’s not enough for you, . Almost every weapon has its shortened version meaning that you’ll sacrifice power but it will take less space in your inventory.Some have custom reloading mechanisms , others come with melee weapons attached to them. If you can’t aim with those terrible iron-sights, pick a dead-eye or marksman variant of your favorite weapon and add some proper optics. The options are numerous.What really sticks out like a sore thumb is the game’s performance. With a whole generation of stronger-than-required hardware, I’m struggling to maintain a satisfying framerate in this game without even maxing its graphical settings. And I’m not the only one.Although very rarely, the game will sometimes simply choose not to work. Objects will appear as muddy blocks, placeholders, or fail to load entirely making it impossible to navigate as I keep bumping into the trees, mud hills, random objects, and partially rendered, t-posing monsters.Another minus to the game, even though I appreciate the vagueness when it comes to certain aspects, the game really should improve on team communication. Mainly, the ping system. It’s just bad and needs improvement.Last but not least – the microtransactions.It’s not like you’re forced to get them but the game is obviously made with some of them in mind. Acquisition of legendary items and hunters (basically skins) and additional hunter slots is incredibly slow and I’m pretty sure the microtransactions are to blame. It’s a AA, premium price game with a bunch of paid DLC to it.To be fair, the game does allow for Blood Bounds (the premium resource) to be farmed but the process is incredibly slow.Are youre hardcore macho who values challenge? If you’re not afraid to lose everything and can withold yourself from smashing through your monitor with your macho fists when a game pulls a cheap one at you, consider giving it a try. It may not be perfect but it might be what you're looking for.

reviews.text: Hunt is.. whoo boy.. how do I describe this.. it's a PVP arena shooter with PVE objectives. You search for other players during matchmaking, won't know how many there are. The only things you can influence are "server region" and "Teams of 3 allowed". Normally it's either solo players or duos.Everyone spawns at certain points at the edge of the map and tries to use their special power "Dark Sight" to search for clues on the location of these PVE objectives. At the moment of writing this, there are 3 bosses:The Butcher, the Spider and the AssassinIt takes 3 clues per boss to pinpoint his location (unless you just so happen to be strolling into the boss' building by chance).Your job is: Pick a hunter, buy equipment (both hunter and equipment are lost on death) and try to be sneaky enough to not get murdered from behind by a fellow player. At the same time making sure you are well-enough equipped to take care of whatever boss the game decides to throw at you.If you happen to be the first team at the boss or everyone else has left the playing field one way or another, you can kill the boss and pick up its bounty. Now your final job is extracting that bounty and bringing it home safely. Because here is the catch:As soon as you start banishing the boss after killing it (takes roughly 2 minutes), every other player will know your location, whether they picked up the 3 hints or not. And if you're unlucky, everyone wants a piece of your kill. Since every boss only drops 2 bounties, there are often firefights during banishing where one team tries to remove the competition and it developing into a 2 v 2 v 2 stand-off.But wait.. there's more.. should you manage to defend your kill, picking up the bounty will make you permanently visible on the map for all other players. So now you get to run to an exit with everyone knowing your exact location.Long story short: Hunt is an adrenaline-inducing adventure, sometimes frustrating, sometimes breath-taking. You want to bring your best hunter and guns to make the job easy, but should you get unlucky, that hunter and that gear is permanently lost, leaving you to start from zero with a different hunter anew.There are many moments where you sit in cover, holding your breath, hoping to not get noticed. Others where you are desperate to try and get your character out of a difficult situation by running for your life.It is a challenge, I won't deny that. It definitely isn't for everyone. This is not like other mainstream shooters where you get to respawn and find your killer. If your team is wiped, so is everything you have worked for with that one character.In terms of enjoyment and entertainment I give this game an 8.5/10One thing I should add: This game chugs performance like a mofo. A middle-class or higher gaming PC is advised.Edit:I love this game, but one thing that keeps annoying me: This is now the 3rd 30+ hunter that I lost to server errors. If your game crashes, you get your hunter back. If the server ♥♥♥♥♥ up, you lose everything.

reviews.text: This is by far the most intense multiplayer shooter experience I ever had. And that should be saying something, because I have been playing and reviewing action games professionally for almost 20 years now. I could go into more detail about how perfectly this game is crafted, but that would be wasting precious game time. To cut it short: If you're at all interested in a slow paced, yet high intensity monster hunt where YOU regularly turn out to be the hunted, where every match is different and you still master new techniques even after 750 hours of game time, Hunt: Showdown is for you. Buy it.
