reviews.text: Hunt Showdown has been the best experience I've had with a shooter so far.The game is a pvp & pve stealth game, but it can also be played more fast pace, though the game is designed to be played slower and with a more careful approach, since every small decision or mistake can lead to you being discovered or possibly killed.PROS:+The gunplay is a lot of fun and makes perfect sense for this type of game.The guns feel like they got weight to them, kind of clunky but true to the era.The clunkiness of the weapons also impacts your playstyle and when you decide to shoot, because every shot counts, due to the scarcity of ammo and other ressources and because you might be discovered by other players in your area.+The game design and setting is beautiful, dark and unique.This western setting with monsters and grim lore makes for a perfect pvp survival shooter experience.The map design is smart and beautiful. Every location looks different and has many obstacles and covers where you can hide behind during gunfights. Due to this no gunfight feels the same.+The sounddesign is unlike any other multiplayer shooter game's.You can perfectly estimate distances and directions of shots or footsteps of other players.Every enemy-type makes different sounds when being aggroed, attacked or killed, so if you alert an enemy, other players in the area will surely know.+The Mobs actually pose a threat.Mobs are usually oneshot-kills, except for the bosses, but if you are being attacked by other players in addition to the mobs, you are almost sure to killed. +The perk system is balanced.You can have a maxed out hunter and still be killed by level one hunters who have no perks.The perks are great and make certain things easier for the build you're going for, but they don't make you overpowered.+Recruiting and equiping hunters with weapons and items makes for a fun survival experience.Once your hunter dies on a mission you lose every progress you made with him, which makes the decisions you make feel like they have an impact, and usually you don't just rush enemies, because unlike other shooters you don't respawn instantly after being killed. You have to recruit and equip a new hunter before being able to go on another mission.CONS:-Sometimes mobs just spawn right in front of you, or further away.This takes you out of the experience or could potentially even spook you.-Sometimes the outline of objects don't work.For example, sometimes you will be shooting between two treebranches and the bullet will impact in the air between the two branches because the outline is sometimes not precise, which can be very frustrating when you're engaged in a firefight.-It's hard to recommend the game to friends because the learning curve is incredibly long.I've played the game for 300h  and i still feel like i'm making rookie mistakes.Which is both challenging and annoying at times.CONCLUSION:I can really recommend this game to anyone who likes survival shooters and stealth oriented games.The game is very immersive and dark which no game has pulled off as well as Hunt Showdown, especially since it's a multiplayer game.For anyone looking for a challenging pvp & pve game, this is your game.

reviews.text: I only play as a solo, never on a team (haven't even tried to). In my 65+ hours playing as a solo hunter, I have experienced:I've also had a ton of fun with this game. I primarily farm PvE and only occasionally seek out PvP (though it finds me plenty). I've even managed to take out a couple of two-hunter teams. I'm sure others are like "" but for me that was quite difficult and made for very proud moments. The PvE is fun, and the PvP is also fun.The 1800s firearms are just super duper well done. Reloading animations take forever (as they should with these guns), in a far more realistic way than most FPS games. When I press the button to reload my revolver, the animation is: I hold the gun up, open the loading port, eject the spent casing, load in a fresh bullet, revolve the cylinder and repeat until fully loaded, close the loading port, spin the cylinder, and pull the hammer back. Firing and reloading are just , coming from the perspective that I love these old firearms and enjoy the immersion/realism that goes into their operation in the game. The guns and gun-play are the main things that draw me to the game. I'd love to see a single-player campaign for this, either as content for Showdown or as a separate stand-alone title. I'd play the ever-loving tar out of that too.The sound design in the game is absolutely . Hearing footsteps, broken glass being tread upon, chains rattling, doors opening, etc. all around you is very important. The directional audio is second to none and can help to keep you alive if you are paying attention. Gunshots can be heard from across the map, and each gun (or gun type at least) has it's own sound. You can tell what type of gun someone is using, and approximately how far away they are, and in which direction from the sound that is generated. The hunt is on, and I'm ready to die over and over again in my pursuit of these bounties. Cowboy up, and hunt down some undead.

reviews.text: EDIT 5: More frequent sales, some good events and big streamers playing the game helped it grow a bit. Average concurrent players went up to 9-10k, from 6k. Third map came out way later than it should, but still a great addition. The game is overall better than in 2019. Still recommended. Game is cool, but develops at snail speed.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TL;DR: The game is great, I love it, many love it, but the price tag is off-putting and it never gets popular and well-known. Pricey for a not popular game. It has issues just like any other games, but people play bugged games if they love it anyway. Slow development, updates take long time to come out. Low but decent 6k active playerbase (steamcharts). You can still have fun with it.Review at the time:Here are some thoughts I've already shared in the forums:-I'm a teacher and I have hundreds of teens per semester, NO STUDENT KNOWS ABOUT HUNT. Up to now, I haven't heard ''oh yeah, I know Hunt" as a response to "do you know Hunt: Showdown?" And FPS culture and FPS competitive scene is very strong here in my country (Brazil). -About bugs... a real example: Dead by Daylight has many bugs and issues, delays fixes and quality of life changes, only now will have servers... and people play it. The game costs BRL18 on sales, which are frequent, while Hunt costs BRL90. Both are niche games. Both are innovative. Both have issues. Dead by Daylight capitalizes on skins. People who love your game will buy skins, just like Fortnite, Dota, LoL, and whatever. One good skin in Dead by Daylight costs BRL21, more than the game on sale... On the other hand, Hunt pushes the base price too hard. The price is absurd compared to its popularity, reviews and number of active players. - People need a decent rig to play Hunt, plus a decent account balance to afford it. Not many people will drop BRL90 for a game they haven't ever heard about. EA games are expensive and people buy them because they already have a solid fame and etc, even though they are bugged. People play your bugged game if they love it. But to love it, they must know it first, it's so simple. The Sims DLCs cost more than the base game... All of its DLCs are certainly more than BRL2.000. A nobody like Hunt: Showdown should release at a lower price to attract people. Then after players have put some hours into the game, they WILL be willing to support it and buy the skins and DLC they wish for.-Peak players is higher during Free Weekend than during Lauch, which means the number of people who 'want to play' the game is bigger than the number of people who 'had abandoned' the game. Matches are not always full.-People comment about free games: "It's simple, not a lot of content, but hey, it's free". So yeah, people firstly think about the base price before criticizing anything.-PS.: Graphics are wonderful, impressive job, I don't know why and how can people complain, calling it ugly.Summary: good game, needed more players, but too expensive to attract a bigger number of active players. If more people are trying your game, there will be more people playing and supporting your game.Edit 1: They are trying to lower price now, but game has lost the launch momentum. What a wasted opportunity. Plus are there any ads? We never see the game being advertised. Few new players coming in. It gets a bit tiring to try to be part of it, when it's only going down. Still keeping a thumbs up because of the ''what a phenomenal gaming experience'' moments this game provides.Edit 2: Updates hated by that selective playerbase. By the time I reviewed, it was positive, that's why I'm keeping it that way. But the game WAS a lot of fun, but kept going downhill. What a short lifespan there. That's so sad. RIP.Edit 3: 1 year after 1.0, they put it on 45% sale and launched Twitch Drops. Active players went up a bit by now. But let's see. They took too long to start doing something about price and merchandising.Edit 4: The playerbase somehow kept steady, and the average 6k active players monthly is still there (steamcharts). You can find matches to play, this is enough. BUT game's popularity is still low, not really a well-known game, and it's out for some years, that's disappointing.

reviews.text: Hunt Showdown - was once an awesome and fun game. For the most part, it still is. I really don't want to give this game a thumbs up in its current state, but in saying that, I don't want to give it a thumbs down either. Its a "Love/Hate" relationship. The actual game play is fun as hell most of the time, but with declining players, it becomes stale and boring. The game isn't stable for many players, and the glitches are mounting up. So the ONLY reason I am giving this game a thumbs up is because it has provided me with a lot of fun and joy and I most certainly got my moneys worth. And I do sincerely hope that this game will continue to grow and be great someday. But it does need a LOT of work. A LOT. And of course, it needs more players. The game is definitely very unique. Its one of the best PvP/PvE games I have played in a very long time. They have this awesome idea and style. They just need to focus, fix the issues, add more content. Perhaps even have a DOUBLE XP weekend from time to time to help draw players back. Many games do this. And they need to do some proper marketing. I guess Pros & Cons can be listed below.Pros- Improved performance (however I just recently got a new PC so that could be that reason for this).- Game is fun to play, and anything can happen in any match.- Legendary Hunters/Legendary Weapons are fun to work toward owning them some day.- Female Hunters - however they need to work on a balance because it seems like there are more females than males to choose from. Perhaps adding a "Gender Preference" so that when you shuffle them for hire, you get more of what you want.- Money is easy enough to make- Choice to choose a money bonus or XP boost each time you prestige- Blood Bonds. Gives you something to work toward.- Bosses are more difficult which is good.- Changes in the compound. More ways to approach a compound, more entry points, more ladders etc. - Timer increased to 30 seconds from 20 seconds. It adds tension and can lead to a possible shootout. Bad side though, have seen more extraction point campers since this update.Cons- Trio matches. I do find the option good, however, I find that it splits the player base. Most people who solo or duo will likely have the Trio selection set to "OFF" so without a big player base, you will find more servers empty. For both the Trio groups and for ones that solo or play in Duo. - No Custom Lobby and to learn that Crytek don't see this as a priority. Come on, it would be awesome fun to play with friends. One vs One or as a team against your own friends. Give us the custom lobby. Its one of the main things the community looked forward to.- Graphics downgrade and thinning of the trees etc. The graphics is nothing to what it was back when it was in Early Access. As time went by, they thinned the trees to a point that you could see from one compound right into another. Outside of Slaughterhouse was filled with bushes, so you could ambush players or even hide from them if you didn't feel confident enough to take them on for what ever reason. But all that is gone now. - Only has two maps. And its becoming very stale seeing the same scenery. Crytek need to think about bringing more maps out to keep the game interesting. Playing the same maps over and over, people learn every crack in a wall. - clues need to be more randomised.- Adding the red glow and humming to clues killed the immersion too. It was meant to stop people from clue camping but it did the opposite. And half the fun was also to go to a clue without knowing someone can be around. But now? The red glow or humming alerts you right away. That just kills the fun. Even if you wanted to follow the enemy and strike an ambush, that gets tossed out the window due to this retarded mechanism. REMOVE it for pete's sake!- Prestiging feels less rewarding and feels more like a punishment. Due to the new weapons  & consumable/tools unlock system, it just feels more tedious than it really has to be. Why force players into using items just to unlock the one they really want? Why should i spend money and throw little dynamite sticks if i ever want to unlock a big bundle? Why should i be forced to use a certain base weapon if i want to some day unlock the better varient? It worked fine the way it was before. You unlock it once you reach the appropriate level. So if I want to use Mosin Nagant Bayonet I need to get XP with the non Bayonet version first. Etc. If i want to use Concertina, I have to unlock multiple different things before i can use it. Before full release, it was made available at level 30. It seems like such an extra grind. And when you can prestige relatively quickly, all this unlocking seems pointless and a waste of time. - DLCs are now sold seperately and not as a bundle. And the legendary hunter, particularly the Phantom has some serious clipping issues. - Server instability and Mission Bag Summary that seem to reoccur frequently, where you receive no XP, no Money, no kills. Nothing. But if you die, that still counts. So that can totally wreck with your K:D- Empty servers because the player base is dropping so rapidly - Changes to the male sound files. They were fine the way they were. We want our unigue original Male death screams back.- female voices sound like porn stars when they're injured. Rethink these and maybe change them to sound like they're more in pain than in ecstacy. Just saying.- More Boss additions. - Monster Book / Weapon book seems to glitch. I think it needs to be re-looked at.- Player footsteps are way over loud and drowns out just about every other sound.- Adding heaving breathing sounds to your player when they point a gun wasn't the best idea. Now you can hear enemies way too easy. Even their sneaking sounds are over amplified that i can hear them down the opposite end of the hall. Was this intentional? The overall sounds in this game don't seem to be working too well in general. Some sounds are also cut out entirely. For example. Partner hears gunfire in the distance. For me, I heard nothing. If i creep closer to where my partner was and they fire shots again, THIS time I heard it. I am sure there are others to add, but i will leave it here. I really wanted to give this game in its current state a THUMBS down. But I will give it a Thumbs Up because it is overall, despite all its short comings, a fun game to play.EDIT: After 3 years... the server issues are still a huge problem. Seriously getting fed up when you play a decent match ONLY for the game to freeze and close off with the "Send Error Report" and its happening to other people. How about you fix this issue because seriously, I am getting ticked off with the amount of hunters I have lost due to server issues, among OTHER mounting glitches. And not to mention, 3+ years and still waiting for another map. Finally have another boss, and that's all sweet and dandy, but come on Crytek. MORE maps and how about those custom servers you promised us for years. Why is this put aside for the 2nd or 3rd time now.PS: And maybe look into your so-called anti-cheat while you're at it because I have come across an increase number of VERY suspicious players and its beginning to be very off-putting and the lack of interest from this company is beginning to disgust me.UPDATED: Finally have a third map and its a real fun one. A thumbs up from me for this one.

reviews.text: You're running the gauntlet, gleefully leaving a macabre series of killings behind; you have two partners watching your back, after all. Once the dust settles, the seemingly empty marshland grows ominously silent, and... BANG! The piercing whistle of bullets shrill through your mates' skulls. Both are taking a dirt nap as you wade through the knee-deep swamp water now with only a quarter of your hard-earned bounty, holding on to your dear, almost empty health bar. Facing the same fate as your crew, all that terror you went through, now a fading memory. Very soon you will be too.You'll die, paying the price for shattering the peace in the bayou. You don't win. Best-case scenario, you live to die another day.Blending the competitive forays of Battle Royales with horror-themed cooperative bounty hunting,  comes out on top as the prime example of an engrossing multiplayer experience. It requires your utmost attention. Analyze closely and always think a few steps ahead, as if you're playing chess against a grandmaster. You might have your moments, but doing so is no easy feat.You, a patron to a "Bloodline" of voodoo bounty hunters, have been summoned to the plagued swamps of Louisiana in the late 19th century. Using the Dark Sight to search for clues around three generously-sized maps, your task is to banish the nastiest of those creatures back to hell and escape with bounties in hand. From garden-variety zombies to demonic mutants, all manners of menacing beasts are found along the way. Be it old hags spewing out swarms of poisonous bees from their chest, or charred immolators bursting out in flames if their skin is pierced.But, none are the stout challenge you'd be looking for. Not even the bosses. An elusive assassin, a nimble wall-crawling spider, and a bulky butcher with a flaming hook, all three seem to be formidable opponents, though, against seasoned huntsmen, they don’t require much strategic thinking to take down. Frankly, every hunter of the bayou regards these targets as tertiary, their heads will not make for proud cabin trophies.That bounty you happily took after killing the boss is the start of pure bloodlust. It's a "put a bullet in me" beacon, visible on the map, while also boosting your magic with a wallhack of some sort for mere seconds. As up to eleven other sweaty, try-hard hunters are racing to your location, it's up to you whether to put up a fight or madly dash through the muck to an extraction point.It feels like an insoluble dilemma, given that death lurks about these festering lands. If your hunters go down, after the initial grace period, they’re taking all of their equipment and upgrades with them. While frustrating at first, the immense tension a permanent death causes, however punishing, keeps you on your toes at all times. The fear of losing hours of work in the blink of an eye makes the competitive, if mostly sluggish, nature of the encounters all the more thrilling.Money is found sparsely throughout the world, while hefty sums are given at the end of each session, which is used for recruiting hunters and gearing them up. XP on the other hand, varying on the number of killed baddies and extracted bounties, converts to upgrade points and contributes to the overall Bloodline ranks—a natural progression system to simply show what item unlocks next.You may think once tapped out, you'll be hitting a wall. But no. You can always fall back on a gratis, low-tier hunter. Or perhaps, take your chances in the Quickplay, a free-for-all, last-man-standing take on the bounty hunting mode. Your starting options are narrowed to random weapons, but powerful ones are dotted around the map for the taking. Survive the ordeal, and you have a custom-made cowboy with choice gear and abilities that free ones don't come with.Naturally, the guns of the era are slow to shoot and painful to reload. Having an itchy trigger finger is a sure way to kiss the dust. From puny six-shooters to shotguns and big-bore rifles, with several interesting ammo types per each, all are nonetheless capable of dropping enemies with a shot to the head or upper torso—unlike a good number of frivolous shooters. With that, anything is a death-blower in the right hands, turning each gunfight into one hell of a methodical showdown. A few widely accessible spam guns on the offer may be detrimental to the gameplay, but overall, the balancing is spot-on.However, should you see firearms as the weapon of last resort, your chances of survival will increase fourfold. The pitch-perfect binaural audio design urges you to stay as quiet as possible. Shot a gun? Somebody across the map heard it and can tell what gun you're using. Creeping up on foes caught up in a boss fight? Footsteps, even when crouched, are noticeable and distinguishably varied over different types of ground. Ears pricked for the proximity chat,  gets even more unnerving when other hunters acknowledge your presence. You turn back... but get a flying sledgehammer in the face.Seeing that you'll be spending most of your time sneaking around, understanding how and when to use the tools and traps is of the essence. Yeah, a big bundle of dynamite is scary, but is it scarier than getting flushed out with its decoy just to have your face blasted off with an exploding crossbow bolt? I didn't think so. Makeshift bombs give you an edge in the fights, while consumables ensure your longevity. Another asset to your advantage—or disadvantage—is the ambient alarm systems. Like a startled flock of crows that can easily give away the location of who jumped them. Or the grating noise of all creatures when agitated, from the undead to crippled horses and caged dogs. Most of my kills were obtained by carefully listening for clumsy movements.As you patiently traverse the fetid southern landscape, it's impossible to tear your gaze away from its grotesque beauty; atmospheric and vivid, with excellent lighting, you can almost feel the heat of the sun through the screen, yet a gritty feeling of despair clings to this zombie-infested old-west. That beauty puts a strain on the GPU as it does on the nerves. My  run the game in agony on a fluctuating 40-ish FPS with graphics set to the lowest. As the VRAM usage exceeds the limit, texture flickering becomes a deal-breaker, though that's a pain known only to low-end users.That said, there are a few technical drawbacks on the servers' side, too. While disconnections are few and far between, you can still lose your cherished cowboy when thrown out of the match. Compared to other games, desync and trading kills are taken to the extreme here. I have lost count on how many times I've shot a player down only to get killed by his dead self, lying cold on the ground, seconds later. It also makes navigating and climbing narrow spaces, namely ledges and stairs, a bit irritating as the subpar net coding often tries to correct my position between the client and the server.Ears ringing from all the gunshots, heart pounding out the chest, and hands trembling uncontrollably;  makes me feel alive and fight like there is no tomorrow. Unforgiving. Strenuous. Tense. An experience like no other. I think I need a smoke or three.

reviews.text: Hunt: Showdown is easily the best "BR-like" game there is at the moment. That is the simplest way to put it. Even if you heavily dislike BRs, which I do, Hunt may still be something that grabs your interest.Some standout points that make this game great:1. The Setting - With the aid of the CryEngine, the setting is the best realized and most cohesive setting out there. Set in 1895 in Louisiana, the game is dripping with atmosphere. Everything is appropriately dark and twisted looking to sell the horror and keeps you unsettled. The monsters are visually well designed and look great, the aesthetic of the hunters and their weapons is great, lots of classic "cowboy" weapons and then lots of fun, makeshift gadgets to help keep the game fresh.2. PvPvE - Every map is filled with zombies and other creatures, the ultimate goal is to find a boss monster spawned randomly on the map, kill it, and then take the "tokens" it leaves to an extraction and get out alive. Each individual hunter you bring into a mission has one life, die and you lose the equipment you brought and any perks the hunter may have earned in previous games. While this sounds very punishing, and it was early on in the game's life, the economy and rewards have been adjusted to account for this. One or two wins will often leave nearly halfway to max level for a hunter, similarly a single win can often earn you enough money to outfit your hunter with decent equipment for a couple of games. The lack of a mad scamble beginning where you are relying on RNG for good weapons makes the beginning of a match much more tense. That great loadout you brought is also at risk of being gone forever if you make a sloppy mistake and get mobbed by zombies or fall to an ambush from an enemy team.3. Small scale - Lots of people think "OMG WE NEED 100 PLAYERS IN EVERY GAME". Hunt completely goes against this and it's much to the game's benefit. 10 player max right now, though 1.0 release will raise this to 12 (and add the ability for teams of 3, right now it's duo or solo only). That's 5 teams for duos, this means that the reasonably sized map is not crawling with enemy players. THIS IS GOOD. It keeps the tension of "there probably isn't anybody nearby, but there could be". Due to this, and old time weapons that are slow to shoot and reload, Hunt has a very deliberate pacing with an almost stealth game feel to it. If you know there is a team in a compound and you can get into position without triggering any zombies, sound traps (birds, dying horses, kennels with dogs, chicken coops, broken glass, hanging chains, etc) you will be able to have a proper ambush and that advantage will help you win a lot more.Bounty Hunt is the main "Hunt Experience" with perma-death, hunting for your contract target which will be one of three "boss" monsters. A large spider (that actually acts like and moves around like a spider), a giant zombie with a severed pig's head that is an unstoppable behemoth, and the shadowy assassin that clones itself and dissolves into a swarm of insects as it moves around. Hunters are dead forever if you lose but the experience is incredibly rewarding when you fight your way through hordes of zombies, several enemy hunters, kill and banish the boss monster back to hell, and then escape at any extraction point on the map. If you are worried about perma-death being too punishing, Crytek has introduced a lot of new features to help even out the difficulty curve here. For example: If you like your current hunter a lot and have good weapons but are in a bad spot (perhaps you have no HP left or are just not confident in trying to steal the bounty from a team that already grabbed it) you do not have to be "the last one standing", you can leave at any time at any of the extraction points that are marked around the map. You'll earn money for every clue you gathered (about the boss location), as well as XP for any zombies and players you killed. You can play quickplay instead of Bounty Hunt. Quickplay is solo only and is more like traditional BR. While there is no circle, your hunter is free and you find weapons in the round. The goal is to find four clues first and it will activate the "well spring" which is the game's timer. It starts with 450 seconds on the clock and once you grab it, it starts filling energy for you. Each second of energy = $1 of hunt money. When the timer hits 0, whoever is holding the wellspring will "save their soul" and the others are damned and engulfed in flame. So here there can only be one winner but you do not use your hunter, you use a new one each game. If you survive, you can recruit the hunter you escaped with for FREE and he gets all the weapons and XP he earned from the quickplay round. This makes quickplay a great place, even if you die, to earn money with no risk. Just playing it a few times can recoup several Bounty Hunt losses. There is also a training period where your hunters will "cheat death" in Bounty Hunt until your bloodline (your overall player account level, this never goes down and is not tied to hunters, it unlocks weapons for you to purchase) level is 16. So you will have some time to adjust. And even then, after every game you can generate a new batch of four hunters to recruit and you will always have a low level hunter that you can recruit for free who will have poor weapons and no perks. This is a great way to keep costs down from losses. There's a lot to this game and it's quite the unique experience. It's most definitely worth playing for anyone even kind of interested in a more unique shooter experience.

reviews.text: With the realise of 1.0 the Devs decided to completely change many aspects of the game. One of the initial biggest attractions for many people to Hunt was the fact that the game had a dark, gritty look which was also echoed in the tough, unforgiving nature of the game. It was a slow, tactical game which could burst into action at any moment, whether it be PvP action or you just accidentally wandered in to the middle of a pack of Hellhounds and the resulting noise attracted everything in the vicinity. Unfortunately 1.0 changes a lot of these The graphics are nowhere near as clear or consistent as they were at launch, they have upped the lighting to the point where the once pitch black night is not dark at all. They have reduced the LOD so much that texture pop-ins happen all the time, this is really off putting in a stealth game when you are looking for enemies in the distance in trees/bushes.Up until 1.0 aiming in Hunt was a two step process, One button to bring your gun up into hipfire stance then another button press to bring you into ADS stance. This, along with some pretty severe weapon sway meant that gunfights in Hunt used to require a great deal of skill. Even people with incredible aim couldn't just one tap everyone from anywhere. It meant fights on average lasted longer than other FPS games and this required players to be more than just a 'Good Shot' in engagements, flanking, retreating and re-engaging, using decoys or even triggering AI to help you win fights all happened frequently. However the introduction of 'Gunslinger' mode allows players to bypass the two stage aiming system, with Gunslinger the player is always in hipfire stance, meaning they have an advantage on anyone not using Gunslinger as they only have to press one button to shoot instead of two, and although the Devs claim there is a disadvantage to using Gunslinger I have yet to see where any disadvantage lies. The removal of the weapon sway has meant that anyone with halfway decent aim can get headshots quite easily, both of these changes have reduced the skill ceiling whilst also reducing the average length of gunfights which in turn has seen a reduction in the need to flank etc. This has imo made the game a little boring. If I wanted insanely accurate guns and fast gunfights I wouldn't be playing a game like Hunt as there are so many other games that allow me to play that way easier and with more enjoyment and variance.  They also decided to add a 3d pinging system, it feels so out of place in the game it's ridiculous. I realise they wanted a way for random teams to communicate without using in game VOIP but instead of having the mark only appear on the compass they make it 3d, reducing a huge skill in the game which was being able to quickly and accurately describe the location of an enemy.As far as I'm concerned the Devs have spent over a year and a half making a game that caters to the audience that initially bought the game and supported it an audience that loved the slow paced, stealth and tactical heavy requirements, only for them to turn around and slap those supporters in the face by springing a dumbed down, easier to play and more accessible to the average player version of the game just before full launch. It reeks of a lack of confidence in the original concept and gameplay and stinks of a company who are struggling financially screwing over those that where there when needed in order to chase that mainstream cash. I've been eagerly awaiting the full release of this game for nearly 2 years and I couldn't be more disappointed in the outcome.Edit to add: I didn't realise that 1.0 increased the price to £36 for the little content in this game (two maps, 3 Bosses) it really isn't worth it with that price point.

reviews.text: I don't usually write reviews for games, but saying that Hunt: Showdown is worthy of the time spent here is an understatement. Hunt is a tense, immersive, adrenaline-pumping first person bounty hunting game with a classic western 19th century setting. Without further ado, lets break it down.Immersion is usually chalked up to be a marketing buzz word employed by game development companies to describe a rich world with detail and accurate elements of life.The belief that something could be real is exponentially more captivating than reality itself. Daily life is all too familiar, while fantasy is outlandish. Blend the two and you get Hunt's immersive element. The true to life weaponry, realistic movement, and fantastic sound design are the main life-like elements of Hunt, while grotesque monsters and hellish dark powers bring something exciting to the table. These two halves make an amazing whole that keeps you interested in the world of Hunt.From rugged revolvers to repeaters and rending shotguns, Hunt has something for every situation. Sprinkled in are surprises like the Bomb Lance, a harpoon style weapon with a massive fixed blade and spring loaded explosive harpoons. Snipers like the prairie rifle Sparks LRR and time tested Mosin have scoped options for extreme range. Recently added dual wielding allows you take a matched pair of your favorite sidearms for the ultimate gunslinging experience. Unique throwables like bundled sticks of dynamite, firebombs, barbed wire cages, and even nasty hive bug bombs that chase down and poison your enemies. Maybe you fancy a double barrel shotgun? How about dual silenced revolvers and a silent rifle for some sneaky runs? Hunt has it all. Try everything and find what works best. The AI elements of Hunt are not to be underestimated. Most games with extra enemies will spawn the equivalent of trash mobs, posing little threat to the mission. Forget steamrolling through PVE. Massive meatheads with hooks guard clues in various locations. Fiery immolator demons run at Usain Bolt speed and can explode if shot or sliced by sharp weapons. Hive abominations are transformed women that have their rib cage erupted and heads nearly detached from their body, now inhabited by swarms of poisonous bugs that track and prevent their target from healing. The bosses are pure hell spawn and are just as gross as the rest. A gigantic spider warped from a human's body lurks in the dark, waiting to pounce and sink its massive teeth into an unsuspecting hunter. The Butcher lumbers about, shaking the ground as he stomps towards hunters with a fiery meat hook and disgusting leeches poking from his pig head and body. Lastly, the Assassin transforms from a swarm of bugs to a tall human-like figure, with long knives coming out of its wrists. The enemies in Hunt will keep you engaged at all times. Be prepared and bring lots of healing!In Hunt, you have one main objective; extract with the bounty from the banished monster(s). This is accomplished by using a special power called dark sight to locate clues scattered around the map. Once you have located three clues, the bounty target location will be marked precisely on your map. You do not need clues to find the bounty target, as you may stumble upon them by luck or other means, but clues are the consistent way to do so. Once you have your location, you must go and kill the monster target at said location. After death, the monster needs to be banished. Banishing takes time and marks the location on the map for all players to see, so set up and hold your ground! After banishing, grab the bounty from the dead monster and head for extraction. Dark sight is a provisionary measure that will allow bounty holders to see other hunters in a 150 meter range for a limited time, due to the fact that non carriers can see hunters in dark sight with lightning above their heads. Be quick and get out on time! Other teams of hunters will be trying to accomplish the same goal, whether it be a two boss map or just one. Matches are never the same and different hunters and weapons make the gameplay very engaging, as you will want to improve constantly. You can play solo, duos, or trios, but there is no dedicated solo mode, which means at the very least you will be fighting duos if you go solo in Bounty Hunt. Quickplay, a solo mode that has you save a damned hunter for a chance for free equipment, and Trials, as well as tutorials, are all available for your perusal. One final note, you will notice that sound is your friend. Use it. - Some GuyFrom the above sections of the review, you can probably gather that I enjoy this game. No game is perfect, however, and this wouldn't be a proper review without recognizing the flaws of this product. The main issues with Hunt can be summed up into three things:This game is hard on new players, without a doubt. Hunt has a smaller community made up of a lot of experienced players. In the beginning, expect to die a decent amount, especially if you try to play solo in Bounty Hunt and Quickplay (Quickplay is solo only). I recommend finding people or friends to play with to increase your chances of survival. The Official Hunt: Showdown Discord is a great place to start. I'll link them below for your convenience. The User Interface of Hunt is also quite an annoyance at times, with many different ways to sort for weapons and blood bonds being a thing can be confusing. Watching any Hunt YouTuber will help understand the workings of the UI a bit better, especially if you're confused about Blood Bonds. Finally, the ping issues can happen from time to time and other related disconnects are uncommon, but present. Make sure you select the right regions for playing!First off, if you've made it this far, I applaud you. This is quite a long review and I thank you for reading through it. Secondly, take everything above with a grain of salt. You won't truly know if you enjoy the game without actually giving it a try. Now that we have that out of the way, lets finish this up. Hunt is unlike any First Person Shooter I've played in a long time. I am always looking for something new to shake up the genre and Hunt does just that. Fantastic gameplay and a truly immersive world has kept me going for 300 hours and I plan to sink many more into it. Hunt is criminally underrated in my personal opinion and offers a lot for the price tag. I hope to see you in the Bayou, hunter!

reviews.text: It's been a while since Ryse: Son of Rome, the last AAA Crytek-developed game I played. I am also familiar with their Crysis franchise. I was glad to read the news on a western-themed FPS software. I found it interesting that instead of the story this game would be focusing on multiplayer. It's been 3 years since Hunt Showdown was released (originally under the early access concept) and new content has been added ever since. With a friend or 2 (or alone if we're brave enough) our job is to look for clues in a huge map. A special visibility mode helps with the search. The aim here is to find information on a boss (or 2 bosses) that are considered the bounties during our match. Once the boss is found we, naturally, have to eliminate it. These are monsters - terrifying, otherwordly creatures - that hide inside a large building. As the 2nd stage is done we begin banishing the vanquished creature. Consider it an automatically applied spell that takes some time and we have to remain in position. After that we can pick up our well-deserved bounty and go to one of the extraction points that are randomly chosen.Interesting, right? This is the PvE part of the game but it is PvP as other hunters also look for the same bounty. It is my understanding that matches support up to 12 players. It can be very annoying when you finally eliminate the boss and then you're suddenly shot down. Or during extraction (there is a timer of 30 seconds here) you are killed before taking home your well-deserved reward.The setting may be the late 1800s but not your usual one. The story takes place in Louisiana so expect a lot of swamps with trees and - most importantly - otherwordly creatures. There are grunts (living dead but often with melee weapons), armored grunts, hell hounds, zombies on fire (immolators), undead releasing swarms of insects at you from a distance (hives) and even the devil (?) is trying to get you in the water if you are not careful. As if all had come from a Lucio Fulci classic.The sound design is superb in this game be it your steps or the noises an enemy makes. You need to be careful when moving around - stepping on broken glasses just after entering a building or bumping your head into a bunch of hanging horseshoes can all be giveaways. I have played every single match with my headset on and it was worth it. Interestingly, ingame voice chat when used can also be heard if other players are close. People use Discord or Steam's built-in version instead.Consider them your heroes. You have some already available but more can be recruited for money. They level up individually as you complete matches but your profile also has ranks. Higher ranks unlock more traits (abilities) that you can assign to your hunters as well as new weapons. Remember, this is the Wild West (or South...) so expect to reload after every single shot. This is not running and gunning like in a Call of Duty game. A dinamite takes much longer to explode than a grenade. Oh, dinamites. There are a lot of throwables, traps, even several choices for melee weapons. The DLCs here mean purely cosmetic items (better skins for the afore-mentioned). Legendary heroes are a bit different - beside the cosmetic aspect (they look unique) and the short bio they come with these hunters have randomly assigned traits. They can come handy at the beginning but they will never have weapons on them.I'm based in Europe but I picked US East Coast as the secondary location for matches. Often one is found in the second group only. In general, finding matches takes long. If there is just one boss players hardly advance to find clues but instead camp out and wait for you. The game resurrects your hunters until you reach rank 11. It warns you that after that your hunters will perish forever. The legendary ones (DLC) you can always buy again but every time they start out as level 1. So, you lose all traits and all weapons. Why from rank 11? If you complete a match and die you only get half the XP. Two groups of people will never level up at the same speed following the same number of matches. When you get shot you see your enemy was a level 1 hunter, for instance. But before moving onto spectating you can check the other players' profiles. They may be level 1 but the statistical data shown to you is surprising (and disappointing): dozens or even hundreds of bosses or duo groups eliminated already and dozens of hunters retired (advisable once your hunter has reached the max level). As you can see from the above the game is extremely unforgiving. Beginners (or noobs in the vocabulary of some) are punished if mistakes are made. I always spectate and check the other players - I usually see players with ranks between 60 and 100. No newcomers? It's been 3 years and a 3rd map is about to be released and really we have a small playerbase consisting of veterans mostly? You can pick the "skill-based" option before starting matchmaking but if the other player has played hundreds of hours already he is better with the same level 1 hunter. Not to mention the kind of gear available for them already. The pop-up message can say we are equally based but, in fact, this is not true, at all.Apart from the above the game is gorgeous. The atmosphere is unique and it makes absolute no sense playing it without a headset on. It is unfortunate that matchmaking has issues, that the game is harsh to newcomers and that beside the usual bountyhunting there is only one other game mode available which puts emphasis on solo play. With the track record of some great story-based games I wish Crytek added a single player mode. I recommend the game due to its unique atmosphere and slow-paced gameplay style but you have to remember I'm (still) at the very beginning while I have so far invested 20 hours. This is not a "easy to learn, hard to master" type of game if that is what you're looking for. The score in particular is great in the main menu!

reviews.text: I would recommend this game in its current state for full price. In two days I've played 20 hours and I don't see myself getting bored anytime soon.The meta has so many layers to it. There are a bunch of ways you can choose to play depending on your playstyle, and the permanent death of your characters leads to a much more realistic suspense. You progress your character through playing missions, and if you die at any point, you must start with a new character and equipment. You can choose to steal other people's guns in game and permanently keep them. The missions aren't to kill the other players, but rather to kill the bounty(s), banish them (wait a few minutes until you can collect the bounty token), and extract with the bounty token(s) at one of the extraction points. The further you progress, the more information other players know about you, and the riskier the situation gets. You never know how many people are left, and chances are if you have a bounty token, they are coming to kill you to steal it. If you aren't confident that you can win, you can extract at any time to save your bounty hunter. All these gameplay aspects lead to very interesting dynamics. Are we the last ones left? Should we extract with this one bounty or should we go for the second? Are people gonna ambush us when we go to extraction? Am I making too much noise?Buy the game.

reviews.text: - Hunt: Showdown is an  (the official title) Here are my thoughts after 12+ hours of ups and downs with it.Hunt: Showdown is a game where your task is to recruit bounty hunters, take them into bounty hunt missions, come back from the missions alive, gear up and do it again. There is some unknown epidemic affecting the living deep in the Louisiana bayous and you’re sent there to hunt down some tough supernatural demons. During the hunt you encounter these creepy, infested humans and dogs that aren’t friendly towards outsiders. Amongst them are other bounty hunters as well, going for the same target as you.Hunt: Showdown is a pure FPS game, which is the only way to go with a game like this. There are multiple examples of games where the 3rd person view just makes no sense, kills the gameplay and only works as an ‘exploit’. So no, there’s no weird camera angles where you can peek over walls to get an upper hand towards an approaching hunter.You can go on a bounty hunt Solo, Team up with another random bounty hunter or Invite/Join one of your Steam friend. The game has an in-built VOIP system which works rather nicely. The distance between you and the other person determines how loud your voice can be heard. Everyone can hear you if they’re close enough, so keep that in mind if you’re trying to avoid the attention of other hunters. Even the chat has a radius too, so prepare for some hilarious “OMG, I think he’s near us. I can hear his footsteps.” Comments every now and then. Or the classis “I told you so.” When you shoot someone, and leave his buddy alive.Every time you go out, your main task is to find clues from your bounty’s location. The bounty hunters have a supernatural skill called dark sight, that helps you with a general direction of these clues. After finding a clue, the highlighted area in your map decreases until finally you get a red marker showing where the target is.And since you’re not the only one in the hunt, prepare for some conflicts; silly wabbits camping in the bushes, interrupted boss fights, stolen bounties or just a random friendly winchester slug in your forehead – just because. Greed and glory.The year is 1895 and your bounty hunters are armed with winchesters, revolvers and shotguns from that era. When you recruit a new hunter, you get a list of four random bounty hunters with various weapons, equipment and traits – the better one’s cost a bit more. You can have max 5 hunters in your roster same time and their price ranges between 50 to 150 dollars. You are then free to equip your hunters with whatever gear you choose, just keeping in mind that if the hunt isn’t going well and your hunter might not come back, you’ll lose him and all his juicy equipment permanently. Luckily basic firearms cost around 4-15 dollars, so there rarely is a point where you can’t  afford to gear up your guys. After a hunt ends, you are scored with experience points and money according to your actions in the hunt. Every monster, hunter, boss kill, collected clue etc. rewards points in both categories. If you die in the middle of a hunt, you only get half of the rewards.With these experience points you level up your total profile level and hunter’s personal level. Profile levels unlock more weapons and equipment in the hunter store, where hunter’s level determines how many upgrade points he has for health and various trait boosts.As I’m writing this (24th Feb 2018) you can’t pick up any firearms (only melee weapons like hammers, axes etc) when you’re in a hunt. There is no corpse looting (player or npc). Map is full of randomly scattered supply points, healing kits and weapon storages to keep you going, though trigger happy hunters might face a hard time when the ammo count eventually runs low.The main selling point here to me is the balance between PvE and PvP. Fighting the monsters is great, but there’s always that sense of danger looming in the background, knowing you’re not the only one in the Hunt, keeping you on your toes. Should you shoot these foul creatures, maybe try avoiding them all together or use a machete and avoid drawing too much attention?The main idea here is not the PvP combat, but it is a BIG chunk of the experience and definitely adds some thrill and excitement to the monster hunt. The sounds play a big part in the game: the sounds of scared crows, distant gun shots, footsteps, water splashes, broken glass, metal chains hanging on walls and ceiling, a pack of barking dogs in a kennel or spooked chickens in a coop – just by listening carefully you known a lot what’s happening around you. (Hearing impaired? Sadly there are no indicators or HUD symbols to turn on from the options, but who knows… Maybe at some point.)It is possible to try avoiding conflicts with other players completely, gather some clues, maybe bash few creepy monster heads in, then extract from the mission with your hunter still alive. You don’t HAVE TO kill the bounty target and deliver the bounty to extraction every time. As I’m writing this, there’s currently only one (rather big) map available in game, with two different bounties to hunt. You can choose a day light or night time hunt, which ever suits your playstyle better. There’s few hiccups here and there like in any Early Access title and the dev team keeps updating us very often about the situation (server reboots, maintenance etc.)I read that there are no plans of account wipes or resets during the further developement (unless some major update or bug prevents bringing the current savegames/profiles to the release version) so your current progress from Early Access stays to the full game.--I have enjoyed the game throughly, even when I lose my favorite hunters by some stupid error or just because I got played. I've been doing solo runs, even some very succesfull ones where I manage to take down multiple hunters and deliver the bounty back too. Teaming up with random hunters is nice too, though I still think the game is at it's best when playing with friends.Very entertaining, has HUGE potential and I'll gladly wait for some new maps and new hunts!

reviews.text: The Bayou is home to a peaceful community of people stricken with a mysterious disease. You, along with other players, will break an important quarantine, self-imposed by the citizens of the region, in order to massacre not only them, but each other as well, bringing chaos, mayhem, and ruthless violence to aggravate these poor people even further.You can tread the corpses of your victims on your own, or invite friends to tag along in your gruesome rampage, as you hunt the bounties put on the most beloved community leaders of Stillwater Bayou and Lawson Delta. You can customize your loadout so that the weapons of your preference are available to inflict pain and losses to the inhabitants of Louisiana's marshes.The more you murder, the better you become at it, as long as you leave these zones with impunity. If your sins are left unpunished by the environment or by other players, you famously 'live to die another day', which means only God Himself will strike you down with the mighty hand of vengeance.You can purchase legendary characters with in-game currency, or through DLC. These are the typical characters you would expect to find on the Deep South of the US in the 19th Century, such as a Japanese samurai, a dead guy, or even a monstrous man who covers his shame of being a lawyer with the mask from the Phantom of the Opera. One can't help but feel that a game with a perk named 'Tomahawk' is lacking some types of playable characters. Yet I can't put my finger on it.All in all, this is a perfect game for terrible people like myself: filthy rats who will stalk somebody who honestly spent their time killing a boss, only to stab them in the back and steal the bounty away. If you can handle this, and the high adrenaline rush after several minutes of quiet, then this is the game for you. The feeling of triumph after a victory, whether hard-earned or sly and malicious, tastes sweet all the same.

reviews.text: A fantastic and strange Player vs Player vs Enemy battle-royale-inspired game set in a lovecraftian late-19th century Louisiana. Hunt: Showdown is hard to grasp in the first few matches, but once it clicks, this game is one of the most tense but fair experiences I've had in a game. The way the game incorporates binaural sound as a primary game mechanic is fantastic. You KNOW someone is coming if they stumble on some crows or run over glass, and can pinpoint exactly where they are just by sound alone. Hunt reminds me a lot of Rainbow Six: Siege, but a lot more fair. Staking out a bounty while everyone is bearing down on you is intense and awesome, and you can easily figure out where enemies are coming from just by sound. However, just because you get one shot off doesn't guarantee a kill.I do have some minor gripes with the game. Even with these issues, this game is an easy recommendation as long as you're okay with lots of lethality and are into more niche multiplayer games. I'm definitely going to put a lot more hours into this one

My best friend started playing with me, even though our rigs were very similar and the performance we got out of them was laughable. But we still played. He fell in love with the game just as much as i did. Not long after that we invested in upgrading our pc's mainly for Hunt: Showdown. We're no way near close being die-hard competitive players, even with nearly 800 hours in I'm only rank 596 while he's 496, we play for fun but our ultimate goal is to win. We joke around a lot, try ridiculous things as well as try to befriend other players, share our bounties and generally be nice to other players. Which sometimes bites us in the ass. But we have fun. We always have fun, each match. I haven't enjoyed a game like this in a while, Hunt has given me a lot of great time, the atmosphere in this game is unreal. No game manages to get my heart beating like Hunt does. The thrill of hunting other players and the uncertainty of not knowing if another player is currently watching all your moves gives me quite a rush. I would play this game nearly everyday, i wouldn't play anything else besides Hunt. I took a bit of a break from Hunt after some 700 hours. Not because i didn't enjoy it, but because i also wanted to play something less challenging, something that wasn't as punishing and unforgiving. Came back to this game couple days ago and the game still feels great. Crytek, i will always recommend this game. I will always try to support it. You guys do an amazing job with this game.Some might say your decisions aren't in the best interest for the die-hard fans of this game, and though i might agree with some of those statements, no one can deny the fact that you guys put serious effort into this game. It is hard to satisfy the wishes of the whole community, but you're doing great. Keep on with the amazing work.

reviews.text: Great game. Love it.PROS:Awesome PvP. Well tweaked gunplay. Lot of single action guns. Throwables matter. Ammo runs out. Great headshot multiplier. One shot kill. Good risk vs gain ratio for expensive guns.Awesome PvE. Scary monsters. Satisfactory kills . Great sound. Makes game very atmospheric. Various weakspots on various enemies. If you walk into a pack of 4 hellhounds at night you dead. Some monsters cause bleeding, some burning that can permanently reduce your health. Some give poison.Great map. Shame it's only one. I expect this game to have at lest 4 like this one at launch and more gradually added further down the line when the rest is finished.However it is large and detailed and varied enough that in some 40 hours I am not bored yet. Far from. And you get it in version night and day.From what I have seen so far, every single object piece was designed with thought, care, lots of easter eggs. Great places designed for gunfights and boss fights, always many possibilities of entering objects, some noisier than others, some requiring 2 people. And you have to walk through all of it to get ammo, medkits and clues to boss location.Also very gruesome, gore porn, perfect theme.Stealth big category on itself: dead horses everywhere but some raise their heads when you come close and let out a loud shriek, monster agro makes noise, crows fly off and alert to you, glass and cans littered on ground. Cans and bottles and chains hanging from ceiling, very good difference between varied surface types when walking. Monsters dont hear you when crouched. At night is harder to see. You can start up a loud generator that turns on spotlights to light up area for defense.Overall, there is just so much game here. One of the best game experience I've had in a while.===About the game===This game is basically a school setting fantasy anime with a twist, the twist being you are in it as the protagonist. If you've watched any of those such as Guilty Crown or Angel Beats, it's going to feel very familiar. The game does a terrific job at establishing the atmosphere of "living a carefree life as a high school student on a summer vacation". The story itself is a bit cliché, but is still interesting and enhanced by the whole concept of being in an empty school in an unpopulated alternate world. This concept alone makes the game feel very relaxing to play, there's no rush to do anything, you can explore the world and socialize with your friends to your heart's content.The game feels a lot like Nier: Automata, not only because of some of the later maps, but the general atmosphere of being in an isolated world too. Just felt like pointing that out because I love that game as well.===Gameplay===A pleasant mix of JRPG combat, base building, and dating-sim...? (kind of). Combat is easy to follow and pretty cool. As a JRPG combat system, it's neither too slow and bland nor too complicated, with its fair share of uniqueness. Character customization with the talent and fragment system is a nice touch, reminiscent of the classic Final Fantasy 7 and 8, and is undeniably fun.Base building - its existence alone in this game is pretty great, especially considering the game's setting, albeit a bit held back by the lack of ability to customize or actually interact with them. Pseudo-dating-sim - Just awesome. It's basically the game's means of character development, but you get to experience it more personally. The dating events are all wholesome and cute, and makes you come to love the characters so you can better enjoy the whole experience.===Characters===The entire cast of characters are lovable, some of them relatable, and all of them simply amazing. The voice-acting is spot on - exactly what you would expect from watching a good anime. They each have their own distinct personality, and learning their backstories and interacting with them are a total joy. Character development is done very well, so as the story goes on, you grow to love every one of the characters, making it easy to fully immerse yourself in the setting.===Visuals & Music===Vast world with photo-realisitc textures like in Forza Horizon 5? No.Beautiful world that makes exploration absolutely enjoyable? Yes.Everything in this game is pleasing to look at. Everywhere I go I feel is worthy of a screenshot, and there are places that are clearly designated photo spots. Combining the gorgeous scenery with a lovable crew, the photo mode is really a great tool to spend some time playing around with. Actually feels like a vacation trip, and gives off a nostalgic feel.Music - unique, catchy, and overall great. Sets the mood perfectly throughout the game and never gets old.===Yuri content===Even though there's no intimate interactions between characters or anything of the sorts except holding hands I guess, there is certainly a mild yuri vibe in the air throughout the game that I'm sure yuri fans can appreciate. My statement from old review still stands, I think it's the best yuri themed RPG out there.===Conclusion===All aspects are done decently, leaving not much to complain about. It's a fairly standard modern JRPG, with a brilliant setting and extra immersion.In addition, there's always this mood of nostalgia throughout the whole game, the feeling of being young, full of energy, and surrounded by wonderful friends. It makes the game feel very special, at least for me.For all of the above, I consider this absurdly priced game to be very much worth it, and I can't wait for a third game in the series.

reviews.text: Blue Reflection: Second Light is exactly what a player would expect and hope from a better version of its predecessor.Everything presented in its first instalment is either reimagined or evolved in this sequel. From its characters that unfolds better to the actual gameplay, which ends up being richer. Blue Reflection: Second Light strikes in with a story that works as a soft reboot to ensure new players and as a continuation of what was narrated in the first game and anime altogether, to please those who have already experienced the franchise in the past. The "magical girl" legacy that this franchise is keeping to its heart is still going strong and faithful, even if the world and the thematic are changing from the first game. Second Light succeds in finding a way to retain what actually means to be a "magical girl" while pushing to give something more, that was never presented before, without resulting excessive superfluous.If there's one thing that seems to be annoying, is that the fast-paced style of the combat, while still resulting frenetic and fun, doesn't make justice to the animation overall, as the player doesn't have the time to look and appreciate what's happening on the screen because keeping the pace of the battle is a core part of the gameplay. For this reason, I hope Gust is going to implement a "Pause Animation Option" to ensure a pause when the girls attack during a battle. With such options, attacks would be divided from animation that a player can appreciate while the fight would still end up being frenetic and fast. I already hope for a 3rd game for main consoles and PC!

reviews.text: Long time ago, I had a discussion with community, ‘If one day, you get ONE ticket to a game world, you are granted to travel there and live there forever, but you won’t be able to come back, which game will you choose to go?’ The answers were vary. To me, the answer is: the world of Blue a Reflection, there isn’t another. As a long time fan of Blue Reflection, I am not going to praise 2nd Light sky high like I did to the first game, instead, I want to use this review to help the franchise at very least has the possibilities to improve even further for the future titles, since the 2nd game is different from the first one, we have the opportunity to see a larger scale of the world setting of the game; a bigger cast than the first one too. Before I get myself started, I’d like to state: 2nd Light has changed many things comparing to the first game, and improved A LOT regarding to combat system, general gameplay. There isn’t any doubt that Gust put tons of ideas and thought into making 2nd Light a better game, and did a great job to deliver the final product to meet fans’ expectations.This is where we begin to see the true potential of 2nd Light, though the game seems lacks of the depth of the developments of these ideas. Starting with combat strategy & bosses fights.I love every single character in the game, the art, costumes, personalities, interacted conversations, everyone is different and unique. And that’s exactly why I felt like the combat needs more work in order to let everyone standing in the front equally. What does this mean? Alright, I will give specific examples here. We have 6 reflectors instead of 3 in 2nd Light who can participate in battle, while having one support slot to choose one more reflector who will be supporting members in battle instead of fighting directly, only switching in if the tide of the combat changes. 3 place for 3 reflectors, huh? Classic. However, Ao’s combat efficiency is somehow bond with Kokoro, because her ability is doing high critical damage when enemies are under debuff status ailments and Kokoro has tons of abilities that inflecting negative ailments while doing damage. Which made them a duo, either one of them alone in battle isn’t going to achieve the max potential and efficiency they’re capable of, despite you can still do that as you like. Meanwhile Ao chan is the protagonist of the game, and the ONLY character in 2nd Light who has Combo Guard which is a skill that prevent combo reset from bosses’ special attacks. Which means, Ao is a must in boss fight, because long combo count= high damage, especially for higher difficulties. So logically, Kokoro would tag along, then only leaves one last placeholder for a reflector, in the other word, 1 out of 4 to choose. The problem here is, Shiho chan is so OP in the game, she’s like the Goddess of War, who can do massive damage alone while providing healing and curing status ailment which made her almost pointless to be replaced by others. Other 3 reflectors either is healing focus character(Rena chan) or damage types( Hinako & Hiori chan) who will rely on consumable items to heal or equip healing amour fragment for healing on boss fights which again, doesn’t seems necessary while Shiho chan gets both problem solved solely.Don’t get me wrong, I am not saying Shiho can’t be OP, she is a formidable reflector in battle and very heartwarming character in the story. She is my favorite girl and I love her from the bottom of my heart. I’m not complaining the difficulty is low on my first play-through either, I know Gust can easily make a game very difficult if they wanted to. What I am talking about here is: the variety of situations of boss fights 2nd Light lacks of WITHOUT increasing the difficulty. You know, even you can oneshot enemies, there are still many ways about how you oneshot them. The combination of Shiho, Ao and Kokoro(SAK) had done 95% of the situation in battle which got me rarely using the other reflectors in general. Because during the long game progress, I have more than enough opportunities to test which combination is the most effective against foes, SAK was the star-champion all the time.Now, let’s imagine a different situation the game doesn’t have, what if there is an elite demon/ boss who has a massive chunk of health, it start attacking your party with low damage, the longer you battle it, its attack becomes more and more devastating, eventually, if you couldn’t kill it in time, it will oneshot your teammate that you won’t be able to revive them in time. Well obviously, my SAK is all-in offensive type, and will be no good in a situation like this, this is Rena chan comes to play. Rena has very high defense value and healing ability, by equipping all kinds of defensive fragments and the fragment that taunt enemies to attack her, she will be a sentinel role which likely would be crucial to a fight like this. If we had these type of enemies, Rena will no longer be sitting on the supporting seat only, doing healing and curing status ailments most of the times. Isn’t this a better respect for her after all? Boss’s 2nd phase?Though there is a boss that you need to beat it several times during the story, but instead of beating it over and over with the same team members, why not separate 6 reflectors who participate in battle into 2 teams, using the support girls who doesn’t join in battle directly as a support per fight? The idea may not be original, but I found it’s actually suit 2nd Light the best, since everyone levels up equally whether they join the battle or not, and there are more than enough fragments to equip, making every reflector in a ready-to-fight statement. If there are bossses kinda forcing you to form 2 different teams to fight at the same time, I dunno, in a different phase or stage maybe, and everyone gets chance to participate in battle, while putting gamers’ understanding of each reflector’s strength and weakness to test, isn’t it one stone with two birds? For example, Hinako chan may not have combo guard to stop bosses from breaking the combo chain, but her special ability adds combo count instantly and support other teammates to gain temporary ability to do so. Couldn’t she be the leading role of the 2nd team seems to me? She seems fine to fight a boss with 2 other reflectors along, while team one -Ao is busy with the other boss?I haven’t studied deeply enough about how Hiori can do her maximize efficiency in battle on my first finished walkthrough, definitely gonna research more about her on my returning 2nd run. Still, it will be much appreciated if we ever get another awesome BF game some time, there are situations she’s a must in combat just like I listed above for others rather than players are desperately creating an opportunity to use her because we love everything about her dearly too. Last thing in this section, I’d advise one thing, the support slot is a great idea, though using purely support girls might be a even better way for reasons (a)every character is making contributions to the fight by doing so, not just in cutscene stories, it means a lot to the world of BF; (b)because of the existence of support fragments, I found there isn’t any point to switch a character in the middle of the fights, rather than fully prepared 3 set reflectors from the start. Reflector who has equip half of her fragment slots with support fragments won’t be that helpful and efficient in battle comparing the status she’s powered by fully equipped battle fragments, it’s better just let the support role being a full supporter all the time helps a lot which is a waste to let a battle participator doing so, don’t you think?Deja vu of Ryza ?Ao chan is a likable character, there’s nothing wrong about being a tomboy, there isn’t any problem to use a tomboy as protagonist in the game. But don’t you feel like Blue Reflection 2nd Light is a bit too Deja vu of Ryza?  Please see the comments below to finish

reviews.text: A massive improvement over the original. Would I recommend playing the original before jumping into the sequel? I would say yes simply because of returning characters and it gives you more insight into the universe of Blue Reflection despite all of it's faults.Second Light improves on everything the first did including a better port, Gust seem to be getting better at porting to PC while other KT properties are either hit or miss (Warriors Orochi 4 had a good port while Fatal Frame V and Ninja Gaiden collection had rather lazy ports). As for the new additions there is a faster more in depth combat system similar to what Atelier Ryza has. There is more playable characters (BR1 was limited to 3). They also added the two leads from the anime as playable characters, which I haven't finished. The level design has been vastly improved while also giving you more ways to trek across each area. Seriously, the level design in the first wasn't great. There is also live banter while exploring dungeons which give the characters more personality and makes the game more lively. Ao has the ability to date other girls which the first game kinda let you do. Another improvement and one I'm glad about is the overhaul of the progression systems. In BR1, Hinako and the girls didn't level up in a traditional manner instead they gain skill points from interacting with other characters in the game meaning the only thing combat rewarded you with was items. In the second game they scrapped that and added in a traditional leveling system through combat but also retained some of the original elements. Instead of gaining a single stat point from interacting with characters you get TP points that also level up the relationship you have with each character. The points you get from here can go into one of four trees. These can give a character a slight stat increase or an ability. Mel Kishida's art is as beautiful as it has ever been with high quality character portraits and designs, seriously his character design's in Blue Reflection and the Atelier Arland games are really good. The music still has that laid back feeling it had in the original. The story is also improved from the first because there is a mystery of the girls finding out about their pasts and about the world they currently inhabit. All in all Blue Reflection Second Light improves upon what the original did and it's really like Mel and the guys at Gust really listened to the criticism's the first game got and decided to create an overall better package than their previous outing.The game is peak "cute girls doing cute things". As for my favorite girls it looks like a tie between Ao, Kokoro and of course Hinako, the protagonist from the original who returns in this game.

reviews.text: The good: Character interactions - An enjoyable and varied cast of characters that you will get attached to over the course of the story.Visuals & Music- The Heartscapes (dungeons) each have an interesting aesthetic and accompanying music that keeps you interested in what the next one will look and sound like.The bad: Combat system - Reminiscent of Xenosaga from back in the day, where enemies and players operate on an action timeline and you need to try and stop their attacks while getting yours in. What I didn't like was the Combo system and the drive system. Essentially, your characters will grow in power as the fight progresses but to me it felt like needlessly dragging the fight out and makes actions taken early in the fight feel less meaningful because well... they are.Crafting system - Will routinely ask you to gather items but often times will not tell you where they are and/or it involves grinding enemies for drops.Stealth missions - Sneak past spastic enemies while using objects for cover that may or may not actually obfuscate you.Story - If you didn't play the first game and watch the Anime, prepare for much of the exposition to fly over your head.Difficulty - The game's difficulty isn't very balanced. Early on it's a struggle, but about 25% of the way into the game you will basically begin to streamroll most encounters if you get a pre-emptive strike. Even bosses usually arent that dangerous - mostly just HP sponges.The ugly: Localisation - Typos aside, other bizarre narrative changes have taken place like trying to portray these clearly high school girls wearing seifuku as being in college. Even non Japanese speakers will probably pick up on some of the spoken dialogue not matching the English text as some words are fairly common in anime. This narrative change is especially jarring if you are familiar with characters from the previous entries and is borderline gaslighting.Yuri themes - If you're coming in expecting lots of yuri content, there isn't a whole lot of substance outside of one established couple involving two of your party members. The 'dates' the player character goes on could have easily been called 'hang outs' and would probably be more accurate as to how they play out. There is handholding later in the game, but as soon as you reach your 'date' location, the interaction is played straight 95% of the time. Occasionally you can flirt which is played for comedic effect and goes nowhere and there is no ultimate payoff at the end of the game. I believe this is referred to as 'yuri bait'.Fanservice - Unfortunately what the game is probably most infamously known for is the character designer saying some controversial stuff in terms of reducing fanservice. If you have played the first title, you will definitely feel that, but someone new coming into the series will probably not notice. For me personally, if that's truly what the developers wanted to do and weren't being coerced by outside pressure, I don't really care one way or the other. Having said that, the lengths they have gone to in order to ensure no 'naughty' upskirt pictures could be taken is both comical and a bit pathetic. In the end, I enjoyed it for what it was, but several things left a sour taste in my mouth that it tarnished the overall experience enough that I don't think I would have paid the exceedingly high asking price.
