reviews.text: Despite being a sequel to 2017's Blue Reflection, Second Light hardly feels like the same game - but not in a bad way.The short answer is “no, but it’s still recommended if you want the full experience”. Second Light features an entirely new main cast of characters and the story is mostly told without being too reliant on the first. I say mostly because the cast from the first do eventually make their way into this story, but it’s done in a manner that you would be able to understand even without being familiar with them.This extends to the anime adaptation as well: Blue Reflection Ray. I myself did not actually finish that anime yet I had no trouble getting to know the characters from it in the game – so again, you can just start from Second Light and be completely fine.Despite how simple the combat in the first game was, I kinda liked it. It was effective and perfectly matched the game’s laidback, slice of life feel. Second Light, on the other hand, completely throws that combat system out the window for an active-time battle system – similar to what we got in the recent Atelier Ryza games.Battles are far faster as a result and with the changes to the ether system, they only get faster the longer you’re in a battle. The MP system is removed entirely and now attacks, skills, and items all consume ether, which is regenerated at different rates per character depending on their stats. That said, I am a bit torn on this system. It is a completely different feel from the previous game and, while cool in theory, it does come with some problems.Mainly, it’s that it takes away a lot of the variety that the first game had with regards to its skills. Whereas in the first game, I was constantly scrolling through my different attacks and figuring out which best to use in a given fight – this game it is 95% of the time just going to be one of my basic attacks. I would enter a fight, spam A throughout the entire thing, and call it a day.Hard difficulty is not unlocked until you fully clear the game once, so you have to do your first playthrough on normal and I found it to be a bit too easy. Even after I intentionally kept myself underleveled by avoiding a lot of the enemies on the map, I still had no trouble clearing each and every encounter I ran into.Around halfway into the game, I stopped caring to even figure out the best party composition, which skills to unlock, and even what moves I was using – it hardly mattered with how easy it is and with how the ether mechanic is designed. Just keep spamming those basic attacks and you’ll build up your combo quickly, which in turn allows you to do more damage with your next basic attack and so on.Finishing up the game, I couldn’t escape this feeling that the battle system was just underutilized. It has all these cool mechanics, but the low difficulty and emphasis on building up combo quickly leave it feeling a bit repetitive.In the first game, the level design was some hot garbage – mostly small groups of pathways and platforms. In Second Light, they went all out. Now there are multiple areas per biome, movement options outside of just… walking, and some actual exploration elements, even if on the lighter side. The new areas are also far more dense, with more detail put into individual buildings and the overall geography being much more varied.Having to do fetch quest after fetch quest just to get to the next chapter in the first game was some incredibly boring stuff, so I was very happy to see that done away with entirely in Second Light. Now, side quests are just that – optional side quests. That said, they’re also more varied. Aside from the usual “craft this for me” or “kill this enemy for me”, a lot of them now have you build unique school development stuff – stuff that you actually can use outside of that individual side quest.There are even some side quests that straight up expand on individual characters by having you explore different areas with them to unlock their memories. You sometimes have to do some boring stealth missions, but it’s at least much better off than the filler that the first game had.It still has the same overall school-magical girl theme told across different character arcs, but there is FAR more focus placed on a larger, more connected story instead of just rushing things right at the end like the last game. Character arcs are almost immediately tied into this bigger story and the game does a great job balancing out character development with this larger mystery.The game as a whole takes a darker tone than the original and the pacing starts off slow, but ramps up around the halfway point once you start realizing the truth behind this world. It doesn’t go completely overboard either – in fact, it might actually be a bit too slow. Perhaps this is just because the game is longer (this one took me just over 30 hours whereas the first took just 20), but I felt like they could have shaved off a bit towards the end to make it flow better.Still an interesting story for sure (and definitely better than the first game), but not quite at the level that I would call it anything more than just “good”.I am a huge fan of the urban fantasy magical girl aesthetic and Second Light only expands on the first game in this regard with the improved world detail and upgraded visuals that bring it more in line with the recent Atelier games. It’s definitely not a shining example as far as actual graphical quality, but the setting, character designs, and overall theme are solid. The music on the other hand, while still good, I did not find to be quite as good as the first game.The first game somehow used 100% of my RTX 3080 Ti even with the fps capped to my monitor’s refresh rate, but this one ran just fine at 155 fps without turning my computer into a jet engine. There are far more graphical options to change this time too, so there is ample room to finetune settings if you need to.One recommendation I will make – do disable the game’s depth of field setting, it is WAY more aggressive than it needs to be. Otherwise, the only other problems I had were with the game always launching in windowed (which you can solve by hitting F9) and a game crash about two hours in. I didn’t lose much progress due to the new auto save feature, but any crash is worth mentioning.And surprisingly, the keyboard and mouse controls are actually NOT garbage this time around. There’s actual mouse support in the menus, on the field, and it doesn’t feel like it’s just emulating a controller. I still used a controller myself, but it’s one of the few Koei Tecmo PC ports where the keyboard and mouse controls would be a viable alternative – I had no problems with them during my testing and they are rebindable too.Blue Reflection: Second Light is an overall improvement over the first game in almost every regard. A more fleshed out story, a bunch of useful quality of life features, much better visuals, vastly improved level design, a decent PC port – it’s got a lot going for it. Unfortunately, the combat is a bit of a mess and the game is far too easy, making a lot of the new combat additions redundant. That, and while the story itself is interesting, it doesn’t come without its problems. Still, I had a good time with it in spite of these faults and would recommend it if you like Gust JRPGs.Follow my  for more reviews + videos!

reviews.text: This game brought me lots of nostalgic feelings and moments of a particular summer holiday, that time when I was hanging around with a few friends and an older cousin, was such an unforgettable experience. We all thought perhaps the world held only us then.The central theme of this game is Cute-Girls-Doing-Cute-Things in an enclosed place, and the usual magical girls slaying evil spirits. The plot is very straightforward even though it seemed convoluted at first glance, of course, there are a few twists to make the story engaging but still very predictable. However, the pacing execution is the key to make even a predictable feels enjoyable.Overall, the game has a clear goal set up since the beginning (one of foremost problems that its predecessor failed to establish)I don't really have anything to say about Graphics aspect. Art style embraced the first game's and improved even more, the result is a beautifully-crafted game. You can also tinker around the Photo Mode feature and publish pretty pictures.However, there are some small texture bugs with characters' hair.The Localization part is a massive step up from the first game, Gust and KT did a great job of getting a top quality localization team for this game.And about the Port, perhaps the best yet. This game came with a fully mapped KB&M buttons - which is a huge plus from me. The quality is very consistent, I have had not notice even the slightest drop in frames.I might be repeating myself countless times, but still, the gameplay is also a massive step up from its predecessor.They got rid of the old Speed Turn-based system in favor of an ATB-ish Turn-based, which offers more strategy approach and nullify cheesing to an extent. The Gear-escalating system blends very well into this aspect, although this can be repetitive for some people.And unlike the first game, your party won't fully healed after getting out of a fight and kept remain their HP through out expedition. Seems like a normalcy to JRPG games but it could threw some people (who came from the first game) off.Additionally, this game now has a Dating system. It isn't as well-crafted or impactful like Persona 5, but still a very nice cherry on top regardless. And through this, the chemistry of characters as well as some RPG elements is expanded upon so there is no harm in engaging with this aspect.Should you buy this game? Yes, you should experience this game for yourself, there are still stuffs that I haven't touched upon.You don't have to jump into its predecessor or watch Blue Reflection Ray anime (but should also consider them a try) to have a reason to play this game.Although, the game's quite expensive right now, maybe once it goes on sales you can consider getting this!Pros:+ Story, dialogues and pacing execution blended very well+ Engaging gameplay and strategically friendly+ Beautiful graphics, lighting and particles+ Localization and Port was handled carefullyCons:- There are some slight graphics bugs here and there- Gameplay can feel very repetitive and boring at times

reviews.text: Now that I've finished the game proper, all of the stuff I said previously still holds up, but here are some extra thoughts on the whole thing:Music: the new tracks are still phenomenal, though I really REALLY miss the multi-phase music for bosses, as that mechanic is entirely absent in this game.Battles: They're like Ryza, but with it's own flair. It's very fun, as are the infight battles seeing as they're very active and snappy. The latter half of the game does get steamroll-y as your damage can scale up really fast once you start stacking fragments and school/item buffs. Bosses feel really weak compared to the original in almost every respect though, as they lack all the pomp and circumstance and get quickly recycled making them feel even less special.Story: I quite loved it, I thought I knew how the whole thing was going to pan out when reaching the back half but they did throw a few wrenches in there to shake it up. It's about as bittersweet as you'd expect.Characters: Each individual character story varied in depth, ranging from 'I've seen this a million times' to 'jesus, this is not daijobu' but each character does get mountains of additional fluff from the dates and chatter you see throughout the whole game to round them out. They really grow on you, and I got attached to every one of them, unlike the original game. I did often found myself just running around and cutting grass while thinking about what was going on in each of their heartscapes.Presentation: I absolutely loved the abstract designs for the heartscapes. Framing for the cutscenes, along with the music and overdone post processing (nuclear sun anyone?) gave it quite the unique look overall and suited the otherworldly vibe they were going for.As for some of the things that straight up sucked:- the stealth mission stuff just blows in every regard, thankfully there's only one or two instances where it's forced early on, with the rest of them being relegated to side missions you can take (or skip). Save scumming highly recommended if you do do those missions.- the back half of the game had some very obvious problems with proofreading, punctuation, and grammar compared to the relatively pristine first half.- the bosses paled in comparison to the og blue reflection, just full stop.Final thoughts: Second Light is a fantastic sequel, and anyone who likes slice of life style JRPG stories should absolutely give this a look (and the first one, also very very good).---Old Review---This is probably one of Koei's best PC ports to date. Looks great and runs great compared to the first game.As for the game, it's built off the original wonderfully along with adding a bunch of new systems that add a lot of flavor and character to the game. The soundtrack continues to be all 10/10 tracks, battling is a lot of fun, and the environments are very pretty and well detailed. The character design is also very nice, continuing the trend of cute girls doing cute things with each other. Honestly, it's met my expectations and more, can't complain at all.

reviews.text: Wholesome yuri dating sim jrpg with a splash of existentialism and an incredible soundtrack. I would highly recommend playing the first game prior to this one, as it is a direct sequel and some characters/story moments will be lost on you if you decide to skip it.There's a ton of optional content in the form of cutscenes, conversations, bonding systems and side quests. These are the meat of the game. If you have no interest spending hours watching slice of life cutscenes and doing errands to build your character bonds, this is not the game for you. The main story works as melancholic popcorn candy on its own, but if you spend the time to learn about the characters and their relationships, it can become something magical.Combat is flashy fun with just enough depth to be interesting, but it gets too easy halfway through and harder difficulties are locked behind beating the game. The 1v1 cut-in fights are pretty cool when they work though.Graphically the game is gorgeous, but has a fair amount of minor bugs accompanying it (mostly clipping). The models can look a little strange at times, but they really work well when they're being used as a catalyst to portray specific emotions.OST is phenomenal. It uses quite a few of tracks from the original, but has a large new selection as well. While the boss/combat themes are a step down, the area music is breathtaking. Each area's story, visual design, and soundtrack melt together in an incredible way and immediately set the tone seconds after you step into a new zone.Tl;dr:If you enjoy spending hours learning about characters and watching them interact while listening to some beautiful music, you'll probably like this game. If you get bored easily, dislike reading, or want to play it for the combat, you probably won't like this game.

I wouldn't bother with the first game though, it's really not worth your time.In my opinion, Second Light is an absolute must-play for anyone who has ever considered themselves a fan of GUST's games, as well as fans of Yuri and the Magical Girl genre. It's easily one of the best games GUST has released in the last 10 years, and it has turned out to be my undisputed game of the year for 2021.

reviews.text: I have finished the game unlike most other reviews at this time. I assume you've seen the anime and/or at least know all the characters that appear in this game.TLDR: General improvement from first game but some subjective weak aspects.As a KT game with cosmetic DLC, I think even just the base game is very overpriced in my currency.I was apprehensive about having characters from the anime in the game, but they gave them enough development and backstory to justify it. That said, I don't feel that all the characters got fair development - stories and traumas from characters like Kokoro, Shiho and Kirara are absolutely forgettable, while other characters have very appealing and emotionally strong backstories, such as Rena and Yuki. I picked Uta for my ending cutscene but was unfortunately let down since her story felt kind of tacked on to the game and I was hoping to get some proper closure on her, which I unfortunately did not. It's a weak way of putting it but I'd say characters overall are 6/10s with some 8s.There are a handful of translation/spelling issues, and I was wondering whether different teams handled different aspects of the text since different things seemed to share separate consistency at times. Nothing worth complaining about overall though.Story was fine, it ties in a little with the first game but neither first game nor anime is entirely necessary to see. I think the premise was fine but the execution was kind of lacking, although I'd expect that from a game that's more focused on character building that story. Without going into spoiler territory, I'd just call it solid. The overall plot is often put to the side in lieu of the character stuff anyway.I thought I wouldn't like it based on the demo because the pause mechanics during battle are different (if you have it set to "manual", you can forget to tell your allies to make their moves). However as expected I got used to it very quickly and I think I prefer the faster pace. Knockdown has more impact here than in the first game, as does the fragment system and the talent system. Overall, battle system is a major improvement - it has been heavily streamlined and is more engaging, with a better Ether system. Even after finishing I'm still on the fence about the one-on-one system, it's nice but sometimes messed up my flow, especially since some enemies can trigger it on their own.Stealth was the main thing I disliked, there are some very annoying stealth missions (Uta, Yuzu/Lime) that I ended up save-scumming. Enemy detection is wonky (can sometimes see through objects or at strange angles) and their vision indicator is misleading (you can stand in the "weaker red" parts and not get seen). Was just frustrating at times being sent back to the start by what felt like unfair detection.I also don't particularly like the crafting/building loop, more than a few times I found myself going back to farm more "Warm Sand" to make and upgrade furnishings. There are 50 crafting teams by the end, which is too many, but I mostly ignored items throughout the game anyway. That said, I also feel that you can mostly ignore this stuff since you just need to do enough to trigger dates, no need to go for the extra bonuses from upgrades. The base difficulty (normal) doesn't warrant this, by about midgame you should be streamrolling all content until the end of the game without much investment into furniture.The final boss fight is very nice however I would still say that Daath is very slightly better overall. It was sort of introduced from nowhere and had little relation to the story other than being there because it needed to be (no explanation for it etc.) There are no game/save breaking bugs like the first game. Unfortunately there are also no real extras for finishing the game other than a quasi-NG+. The ending is purposefully ambiguous so again if you were hoping for particular character story tie-ups you won't get them.The music is very good, I'd say about on par with the first game for some tracks, while others were unremarkable. I couldn't pick between first or second for area themes, but boss themes from the first are probably slightly better (DNF FW15C III or Sayonara is still the best one imo). Interesting choice to sample the voice recording from  but strangely I grew to like it. Tie uses music from the first game anyway (bar the boss themes). There was one moment where I was really hoping that they would play  but they played some funny light-hearted track which as Ao might say "killed the vibe". Generally good job by Hayato Asano once more.Standard Blue Reflection art, it's fine. If you liked it already it's pretty much the same. Personally felt that Uta/Mio/Hiori looked kind of strange in the proper artstyle but let's be honest the anime didn't do them justice either. You know how that went.=Overall was okay but as it is a KT game I cannot in good faith recommend buying it.

reviews.text: The PC port is definitely better this time around, but while I'm glad that KB/M support isn't half-assed like a bunch of older KT ports and even modern IF/CH games (Button based remapping instead of action based remapping will always be horrible, even if what those buttons do are clearly labeled), mouse camera movement still feels really off. Framerate is uncapped by default (take notes non-gust KT and Atlus) (Although VSync is always enabled), and there's a config file tweak that you can do to get ultrawide working (Albeit with stretched UI elements, otherwise works fine).Performance looks about the same, if not a bit worse than Atelier Ryza 2, BUT for anyone using a controller (or at least those using a DualSense controller), there is some massive framerate spikes and stutter that happens when you simply use a controller. This could be because of Proton, but otherwise, I haven't had many issues running it in Proton either. Just a heads up to keep in mind.Why none of the pre-release reviews by PC oriented sites didn't cover any of this stuff, especially when KT and other JP developers (that aren't Capcom or Square Enix) get away with murder without any sort of criticism (Figuratively speaking for those who don't get sarcasm), is beyond me.That said, while Mel Kishida is dangerously based, as of late, he's a ♥♥♥♥♥-cat for pandering to braindead game journalists that whine about anything anyways, and reducing any sort of fanservice down to DLC items (like what KT tried with Dead or Alive and failed to appease any sexpest in the making) doesn't give anyone any faith. reviews.text: A pretty substantial upgrade from the first game in almost every way. It's not perfect, and admittedly, the last 10% of the game starts to fall apart through the narrative and its gameplay. In fact, this series could still use some improvements for future titles if they decide to make a third entry. But the fact of the matter is, they addressed a lot of my issues with the first game to make it an enjoyable experience. The characters are really fun, there's actually a proper level up system, and the school building/item crafting system is an absolute joy to tinker with. As someone who didn't like the first game all that much, I'm glad I gave the sequel a shot and wholeheartedly recommend it if you're still on fence.

reviews.text: I loved this game, it has one of the better social systems I've seen. The cast is all very likable and you feel like you get to know them really well over the course of the game. reviews.text: if you liked the first one then you're more than likely to enjoy this one. its worth full price, but waiting for the eventual sale may make it more appealing for some. there's lots more to do in school and in battles/exploring. the zones you explore are far more varied than the first. as with the first game, the UI is wonderfully designed and crispfor those unfamiliar with this game, its a magical girl jrpg set up similarly to Persona. its a mix between developing your school/relationships with the girls and visiting various zones to battle manifestations of their emotions. the battle system is real time where multiple characters/enemies can be attacking at the same time but battle pauses when you are selecting attacks. as the story progresses, you learn more about each girl's past and how they overcome their various adversities.you dont need to have played the first or watch the anime to understand what's going on, but it makes the experience more enjoyable of reviews.text: Blue Reflection: Second Light differs significantly from it's predecessor and I find myself in the awkward position of being able to recommend it more, while liking it less. Gust tried to capitalize on the success of Atelier Ryza by featuring a similar protagonist, but it just doesn't work in a Blue Reflection context. The prequel had a fully realized protagonist in Hinako, with real motivations and fears. Ao is just a vapid, lazy, under-charming everywoman, who is outshined by a significant portion of the cast. This may sound alright in an ensemble cast format, but when the protagonist has to participate in every one of the many, many cutscenes, her one-dimensional nature leaves a lot to be desired. The plot is urgent and directionless. Without a main villain, the girls are simply in a race against time. Not one of them has a clear idea of how to prevent their impending doom, or how to plan more than one step ahead.The battles uses Ryza's semi real-time system as a foundation, and heaps a mess of different ideas on top of that. It will take a little time to feel comfortable, but it does afford the player some flexibility to play the game more like a turn-based RPG, or more like an auto-battler.The bosses are very frail and uninspired things, who sit around waiting for you to approach them. Ao and her friends have no problem going mano a mano with these pathetic creatures, mere shadows of the lumbering monstrosities of BR 1 that required an entire army of high schoolers to take down.Everything else this game tries to flesh out is equally ill-conceived. The Reflector costumes don't quite work. The world is much larger and more ambitious, but somehow lacks the same atmosphere. The music just doesn't grab you. It's not necessarily bad, but in a game where battles usually take under a minute, you cannot include tracks that take that long to make a point. At the end of the day, this is a game with twice the play length and content of its predecessor, and still retains enough of the series essence for me to give it a recommendation. While I am a bit disappointed at the direction Blue Reflection is going in, a game must ultimately be judged by it's own merits, and you could do worse than picking up this title.

They do only happen once during a heartscape or during a boss fight, but again through multiple backtracking you will end up seeing them a lot. Unskippable but are only a few seconds, still got on my nerves. And the worst of all is the garbage stealth mission. They are only a few and the majority are tolerable. reviews.text: Are you here for gameplay? Better look somewhere else. Otherwise, look closer. Provided you don't mind lesbians. I hope you don't.Blue Reflection 2 (or Second Light) can be played without playing the first game, or watching the (not very good) anime. There are recurring characters and themes from both, but I'd say in case of the anime it's probably better to not know it. Has a good enough chance to make you dislike the characters coming from it, because it's not well written. The first game I can't just recommend due to a lot of issues thanks to its non existing budget. If you liked this game, you could still check it out later.What about the DLC? Ignore. So far nothing worthwhile has been released. The DLC area has barely any story/cutscenes, and for that we are here.So, what's this about anyway? A bunch of girls, with more and more appearing, trying to survive in a strange little world they are imprisoned in. Outside of the protagonist, Ao, none seem to have any memories. You play through their so called heartscapes, to see their most precious memories and help them to restore their memories. These memories made out of fragments of a key event of their lives, usually involving hard times that made them able to become what they are today. They are generally kept believable and on the ground, so it's a refreshing and relatively calm experience. The music nicely underlines this with a lot of nice and calm music with some electronic aspects to otherwise often piano music. Pretty good music, mind you. You may also get a little teary eyed here and there, but it's never too heavy on its mood.Aside of that, you get to know the characters better. Everything really has story meaning in the game. Building facilities for your place or fulfilling quests character give you, don't just give you gameplay benefits, they also grant "date" events, giving you a closer look at the character(s) in question. Raise their ranks through both, and you get further events with them. There's not much romance, mind you, though one very explicit lesbian couple exists, but that doesn't concern Ao. She can play wingman though... and still hold hands with the involved girls. Okay, it's weird, but that's just Ao. You can make her flirt pretty hard with any girl, really. If you like that, great. If you don't, there's usually an option to not do so, but it may be hard. Ao is just that much of a huge flirt. You do these things usually at the beginning of a chapter and it can take 2 or 3 hours. During dates you can often also find optional events (marked on your map), which is a nice touch, aside of some obligatory choices slightly changing dialogue. Eventually you'll go into the next dungeon, and here we get to the less great part. The nice part of them is, that you can find the fragments and get enough little cutscenes to entertain. The not so nice part is, gameplay.Dungeons. Gameplay. Well, it's an Rpg, right? Right. First of all, if you aren't willing to use cheat engine to get the difficulty up to hard, or as of v1.01 deathwish, you can stop reading after this paragraph. It's so easy, you don't need to know if the mechanics are for you. It's gonna be boring, but you can dodge a lot of enemies in dungeons. There are also some stealth missions, where some later ones might frustrate. You can however save ANYWHERE in a dungeon, and pop right back to where you were, making it ultimately never more than a minor test of patience. Now then, you have cheat engine ready? Higher difficulties actually require that you really make sure to upgrade facilities and care about what skills you learn. (hint: Don't touch the flat stat ups, like attack + 3, and get the Yuki ether boost skills ASAP) That said, once you hit a certain point of the game, even deathwish becomes easy mode. In new game+ it should be easy mode from the get go. (the point you'd normally have it unlocked for) Because battle performance really matters little, I won't write much about the battle mechanics. Just one thing: Basically every fight is the same, which I consider a big minus. Some mechanics are also rather counter-intuitive (1vs1 is just a BAD mechanic, no matter how you look at it), and nothing is even remotely strong enough to live till you can use your "ultimates", especially given that enemies love to kill themselves due to triggering 1vs1. The endgame is also particularly stretchy, getting in the way of the story climax. Really, it's not great. Can be fun for a bit, but eventually you just cruise, as if it's normal mode.Still though, it's a good game, if you like cutscenes and getting to know a big cast that's well used and doesn't even really suffer from the "everyone has to say one line per cutscene" syndrome. Unfortunately there's also some bad news. The translation is a professional 4/10. While each line by itself is mostly correct, , in context there are way too many moments where the word choices do not make sense or downright clash with lines just seconds before. Being a liberal translation is fine and all, but then you need to pay a lot more attention to context, which they really didn't. The translation also likes way too much to write out what was originally only implied. If you played the first game, it's very similar to that. While it's a shame that the translation is so sub-par, there's still a lot you can enjoy. For a commercial product that relies heavily on its text, the translation may be disappointing. But there's way worse out there. This was simply a game that required more attention to detail, which it did unfortunately not get.

reviews.text: This is a flawless PC port of a great game. If you've enjoyed the previous game and the anime, then another emotional journey awaits you. Here, you will be building memories with both new and old friends. Even if you have no prior experience with the series, the game provides you with enough backstory to ensure that you don't miss out on the most heartfelt moments.Production values have been vastly improved this time. Character movement has enough weight that we don't feel like we are just floating around. The visuals are consistent, and at times breathtakingly beautiful. Mise-en-scène resembling contemporary art films from the first game is still present here. Both party members and NPCs move around the school and do various activities on their own such as watering plants or eating takoyaki. It's quite endearing at times just watching what they do.Bonding events are plentiful and a lot more interesting. As a matter of fact, I haven't come across any bonding event that feels trivial enough to skip - even though the temptation can be high as the main plot gets intriguing. One might say that there are simply "too many" of them, which can get exhausting. Also worth noting is that there are a lot less incongruous fan service scenes this time.Unfortunately, the game is not without elements that can compromise enjoyment. First and foremost - the stealth missions. I know they are optional, but the completionist in me tells me otherwise, and so does the character who has lost her phone and needs my help sneaking past densely packed enemy hordes to retrieve it. Enemy movement appears to be completely random, and the camera often prevents us from being able to see whether it's safe to move forward or not. This, combined with exhaustion from monotonous battles and a few uninteresting maps, makes the game fall short from being my favorite Gust produced game.Regardless of some annoyances, the game is, after all, an amazing experience with its excellent story and lovable characters.

reviews.text: Summer holiday JRPG that delivers well on core values and exceeds the sum of its parts - outstanding writing and characterisation, decent map design, complex ATB-like combat system and detailed crafting/building system (but with q of life feats making them really approachable).A key feature is that you can progress either by battling, or by developing relationships with the varied and engaging characters.Anime streak is running strong in this one, with a slice of life + light yuri experience combined with an over-the-top fantasy plot. An engaging, modern soundtrack and good voice acting for icing.Not sure this can be recommended for lower end gaming PCs. Visually: art but not without technical blemishes, and cloth + hair physics come across as a little broken (even mid/upper rigs).Game systems are well integrated (they support each other) my only gripe being I'd play happier if they went easier on the signposting (or just let me turn off some of it)There is enough content to justify a 2nd run unless you doggedly grind and unlock every upgrade at every chapter on first play (in which case you're spoiling the RPG/combat experience cause it will be too easy).Isekai/yuri/slice of life/magical girl fans will be delighted; likewise: have a good time if an all-girls cast is not off-putting, and you JRPGs but usually feel they are too grindy.Striving for objectivity, I'd say Second Light has evolved, and here is now a better game. Still, I recommend Blue Reflection (first game) as the ultimate magical girl experience; can understand newcomers may skip the first issue, but they'll definitely be missing out.

reviews.text: Edit: for all the people experiencing stutter every 2 or so seconds, plug in a controller. Ridiculous, I know, but a recurring problem in previous KT games; Tested in a RTX 3060, game still doesn't utilize 100% GPU and doesn't run at 144 fps, but now at around 110~120 all the timeVery cute, chill and interesting game. Combat is a little confusing at first, but gets fun real fast. Visuals, specially the environment and character models are gorgeous, I'd say way better than most anime games I've played (although there wasn't many). I guess some people would think the story is a bit bland or shallow, but so far I'm very interested in what's going to happen next, not to mention I like all the characters so far.Performance is a little weird at the moment. Game runs fine @ 60 fps most of the time, but drops to 50s, 40s and even 30s at the most random occasions like a close up on a character's face in a cutscene, while maintaining solid 60 fps while in battle or exploring a large area. GPU utilization also almost never really exceeds 80% even when running at 30something fps, so I imagine there's some underlying issue at the moment that may get fixed at some point. This is running @ 1080p, mostly medium and high settings (didn't see much of a performance difference on low, but the game looks a lot worse), on a GTX 1650 and i5 11400F with 16GB ram, so keep that in mind when buying the game. That being said though I barely notice when there are frame drops, mostly because of the somewhat "slow"-paced gameplay (it's a good thing), so it doesn't bother me at all so far.Turning anti-aliasing ON in the game's settings make everything a little blurrier for me for some reason. Turning it off and then turning FXAA on inside nvidia's control panel made a whole lot of difference.Haven't played the first one (but do plan on doing so) so can't compare them.

reviews.text: This sequel is nothing to scoff at. Gust has taken some great strides this time around! The original game had some serious pacing issues by gating you with padding and any menial sidequests with not much pay off other than earning enough points to unlock the next main story quest. BLUE REFLECTION: Second Light quickly found its footing. There are still hunting quests, stealth missions, etc BUT this time you are rewarded for your time helping your friends by getting talent points and levels, new scenes and more chances to take your friends out on dates. It's not your typical JRPG. The pacing here will be a bit different due to BLUE REFLECTION's focus on intimate character interactions. In this game, in order to unlock new talents, its important to spend time and bond with your friends. By building relationships, your party grows stronger. This game is very cutscene heavy, but please stick with it. The character interactions are great and are the big highlight of the magical girl genre.Gameplay: 8/10The questing can be a bit mindnumbing, but the rewards and the battle system keep it interesting and fun. I am close to 20 hours in and I am still enjoying tweaking with my character builds and trying different teams. You will eventually unlock fragments which grant you skills and bonuses that you can equip to each character. Do not neglect these as they are extremely useful. They can be earned by going on dates with friends.Graphics 8/10This is not a graphically intensive game, but they have really stylized it and made it their own so it still looks gorgeous. Their use of colors and effects for transformations are flashy and fun. I really don't mind the repetitiveness of the transformation animations since its a key aspect of any magical girl show :DStory 8/10The story is definitely not for everyone, but I found personally found it engaging. I found myself getting very excited when a new zone opened up so I could learn more about each character. This is an extremely character driven narrative and the interactions between Ao and her friends are the highlight of this adventure. I am not giving a summary because it can get spoilery quick, but if you really enjoy deep, personal narratives with slice of life aspects, give this a shot!Music 9/10The battle music is fast paced and fun. Each zone's music is heavily stylized to the theme and I really loved all the different effects that they used. It may not be for everyone, but I always feel like Gust nails their OSTs.Overall 8/10 I am so far really loving BLUE REFLECTION: Second Light. If you are on the edge of the water, just dive right in. I think Ao and her friends will make it worth your while!

reviews.text: is a heavily story-driven action-adventure game that tells the story of two convicts,  and . The catch is that the game is playable only in co-op. The game supports both local and online options, and you can use  to stream it to your friend, or you can use  on , where your friend just needs to download the game files, and you will invite him to your lobby. You can also play with random people online, but you cannot play it alone.The whole game feels like a good action film with several interesting plot twists. The story itself starts in a prison where both  and  ended up because of a guy called . As their path crossed during a few incidents, they decided to work together, escape the prison, and find . Both characters are unique in their own way as  is more of a guy who first acts rather than thinks, and  is the exact opposite of him, which leads to several humorous and a bit unpredictable situations. I would say that their personality is interesting and likable, as I was interested in their problems and related side characters, like family members. On the opposite, the villain  is just an uninteresting figure who does not have any depth at all, and the game would prosper from fleshing out his character more. There are also a few situations that do not make sense, and they break my immersion a bit. For example, if a character has another person as a human shield, its weapon’s ammo is unlimited, and he does not reload it at all. However, even with all these problems, I enjoyed the story, as  and  journey was thrilling and emotional. In the end, I will remember some story twists for a while.I highly recommend playing this game with your partner, friend, or another relative, as it adds a lot to the experience rather than with random people. The game lasts about , and I would say that the length is just right. I could probably argue that one more hour could help flesh out some characters, but it would still be quite short. Most of the time, you have to go through small open locations and finish the task to continue to another section. One of the most used gameplay mechanics are quick-timed events, which are surprisingly done right, and there is no tremendous button mashing, so that is a plus. However, do not expect some complex gameplay or mechanics. This game relies on quick-timed events and short different elements. The gameplay is tailored to fit the story, you will not find here difficult puzzles as in  series or more complex combat options as in  series. The game is very forgiving, and the checkpoints are very common.Throughout the chapters, the game changes the environment, tasks, and gameplay activities a lot. The co-operation of both players is very important as you cannot finish the game without it. There are a lot of easy environmental puzzles that fit the narrative and linearity of the game, but I would still wish for at least a few more complex tasks. Sometimes the game lets you deal out with enemies via stealth or shooting. Unfortunately, AI is quite stupid, so you can rush through the area quickly and knock them out. As for shooting, the gunplay is quite good but a bit easy, as well. However, sections, where you drive vehicles, are a bit harder as you mostly fight the camera (this, especially, applies to the bikes). I would welcome some difficulty settings, at least for the enemies. If you are looking for a challenging co-op experience, then you will not find it here.The game also offers various activities and minigames, which are only present in specific chapters. For example, you can throw darts, play videogames, interact with others, and much more. I am not going to name them all, but it varies a lot throughout the chapters, and it keeps the game fresh and interesting. Even if you decide not to do them, you will still receive a fair amount of diverse gameplay.Sometimes the game offers you a choice to continue in certain situations differently. It changes cutscenes and gameplay a bit, so small replay value for at least one more playthrough is here. To put a clear picture, you might decide if you will try to cross the bridge with the police in a car, which is the fastest but more dangerous variant, or if you will go underneath the bridge. Speaking about choices, the game also has two endings, but none of the previous choices matters, as they are more about how do you continue your journey gameplay-wise rather than about longtime story effect. The thing I disliked about this mechanic is that both players have to actually choose the same option. If two players will not choose the same thing then you wait until one of you decides to side with the other player. The game should have implemented an RNG system that would choose in such situations.The second thing I did not like much about the gameplay is how the screen is split in half even in online co-op. I understand this is necessary for local co-op, but it is a bit irritating as your screen is smaller for the whole game. There were few occasions where the game actually let play only one player and the scenes transmitted rather than being cut in half. This option was way more enjoyable and film-like. It would probably also add a bit to the difficulty, as you would not have an option to look to your partner's side.The game looks great graphics-wise. It offers several beautiful sceneries and cutscenes which might be comparable to films. There are several animations for different situations, and they are properly fleshed out. The only minor issue is that you can drive through a few branches during car chases which destroys an immersion a bit, and I would not expect this in this linear short game. As for the sounds, the sound effects themselves are of high quality. As for the soundtrack, there are few compelling compositions, but nothing memorable. The game was tested with an , running at high settings at  frames per second, at  resolution. The game ran without any problems and crashes. reviews.text: The best split-screen co-op game so farBefore you consider buying this game, make sure that you have a friend or family member that is willing to play hours of this game with you, because this is a co-op only game.A Way Out is a one of a kind game. Usually, massive story-driven games are only for single player and it's hard to share the kind of experience that these types of games give you. A Way Out, however, allows you to experience a massive story-driven game with a friend. Playing the two characters gives completely different perspectives on the story. The two characters often get separated and do unique things while still kind of connected. Playing a different character after finishing the game gives a completely different version of the game.All the levels are creative and use split-screen co-op's advantages to its best. The cinematic camera angles and changes of screen placements are pleasant and well designed. In the hospital level where the players take turns to controls their characters in full screen, the use of cinematic transitions and long camera shots are amazing. The different choices that the players can vote on could have some influence on how the game plays. These choices don't change anything major, but they make some parts of the levels different.The story of A Way Out is great and the endings are unexpected and emotional. The characters are pretty well made, and their emotions seem real. There are many mini-games scattered around the story for the players to compete with each other. Some of them are not well made, but it's always fun to mess around with a friend and have a little fun.At some later parts of the game, the characters get guns and start shooting people. The aiming is a bit weird, especially if you are playing with a controller. Those parts just feel like a cheaper and more boring version of Uncharted 4 without all the grappling hooks and moving around the environment.There is barely any game out there that targets split-screen co-op as a major selling point except for A Way Out. I highly recommend trying it out with a friend or family member. I hope there are more good co-op story-driven games like this in the future.

reviews.text: Even though the game's brilliant mechanics seem bluntly obvious in hindsight, A Way Out was kind of a revelation when I first started playing. Most co-op games I've experienced involved playing  to somebody else, where your respective lines rarely intersected in a significant way except during combat when you both happened to whack the same guy. A Way Out tangles up your lines and throws the two of you into sticky predicaments where you have to  together, and not just fight together. Communication and coordination are very important and you are just as dependent on your companion's poor timing as they are on your shoddy aiming. This results in some genuinely tense collaborative moments and a good amount of laughter (under which some quiet grumbling can be tucked away) when things don't pan out.Fortunately, the game is fairly easy as its main focus is the narrative and the interaction between the two protagonists. The story is the third protagonist by the way, and it provides the perfect premise for your synchronous shenanigans. But it also does so much more, as it is the main driving force behind the whole game, propelling your characters into one scruffy escapade after another. The puzzles and fights you encounter, while very light on gameplay, are woven cleverly into the narrative. Your mutual efforts feel practical as well as natural, and reinforce the two men's cooperation through your own blundering attempts at assisting one another. The sense of striving and failing together seeps from the real world to the game world, smudging your own feelings over your character's in a nebulous blend, and creating an incredibly immersive and convincing co-op experience.

reviews.text: A Way Out is a coop story driven game where two players work together to achieve their goal.This is exclusively a coop game, I have nothing against it but I think it should have a solo mode which shouldn't hurt and only would make it to sell better.The game plays in split-screen despite if you're playing local or online. There are some spoiler sensitive scenes I can't speak about where this didn't make any sense.The story is quite good, it comes from the developers of Brothers a Tale of Two Sons. There are two characters – Vincent and Leo. They meet in the prison and decide to break out of it for revenge.From the very beginning you need to learn to work together to bypass various situations and threats. While the game is mainly story driven I wouldn't call it a fully narrative experience. There's quite some gameplay there and it's pretty diverse. Mostly you'll be walking around or sneaking while figuring out how to get to where you need. Which isn't hard by the way, there are no real puzzles. But it has other gameplay mechanics like rowing the boat, driving and shooting. While all of these usually are very poorly executed in similar games, here they work well. Of course don't expect super deep driving physics or shooting mechanics but driving feels smooth, sometimes it feels like a proper racing game. And shooting is also decently done and isn't clunky at all, mostly it works as cover based shooter.Gameplay changes often and there's always something new so the game doesn't become boring or repetitive.You do stuff by pressing or tapping buttons, sometimes in perfect sync with another character, there are no moments when another character has nothing to do. There are sections when one character is more busy than the other but at these moments you still can explore the surroundings, speak with people or play some mini-games. There are mini-games for both players too. Oh and i encourage you to speak with people since that leads to some funny dialogues and little stories. On top of that there are easter eggs which are tied to achievements and roughly half of them are really fun to do because they lead to some short cut-scenes, mostly funny ones.In general gameplay is nearly perfect and has perfect amount of everything, calm moments of silence, talking, action, running and so on. It feels like a really long movie.Graphically the game looks good. Surroundings are beautifully crafted with lots of small details around and things to interact with while character models are good but could be better, it's nowhere near Man of Medan or Quantic Dream games. Although facial animations and expressions are quite good.Performance is perfect, game runs on max settings at 90-100fps easily, played on 5800x, 2070s, 32gb @3440x1440. There's ultrawide support but it's weird. Sometimes when there's a scene of only one character the image is in correct aspect ratio but smaller with black space around it. But there are some moments when the screen space is fully utilized so ultrawide works.Voice acting and sound are good too. Music feels like it's from a movie and plays along nicely with the mood of the scenes. Voice acting sometimes could be ok only but mostly it is good.Overall a very good coop story driven game with diverse gameplay, cool movie-like action scenes and dramatic moments. Definitely worth a buy. Not at full price though since the game is short and has no replayability value. Achievement hunting and another ending could net you an additional hour or so since it has chapter select but that's it.

reviews.text: Played this game with a friend and we both enjoyed it a lot!Definitely too short for the expensive price but if you get it on sale (got it for 9€) then it's really worth it! ~7 hours to finish the story while taking your time and messing around a little. You are two inmates, one who just got incarcerated and another one who has been there for 6 months already. You quickly realise that you both ended up in prison because of a crime boss named Harvey and you decide to escape prison to take revenge on him.The prison is actually just a small part of the game, your adventure will go much farther than those walls! The characters will get to learn about each other and decide on what to do to reach their goal. The story is kinda typical but there are some twists that we personally didn't expect at all. In any case it was very enjoyable and we were completely immersed in it (you feel it when you or your partner is in danger!). The screen is split in two so you can both see what the other is doing and when something important is happening to one character then his screen will extend and cover the other one for a bit. The same thing will happen if there is a shared cutscene, but this time making the two screens fuse. This feels a little weird at the beginning, but you quickly get used to it and it's really nice to see what the other is up to, especially when you split up.The story is divided into scenes/chapters. You go to a place, you do this, then you move on to another scene. You can usually mess around in the scenes and they are big enough to not feel trapped. But it does feel sometimes that you are jumping from one to another a bit hastily.The two characters have very different personalities and will not react the same way to things or dialogues. One is reckless while the other is more cautious. Sometimes when choosing a way to pass an obstacle you'll have to choose which character's plan to follow. But it's also in the little things: when prompted a character will break the locked window while the other will try to find another way. The choices, even the little ones, really help with the immersion.There are several puzzles (ex: how to get this thing out of this room without the guards noticing). From what I have seen, there are always several ways to reach your goal.There are some action scenes too, where you need for example to run away from things. Again, we were really into it and trying hard to succeed. If you fail though (which happens rarely because the emphasis is clearly put on the story/adventure and not on the challenge), you will be brought back to a nearby checkpoint.There are lots of little things scattered through the levels to have fun with your partner. There are often silly things: cut the wood because... why not? Play a board game or darts with your partner and get the highest score. And as silly and useless as it sounds, we would always seek them out to try them, because they were actually fun. Little hidden things throughout the levels; like tell this to that person, play that game, get this score, do this silly thing... Nothing annoying. You can replay a specific level so it was really easy to go back and get them all after our playthrough.

reviews.text: *UPDATE 2022 REVIEW AND GUIDE*The most common question asked below is why 2,000 hours? well I have now elapsed 4,000 hours across my accounts. So maybe the question I should have been asked is not would I refer this to my friends. To would I continue to play it more?And to that the answer is yes, despite all the  the game is very realistic it continues to add new maps and features and methods of fishing which push me to try new things. And one of the smartest fish AI in the world. When you have hooked a large fish and fought him for minutes or in many cases hours. the feeling up triumph is overwhelming.Overall Game play:First lets start with the most important. The game is very Grindy, Experience and level are easy to come by. However money and gear are much harder to acquire. Second lets talk about the realism. This is what keeps drawing me back. This game is the most realistic on the market. It is not just the graphics, it is how the fish fight, to wear and possible malfunction of your gear. It is such a challenge to chase a big fish down the stream knowing at anytime he could break your gear.Third is Mechanics. Mechanics are what is required to land a fish. Since shortly before Amber was released, was a mechanic implemented in the game. This mechanic causes the fish to nibble at your line setting off your alarm without taking the bait. You must be patient and watch for the rod to bend during a strike. However if you are currently engaged with another rod you may miss this exact time, and you are stuck reeling in a slack line. It is very easy to not catch fish because of this. It takes patience and experience in a already difficult game and even then you will miss a lot.Mechanics continued: because of the recent changed players are abandoning the game in droves. The developers seem to be more focused on the realism of there product than how it affects there player base.The mechanisms put into the game caused an increasing number of  When this happens in an already difficult game especially when fighting a large fish and without slack line the . Revenue: Every good game has a source of revenue. Competitors to this game must charge an initial fee or charge for download content. This Game Can be completely played Free 2 Play.This game source of revenue is premium and gold coins. Premium gives double experience as well as an increase chance of skill up %. Many will say you can actually set yourself back by buying premium at a low level. The theory is that you catch less fish per level, so less silver, and then you access maps which require heavier gear to fish. My own theory is different. While you absolutely should play this game for free if you can, If you do have the ability to buy premium it is to your advantage because; Every level you acquire more ability points. when placed in skills this can have a very great effect even increasing Trophy chances, also with the additional skill ups will decrease the grind considerably and allow access to higher rigs like PVA and Sand which baits sooner. If you do subscribe to premium please be careful to not over fish your gear, also in RF4 no matter premium or not there WILL come a day when you unlock a map you do not have the gear to fish. So fish with caution always.Gold coins are used for a variety of things, you can use it to purchase rods or reels. as well as there is bait some fish prefer which can be bought with gold coins or crafted.Hints & Tips:Dig! If you saw me fishing you would think this game was Russian Digging 4. A shovel costs 38 silver and can be acquired as early as level 3. Digging is a FREE (after you purchase the shovel) way of grinding up your bait harvesting. You will initially only dig up worms, but soon you will dig more and more baits. Eventually digging up Gold Baits which you would otherwise need to buy.Drink tea ?!? Ok 1st let me say this, there are many players in the game who almost never eat or drink. Your character can not die. One of my sources below has gone so far as to hide his stat bars with an overlay to make them look full because of the constant flow of people telling him to eat when he knew he did not need to. That said, Drinking Tea will make your energy rise faster. To Make tea you need a Packet of Tea from the grocery store, you need a tea kettle from the hardware store, and you need Firewood and matches also from the Hardware store.Hot Slot Coffee/Tea: You are given 5 action bars, I like to use my first 3 spots for my primary rods I am using. number 4 goes to my scoop/shovel and my 5th slot is coffee or tea. By hot slotting coffee/tea you can quickly drink it for an energy boost without needing to bring up the food menu, particularly important when fighting a big fish.Gear Advice:There are many ways to play this game, please play it your way. but this is my advice for maximum profitability. Buy 3 starter feeder kits from the tackle store (149 silver). These kits are well balanced and are a great value for a new player.Most players prefer to next move into a mid tier reel like the Caliber HSV or Narga. And while the Caliber HSV is the most popular pick I have seen a great many of them break! They have incredibly weak mechanisms. Kiltedjocks spread sheet below lists the Theoretical break points of reels and The caliber HSV lists as a maximum drag of 31.72 the Narga 8k is 44.6kg max drag. and even the cheaper Alfa 8k out performs the caliber hsv as the alfa's break point is 38.1 kg.The more you spend on mid tier reels and rods is up to you. As you really need to save for meta gear. This is just very grindy.Last Piece of advice: I myself was given poor advice on how to setup a rig. I should have known better. But I setup my rig faulty anyhow thinking on my poor advice. I nearly broke my rod, and I did near fatal damage to the blank (un-repairable).I was devastated. I took my time and hid in my embarrassment. But eventually I contacted rf4 support and calmly explained what I had done. RF4 was nice enough to repair my rod. This does not mean they will do it for you. They even told me this was a one time fix. If you have a problem contact supprt at Sources:I would not be able to be here giving this advice without having received so much knowledge from the following people. They have many more hours in the game than me. Please visit them drop a follow and say hi, then ask anything you want to know. They will gladly help you with rig advice, gear selection, they may know of a hot spot for you, and if they don't. Odds are someone in their chat does.Thank you so much for the Likes and Comments. And a special heart felt Thank You for the badges 🥰

reviews.text: Ah, Russian Fishing 4.An amazing game, but yet one that i advice you as a player to stay away from even after having played it for nearly 700 hours myself. However, the reason may not be what you would immediately expect. So let us not get ahead of ourselves, and instead first examine the pros and cons of the game:Pros==========- Very realistic in most aspects. Probably the most realistic fishing simulator on the market at the moment- A long progression path that will keep you "busy" for a very long time (i did not reach the "end game", although i came close)- A large selection of gear and fishing specialization paths for you to work towards and explore- Pleasantly and beautifully made lake maps- Overall gives a feeling of actually fishing rather than playing a game- A highly complex system of variables to take into account when catching fish. Among them the standard weather, temperature and time but also things like line type, line size, leader size, attachment visibility, gear and tackle qualities, fish migration, bait preference changes and much moreThat all sounds great doesn't it? So why the negative review? Well, let us move on to the cons:Cons==========- In several instances, the lake progression path does not make sense. This will often leave new players frustrated with broken gear fishing at places they do not have the correct gear for yet or simply no or few fish- In several instances, the crafting progression does not make sense. In RF4 you learn to harvest baits as well as making groundbait and lures. However, often in those progressions what you learn does not match the actual lake/fish availability.- In several instances, the store stock system especially will leave new players frustrated. Every lake has a certain set of stores in which many items will say "out of stock". For most items that actually means "will never be in stock", but the game does not explain this. Furthermore, crafting requirements often need components from particular lakes that do not fit with general player progression. In some cases when the player finally reaches a "checkpoint" in crafting, they have passed the need for that craft in the first place.- Bugs. Although this is an early access game, there is a large list of bugs, many of which are not recognized by the game management even though every "old" player know that they are present. These bugs include (but are not limited to) chat lag, IDs appearing instead of player names, store lag, selling lag, ghost bites, strange "fish got away" streaks that sometimes do not make any sense at all and much moreSo those were the general pros and cons of the game. But wait, there is more to be said about the game. You see, the game includes a place called the "penalty pond" or popularly called the "prison pond". This place is a specific "lake" map players are sent to if they for some reason have a falling out with the management of the game. Having a "falling out" with the management can entail everything from what you normally see moderated in other games by a profanity filter to posting something on the forum or discord that is not the the general liking of the management.When you are sent to the prison pond, you will get a notification that you have to catch X amount of weight of fish to get out again. Mind you, the fish in the prison pond (i am told) are all small, so having to f ex catch 10 kilos of fish may very well take a very long time. Not exactly a fun prospect in a game which a player originally decides to play for just that - fun!The philosophy behind the prison pond isn't all that bad though in my opinion. However, you may suddenly find yourself on the receiving end of the stick for a supposed violation that you do not understand or agree with. And at this point you will have no choice but to bow down and catch your small penalty fish effectively wasting your time and metaphorically speaking agreeing that you were rightfully penalized, or quit the game. It does not matter if you have played 10 hours, 100 hours or 1000 hours. The management are generally not open for debate.This leads me to one such example that happened to me yesterday after having happily played the game for 675 hours. We were several people chatting in a private channel and the debate was about the prison pond and what got you sent there. It was generally agreed that profane words were a sure way to get sent to prison pond, but that you could get away with misspelling or abbrevations of such words.Myself, having never gotten sent to prison pond and considering myself a loyal player, at some point replied with a harmless personal opinion which included a four letter foul word. I did not think anything of it until about an hour later i found myself being teleported to prison pond.After this i stated my case on the forum as a technical issue, since i felt that the issue must have been a wrongly automated action. I was abruptly shut down and told that i violated the terms of service with a blacklisted word in my sentence. I then read through the whole of Russian Fishing 4's EULA (yeah, i had not read it beforehand, these days how many actually read these very large agreements written in legal speak?). To my large surprise i found nothing in the EULA stating that the sentence i wrote was in violation of it.I then posted about this, highlighting the parts of the EULA that could have had relevance but did not in my case. However, instead of having an adult conversation with the moderators, my post was deleted. I then reposted it. It got deleted. This repeated itself 4-5 times until an administrator posted a reply stating that i asked for an explanation of the ban and i got it. Ofcourse the administrator posted one of my earlier posts instead of the post where i was pointing out that i was not in violation of the EULA which is terribly convenient. At the same time my posts were marked for moderation approval, which in other words meant that i was cut off.So there you have it. Russian Fishing 4 is a great game in many aspects, but it comes with a serious flipside to the coin. In its current state i can not recommend it, as you as a player might get hit with the same misfortune as i did, effectively wasting very many hours of otherwise enjoyable play.But do not just take my word for it here. Plenty of review have complaints like mine but nothing to back it up with. Luckily i saw the direction things were headed in, and captured screenshots of the conversations so that you as a potential new player will know what you will be up against before deciding to play:Some of the screenshots may be in the wrong order or overlapping slightly, and i apologize for that. Regardless, should you decide to play anyway you may want to have the above in mind. Good luck and have fun :)

reviews.text: Alright, I got 160 hours into this game, made it to high level to play all the maps, and now I feel I can give my honest review of the game.It needs A LOT of work. It IS NOT pay to win, meaning there is at no point of the game you need to purchase anything to continue playing EXCEPT, that it is, and I will explain how.The concept of this game is great, you start out as a character that has never fished before, has a limited amount of money, and is trying to start out. As you go to enter the tackleshop, you see reels and rods in the thousands of silver cost, and you started out with a measely 50 silver. So you think, shouldnt be too hard to save up. Wrong. Each fish you catch will average about 0.05 silver, if you catch a nice size fish, it will jump up to about 1.20ish at low levels, if you catch a trophy, it will be around 10-20 silver for the fish, but a trophy fish is extremely rare, only 1 caught out of the 160 hours of fishing I have put into this game. By the time you make it to level 12, you might have enough silver to buy a LEVEL 5 SET UP, and at this lake, are fish that will literally destroy it, or take 45 minutes of your time away trying to land a fish worth 5 silver. The money can start coming in at level 16 when you hit kouri lake, but the thing is, now you need level 16 gear AT LEAST to land these fish, and these reels and rods will be about 900-1400 silver EACH. Even at Kouri (one of the best silver per hour maps) you will make on average 100-200 silver AN HOUR. A decent reel at level 20 costs 2000 silver, so you will be looking at 10-20 hours of grinding, and not spending any of it, just to get a reel. Then as your usin that reel to save for a better rod or say even another, you will start to notice it just doesnt have the stopping power it use to, oh guess what, you got to repair it! Repair costs for the reel will be anywhere from 30-70% of the cost of the reel to just repair. So in the long run, no this game does not have a pay to win wall where you cannot advance anymore. It has one discretely, giving you the option to continue the game for free and literally not get anywhere, or buy gold and premium time to repair your rod and reels without spending insane amount of silver, along with no wait time. I would much rather pay $60 for a game, than a free to play game with microtransactions. Also, if it was not for some people to pass down there gear to me at lower level, I wouldn't of even commited 10 hours into this game. EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO GET STARTED. ALL THE SHOPS ARE OUT OF LOW LEVEL GEAR, NO INTENTION OF A FIX.more info on the game can be found on their website/forumsI only recommend this game if you dont mind a grind, can't get out fishing, and just simply love to fish, but today, I cannot recommend the game for anyone to try given its current state.For me it was fun while it lasted, but the grind isn't fun to me anymore.

reviews.text: Russian Fishing is the best fishing sim out there. I have played it since before it was translated, way before the Steam release. A mid-level rod + reel and assorted baits will easily set you back $50. It's actually cheaper to go fishing IRL.* If you decide to bite the bullet and invest RL money in gear, you'll find that this is a beta and rules can change. One day, rods can be repaired. Suddenly, rules change and your expensive rod can become perma-broken. And not through hundreds of hours of play: Just getting your line stuck will do it. Ooops, hahah, beta! And there goes your money.This game has everything to be awesome. Instead, it got mired in its punishing economy. Play it if you're content with tossing out a float but expect to never see most of the XP-locked content.

As comepensation they gave everyone 10 days of prem, but regarless if you lost anything or not.When you ask for the exact amount the skillpoints buff your chances on a trophy, you get no answer cause they know that those numbers are stupidly low. Which brings me to the things that are still going wrong in game.1: Still no exact numbers of how much skill points buff your skills, for all of them.2: Skill progression for Harvesting, groundbait and lures is way too slow even with premium. To get 100% in harvesting for example you need ~1000h of "normal" skilling or invest an abnormal amount of silverSkill progression of the fishing techniques is ok, if you have premium, cause it doesnt limit your gaming experience that much.3: Leaders and live baits(except for frogs, they are op). Since the introduction of fluoro leaders the steel ones are basically useless cause you get 1 fish/h and with fluro you just get snapped by the first bigger pike. I dont get how this is considered real by the devs. I fish with steel leaders exclusively when spinning cause there are pike in my water and never had any trouble hooking said pikes, zander or catfish.The problem with live bait is similar. even with fully skilled live bait you still catch only small fish.( my record is a pike that was smaller than the bait) The whole reason to fish with live bait is to get bigger fish at the cost of bite rates. reviews.text: After a bit more than 400 hours, I suppose I can finally feel confident I know enough to review this game. I'll focus on the questions you might have when you see a free fishing game and the tags it has, or at least the questions I had when I first saw it. So without any more delay, here's my thoughts on Russian Fishing 4.The big one- "Free". How free is it? I have not paid for over 400 hours now and I've enjoyed my time fishing. So I would say it is very viable to play for free. The price for premium is roughly on par with a normal MMO's subscription at 12 euro/month.  You get a few perks out of it, but mostly it's just extra exp so you get to level up faster and get to unlock other areas and skills easier.As for the multiplayer aspect, I find this one just straight up weird. Only a few parts of this game appear to have any multiplayer to it. Aside from those parts it is essentially a single player game. These parts are a leaderboard and chat function. That one explains itself and makes sense. A competition system, but it isone that I've never found a use for since all the contests are in Chinese or Russian. So I have no idea what they're asking, and they seem to be limited to higher level players anyway so for about 300 hours I never qualified to get in even if I could read it.The ability to send items to other players only if you have paid for premium, and lastly the shop inventory can be sold out if other players buy a lot of it in a short time period.You do not get to sit next to a friend when fishing, see others fishing, or even really see what other people do at all. Your only interaction with others is through the chat window, and the occasional message in chat when someone catches a sizable fish.The gameplay- It's fishing. You cast lines and reel in fish. You can fish with bait both by float fishing and bottom fishing, and with lures both from the shore and by trolling. The way you fish seems to have an effect on how well you catch things, while time, temperature and weather matter as well. The detail is better than any I've seen before, and it feels like you can actually control what you catch and whether you're successful by paying attention to the circumstances. The gameplay itself is good. You sell fish you've caught for money or can release them for bonus experience, but that's not really an option. You need the money.The progression however is less good. I've spent a lot of time on it and I still use some of the beginner gear, and I've still not unlocked most of the areas. You never get enough money to buy anything, and I know you're thinking they want you to buy the premium currency for it to skip the grind, but they don't really support that. If you buy premium currency to get gear you will need to spend around the price of an actual physical fishing rod to get early to mid level gear. And that gear will deteriorate very quickly, requiring that you pay even more to get it repaired.It is honestly cheaper to just buy a fishing rod and go do actual fishing than it is to try to spend money on gear in this game.Your progression is limited mostly by money. You can unlock new places by leveling up, but what use do you have for a place known for fishing large carp if they'll destroy your gear with ease and then just swim away? Progression is very rough and there is no way to get around it. You will always be struggling for money and be limited by your gear.In conclusion, while I find it very strange how they handled balancing just about anything I have enjoyed my time playing Russian Fishing 4 and would recommend giving it a try. If you enjoy the gameplay and just want to sit down and fish, you might enjoy it too. But don't expect to reel in huge fish, or even just somewhat big fish. You're going to be fishing in the same waters with your small rods for a very long time before you can unlock anything else.
