reviews.text: A masterpiece of a game, I know this word is overused a lot, but truly one of the most immersive games Ive ever played, you don't play through metro exodus, you live through it. A wonderfully crafted story that will take you through different parts of russia, different climates, different times of year and weather, as you encounter all sorts of different crazy characters, lots of baddies but also some truly good ones, it feels like a journey of a lifetime and for most if not all the characters on board your train - it is. The game centers around your exodus from snowy nuclear winter moscow into the wilderness of the rest of russia, as you travel across it on a train fittingly named Aurora, the goddess of dawn. Each member of your crew feels like a real human being and they are all very talkative, happy to share with you their thoughts and feelings over a smoke break or a cup of questionable beverage, despite your character being mostly a mute (only ever talking during loading screens) the game plays with it pretty well. Sadly I can not tell you more about the story, because its a thing thats best enjoyed yourself without any spoilers or tips.Now, why did I say it was immersive and you live through it, well simply put, its because it lets you become the main protagonist, it never breaks character and you feel as you are part of the story, you are not just a player, you are Artyom, there are no cutscenes, instead there are moments when you lose control of your character, but its all always done in first person, you shake hands, you hug characters, you give toys to children or items to your crew members, all done in first person. You get attacked by mutants and have to free yourself in first person with a quicktime event (which has several accesibility options so you dont have to mash a button like a crazy person), you row boats and drive vehicles, you push buttons and pull levers, open or close doors, but all with a proper animation, you have to recharge your flashlight manually with a portable charger, put your gas mask on and off, put the nightvision googles on, wipe the dirt off your mask, fix it up quickly, burn some spider webs with your lighter which can cause some spiders to crawl all over your hands and face and so much more that I am probably forgetting, but you get the idea. There is only really one menu of sorts and thats the crafting one, still the game tries its best to make even that feel realistic and part of the world too.Now, all the immersion aside, what about the gameplay itself you might ask? Well its simply fun and allows for different style of play and approach, several different difficulty settings allow for any kind of player, from a casual to hardcore, from story enjoyer to immersion freak, you can set it all up yourself. You get to fight all sorts of different beasts but also humans. Speaking of humans, there are basicly always 2 options for you, stealth or combat and you always have the choice which one you pick. Combat is only forced in one single chapter/mission but i would argue you are not truly fighting humans at that point but rather beasts in human form, play it and see for yourself :) Stealth however is never forced on you. So you might be wondering, why would you ever want to stealth then? Well aside enjoying stealth itself you might wanna do it because of the karma system in this game, same as previous games, the ending of your game will depend on how much of a humanist you were during your playthrough. See, while there are factions in this game that are truly evil and they know it, those you are allowed to kill as much as you want, bandits, raiders, slave owners, you know, that kind, there are several factions that are not evil and are just defending themselves from you, the intruder into their world, with those, you might wanna rethink your approach and maybe try to stealth and spare them, speaking of sparing people, even the bad guys sometimes will surrender, as a rule of thumb the last survivor of a group of bandits prefers to surrender than die like the rest of his gang, at that point killing them would also give you bad karma. The karma system does not just end the game differently, it changes the way other characters react to your actions and interract with you, it changes the endings of several chapters of the game before the game end itself, all in all, as you might realise now, it calls for at least 2 playthroughs, oh and there is also new game +.As far as DLC goes, both are great even if they play out fairly differently. The Two Colonels is a more linear one of the two, jumping between 2 different time periods and 2 different characters, hence the name, it tells a great story of the struggle of one colonel between his duty as a soldier and his obligations as a parent of a young child, a great story all in all, even if a sad one at that. Sam's Story is a bit more open one, like the base game, and takes place after the end of Metro Exodus main story, Sam, the only american in your russian crew takes on a long journey in his attempt to leave russia and finally come home to his parents that may or may not still be living in whats left of usa. Not only is Sam an interesting character in both the base game and the dlc (being an american in post nuclear war russia aint easy) but he is also voiced by the legendary Steve Blum, that you might know from Cowboy Bebop as the voice of Spike Spiegel. I forgot to mention, both him and the colonel from the other DLC are not mutes at all, since you are no longer Artyom, they talk and they talk a lot, both in-game and during loading screens, so prepare to hear lots from them during gameplay.This review is getting kinda long, so ill try to wrap it up for you here. The graphics are great but also demanding, especially so the enchanced edition that you get for free for owning the base game, so do check the requirements and how well it performs online. The audio design is absolutely awesome, the music gives that extra atmosphere to the setting, be it during combat or calmer moments and overall the sound is solid, the weapons and monsters especially so, the guns feel powerful, loud and real and the mutants feel scary, strong and sometimes plain disgusting. (like giant spiders or worms, definently do NOT buy if you have arachnophobia). There are however occasional bugs,  I did not encounter anything game breaking, but I did see an occasional t-pose of an enemy i already killed or like when the combat music got stuck for me once and kept playing despite me being out of any combat and then just randomly fixed itself later, one enemy once phased through several tables and a window to get to me which gave me a light scare, the bugs are rare but they do exist, its nowhere near cyberpunk or fallout but its not 100% perfect either, so i felt i need to address it. Does it ruin the game? No, absolutely not and it gets my recommendation, It is a 10/10 game for me, that left me amazed and only wishing for more and a sequel. Speaking of sequels, Metro Exodus is a sequel, so I highly advice you get Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light, since its all one connected story, I would argue Exodus is a bit more independent from the previous games, still, you will not understand a lot of plotpoints if you have not played the previous ones and those games are masterpieces too, so get the whole trilogy when you get the chance. I came to play as Artyom for the third time, but instead I lived as him from start to finish, a wonderfully crafted story-driven adventure, that shows how do to both storytelling and immersion into the gameworld right, It grabs you and does not let you go till you are done, a rare but true 10/10, get it and you wont regret the money and time spent :)

reviews.text: Hands down my favorite game in the Metro Series. There is less of mystical stuff. Game is generally focused on post-apocalyptic survival and exploration. I consider Metro Exodus a fully fledged AAA first person story game. That's a mouthful, but it is a great leap forward for the series as a whole. Previous two  titles were AA quality, but still awesome. Metro Exodus is excellent.So what does make Metro Exodus stand out? It is a newer game with gorgeous graphics, well-crafted and adequately paced story, which are all mixed with horror/stealth/action gameplay. You can go Rambo if you want too. I'm obviously touching the tip of an iceberg here. If you are into Fallout or Mad Max games, you should definitely give Metro Exodus a try. The previous two games were strictly linear, whereas Exodus spiced things up with open-world levels. All of main story and side quests will affect the ending of the game. Thus, you might actually play the game twice to get the ending you think fits better.As in previous games, you make moral choices. This time around you have well-designed side characters, who will be affected by the choices you make. After completing a level, you might catch yourself listening to side character dialogues for additional information. The world around you feels alive, and your allies are there to share their opinion on your actions too. For example, I made a call to follow a side character's advice, they brought it up in their smoking break chat like 5 hours later in the game. Your allies also get stuff done and save your ass out of trouble, so it does not feel like a Fallout 4 settlement, where you have to change everyone's diapers and get everything done by yourself.I don't want to give away anything important about the game's story, but it is great. Sometimes it is difficult to keep the fans excited, but I was seriously impressed that there was so much more beyond the lore of the previous two games in the series. Metro Exodus took everything I liked about the original two games, and just expanded upon them. I like how there is a good mix of linear and open world levels. This is how single player games should be made. You manage your ammo, weapons, loot either on a go or at a work bench. Looting in complete darkness with spiders behind you is something. The campaign is much longer and might feel tiresome. Use the quick save to take breaks from the game. It took me 40 hours to finish the game thoroughly and Rambo combat, whereas stealth style was only 20 hours. In my second playthrough I did my best to get certain things done in the story,  and it paid off with new cut scenes and noticeable gratitude from side characters. The campaign is great, really.Graphics. Well wow! I played the game with Extreme graphics and Ultra RTX. Well I can't go back to regular graphics after that. RTX Global Illumination makes the lighting and shadows look too real. Every corner, passage, or a room are properly lit up resulting in an extreme immersion especially in dark spooky areas. I beat the game twice, once without RTX and once with RTX on. I caught myself using the night vision goggles in the areas that weren't even dark without RTX. I get it that vast  majority of players haven't experienced the game with RTX, but it is still worth pointing out. Metro Exodus looks great either way, but it really feels next gen with RTX maxed out.The game is buggy. I have previously lost about 15 hours of gameplay. I was mad; thus it took me about 6 months to get back to the game. It is especially frustrating that nearly two years since the game's launch, it hasn't been properly patched yet. There are still levels with shaky frame rate. Vaulting was finally added to the game, but it is not perfect either. Sometimes I can't initiate it. In retrospect, I can't even imagine what the early days of the game were like. Glitches galore probably.Considering PC specs and experience with the bugs, opinions may vary. I did not even mention the last minute dump  to another launcher prior to the game's launch.  Metro Exodus is an excellent game with noticeable improvements from previous games. It is a buggy AAA attempt from a AA studio. However, the main story is so great that I will give this game the benefit of the doubt. It is a must play for the fans of a single player genre.Edit: this is my GOTY on Steam!

reviews.text: Metro Exodus (ME) is a first-person shooter game with survival horror and stealth elements. It has been developed by the company 4A Games and published by the company Deep Silver.++ Journey across the post-apocalyptic Russia on a train with your heavily armed friends. Revisit the claustrophobic tunnels of Moscow, shake hands with cultists on Volga's frozen tundra, liberate slaves in the desert of the Caspian, play hide and seek with the tribes in Taiga's lush forests, and sneak around blind gorillas within the irradiated ruins of a dead city.+ I like most of the characters because they are well written, and the game gives you enough opportunities to support them. My favourites are Stepan and little Nastya; I could not refuse her plea for the heroic rescue of a teddy bear.   + Solid addons. Both of them illuminate the events around side characters that you will encounter during the main storyline. - The depiction of Colonel Miller, a hardened veteran and military leader, as a naive and irrational commander lacks credibility. And believe me, thoughts of mutiny crossed my mind several times.- Occasional FPS drops, irregular crashes, and corrupted save games. I have experienced all of it, and it boils down to... *switches to a Russian accent* completely normal phenomenons.-- Taking the game out of the Steam store, two weeks before its release, is referred to as a d*ck move in the gamer scene.I consider ME to be a great continuation of the series, and the strongest part of the franchise. It has surprised me with its open world aspects and gripping storyline. Alas, the overall impression is tarnished by technical issues, and the rushed cooperation with the EPIC Games Store for temporary exclusivity. You can do better 4A Games and Deep Silver.Recommended for fans of the post-apocalypse and gas mask fetishists. reviews.text: Metro Exodus is hands down the crowning achievement of the Metro franchise. It brings Artyom and company out of the claustrophobic metro tunnels of 2033 & Last Light, and into the daylight of POST-apocalyptic Russia, in all its glory. Never before has a game so effectively blended the polish of a linear FPS with the freedom of a reactive open world, while capturing a Slavic atmosphere which rivals that of blin-kingpin S.T.A.L.K.E.R. itself. Exodus takes Metro to fantastic new heights while cutting out nearly all the lows, whether that be in gameplay, world-building, or storytelling. As a fan of the series for years, I’m happy to report that this  the sequel we were waiting for.Metro Exodus begins with the protagonist, Artyom, plagued by the suspicion that there is still human life left on the surface beyond the Moscow Metro system. You, as Artyom, have been making frequent dangerous excursions to the surface since the end of the previous game in the hopes of finding a radio signal to validate this theory. This causes strife with your wife, Anna, who is fearful that one day you won’t arrive home still breathing. As a consequence, she decides to come with you on one of your trips to the surface to watch your back. On that fateful day, Artyom and Anna discover; not a radio signal, but actual people who claim to hail from outside the city… as well as an operational locomotive train, capable of taking them – and the Spartan Order – across the country.Shifting to the graphics of Exodus, I have to say that they are entirely up to series standards. The art style is identical to that of its redux-ed predecessors, but every visual detail has been tweaked to breathtaking fidelity. Textures are photorealistic, faces are way beyond the uncanny valley in a positive direction, animations are fluid and numerous, the lighting is gorgeous to the point that its beauty exceeds real life, and all other technical components are practically flawless. The soundscape is noticeably (mostly) unchanged from the previous games, however there is a whole new soundtrack which accompanies Exodus’s atmosphere terrifically. As for performance, the game is demanding, but still well optimized. All in all, I’m absolutely taken by Metro Exodus’s presentation.Exodus is divided into roughly three separate maps throughout the course of the game, as well as a few more linear levels. While the settings themselves are gorgeous to the eye, from the swamps of the Volga River to the deserts of the dried up Caspian Sea, there’s also a lot to do. Each region has multiple objectives and locations, with secrets to uncover and loot to seize. There is a disparate theme to the individual provinces too, giving Exodus a real sense of variety. Notes and audio journals dot the world-space as well, revealing the history of a place and its people following the war. The several environmental stories told are enlightening, and sometimes even heart-rending. Altogether, Exodus’s environments are impeccably designed, and reward intense investigation.Metro Exodus, among other secondary features, utilizes an all new crafting and modification system, which I’d say is… a mixed bag. The crafting component of the game feels lazy, as there are only two materials to work with: metals and chemicals, which (annoyingly) functionally constitute 90% of the games lootable items – meaning most valuable consumables must be crafted. On the modification side of things, there’s a lot more to like. There are roughly ten base guns in the game, but each can be radically altered to work more effectively in different scenarios. Gear modification serves as the progression system, so it’s important to stay up-to-date with your weapons and accessories. There are a few more gameplay mechanics such as stealth, radiation, and vehicles, but all can be roughly summarized as ‘well implemented.’The Metro series is known for its atmosphere, and the immersion of its combat is a central element. I truly believe Metro Exodus has perfected the first-person impact of firing a gun; between the recoil and sound design, and even on down to the stopping power of each individual weapon. And good news – from bandits to mutant beasts, and slavers to the eerie humanimals, there’s a whole host of new adversaries to blast away across the scarred face of Russia. The AI of human enemies is quite sophisticated too, being able to call out your position to their allies if they spot you; relative to the objects around you. It’s also worth noting that you can defeat humans non-lethally, and that combatants will surrender if routed. Intricacies like these nested within Exodus’ combat system are what drive the gameplay, and make it uniquely satisfying.Refocusing on Exodus’s story, it’s a much better tale than that of the previous titles. For reasons I won’t spoil; you, Anna, Colonel Miller, and the rest of the Spartan Order travel eastward through post-apocalyptic Russia in the train found at the beginning of the game, which is quickly coined the . As the crew trek across the scorched earth of the motherland, seasons change, and new societies are discovered. The survivors of the nuclear holocaust have become vicious luddites, bandits, cannibals, and slavers – but a rare few have preserved their humanity. Eventually the Order’s goal becomes to find an untainted land to call home; a place where a civilized society can rebuild, and Artyom and Anna can raise a family.Whereas in past Metro games the supporting characters were side-pieces or even something of a nuisance, Exodus is much more character-driven in its storytelling. The blank stares of Bourbon and Khan are gone; replaced by the sensitive compassion of Stepan, cockiness of the impressionable Duke, and the  love of Artyom’s wife, Anna. The Aurora’s crew grows and changes with time, developing through the experiences they endure and the trials they overcome. If you care to bend an ear, your comrades will talk it off, expressing their thoughts, plans, hopes, and fears. While the translation of dialogue to English can be clunky at times, the character writing itself is just magnificent. The inspiring humanity of this small group of characters truly bring your goals as Artyom into perspective. The people of Metro Exodus are what make the whole experience.On a quick narrative note before my final verdict, I’d like to clearly express that Exodus tracks your moral status throughout the course of the 25-odd hour campaign. There are particular actions you can complete that will give you positive karma, and specific crimes you can commit that will accrue negative karma. How you interact with the game world and its characters will have consequences – not only in the form of separate endings, but in a cascade of different narrative outcomes. The Order’s exodus is a treacherous one, but the most perilous war is that of the one which rages .I feel my opinion on this game has been made fairly obvious by this point, but that doesn’t mean I won’t praise it further. Metro Exodus is one of the best games, period, that I have ever played. Its the culmination of what already was a phenomenal series, and Exodus pulls no punches in giving the trilogy a stupendously vast, enjoyable, meticulous, touching, and downright impressive send-off. I couldn’t have imagined a better way to conclude Artyom’s journey.

reviews.text: Excellent game. Won't blow your socks off, but literally brings fresh air into Metro series by introducing open world outdoor areas mixed with those claustrophobic indoors we've come to expect.You manage to escape Moscow and are now on train, searching for a refuge to settle in. That's basic plot.THE GOOD:+ Graphics. Soviet apocalypse has never looked better.+ Lengthy and immersive.+ Lot's of dialogue and interaction with friendly npc's, almost to the point of exhaustion. You    get to know them and their mindset fairly well. Between missions, you can spend 30min to    1hour inside the train, just listening their ramblings.+ Level variety. From metro tunnel settlements to frozen Volga to underground bunkers to    Caspian deserts to lush forests to new irradiated cities. There's a lot to see and ground to    explore. And exploration is rewarded well.+ More emphasis on stealth than before... BUT...+ Surprisingly stable. Has yet to crash even once for me.+ Excellent DLC's. The Two Colonels is a short one, but brings a light to the tragedy of    another Metro community we come across in the main game. And you get to play with a    flamethrower quite a bit. Sam's Story is a longer one and let's just say it tingled my    S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-senses, like, a lot. I'll leave it to that :)THE NEUTRAL:+ / - The story. Not bad nor super excellent. Pretty much what you expect from Metro games         in general: does the job with few nuances and that's it.+ / - Weapon and suit upgrade system is pretty basic but I'm glad it's there, because the high        end upgrades are awesome. THE BAD:- There's more stealth emphasis, yes, but the system is iffy. Sometimes enemies feel totally    blind but sometimes spot you no matter what you do. Too much trial and error in my book.- Weapon selection is still pretty much the same as in previous games. Only a few new ones. I   know that the Metro's world setting limits weapon selection, but c'mon. Where are all the   PKM's, SVD's, RPG-7's, civilian owned Mosin-Nagants, Tokarev pistols, different AK-variants   or underbarrel granade launchers? You'd think at least Stalkers would have found a few from   military depots... or locals would've turned those into something Metro-made.- Plenty of npc dialogue, but mostly it doesn't lead anywhere. No new mission objectives,   revelations or anything. Just the mundane stuff. And Artyom still doesn't reply or comment   anything. A simple commenting choice á la Titanfall 2 would've spiced things up a notch.- The main story has a pretty big revelation about the current world situation in the first hours   of the game, but sadly this isn't expanded upon later in the game. I think the game would   benefit from tidbits of information about what events lead to the apocalypse and how the   current world is beyond Russia.__________________________________________________________________________All in all? If you liked previous Metro-games, this is a no-brainer (dlc's included). If you're new to the series: story wise, I recommend you play the first two redux installments first. With every installment, the Metro series has gotten progressively better. Definitely looking forward to the next one!And Epic Store can seriously f*ck off.

Shame on them for being among the first who set this train (no pun intended) in motion.Now when that's out of the way, let's get to the actual review:Metro Exodus is a game that was a bit rushed, just like many other games. It gets pretty obvious in the last two chapters and one can feel it in many aspects throughout the game, but it still manages to deliver. It provides experience that is somewhat different from previous games in the series, but it doesn't step away from it's core formula too much to alienate its core fanbase, at least in my opinion. I would also like to add that there's hardly anything left to be told about life in metro, so the devs made the right call when they decided to lead our characters on the surface and out of Moscow. Overall, the gameplay is okay (although they should really hire somebody with experience in designing FPS games), the story is pretty decent and all it's shortcomings are compensated with some really wholesome moments that you can spend with other characters. The graphics are nice, but the game is rather hardware-demanding and the sound design is, like always, superb.8/10. A game definitely worth buying for the series' fans, and actually a decent entry place for newcomers; although I would definitely recommend playing the games in their right order, if you wish to give it a try.

reviews.text: In light of all the upset currently surrounding Metro Exodus I wanted to provide my own, more middle of the road review. Everything I say here comes from someone who, while enjoying the Metro games, is by no means an overly supportive fan who would instantly love anything with the Metro name slapped on it. Nor am I willing to pretend I hate a game simply because others have decided it must be hated no matter what.As it has been the subject of many debates already I am going to avoid beating a dead horse here and refrain from giving too much discussion over the decision to remove the game from Steam in favor of exclusivity on the Epic store. All I will say about this is that I find it to be a very underhanded move, but my frustration lies with Epic and Deep Silver’s corporate team, who are ultimately the ones who made this decision. I find the hate aimed towards the devs of Metro, who typically have no say in such decisions, to be misguided. Especially when they have obviously poured a lot of love into a game that has had its launch marred by a decision that was out of their control. I happened to preorder Exodus just about a week before the removal from Steam was announced, but in the interest of full disclosure I will admit that had I not happened to catch it at this time I would be waiting a year for it to be back on Steam so as not to support the Epic store.First and foremost Exodus absolutely blew me away with the level design. You will find there to be a much greater variation in locations and scenery than ever before seen in a Metro game. Every single area you encounter is completely breathtaking in its own unique way, with an incredible amount of detail on just about everything. For a game that is meant to be played through slowly and deliberately this beautiful world-building absolutely pays off, as you find yourself really wanting to explore and take it all in. The world does manage to feel a lot more open than we might be used to with Metro, providing a lot more space for you to explore and figure out a stealthy approach into various situations. But this being said, the game is still very linear, as you are never wandering around aimlessly and still have various objectives which keep you moving straight from one area to the next. This feeling of having a bit more space and freedom provides a nice contrast to all of the time you will spend exploring dark, claustrophobia-inducing underground areas.I absolutely adore the characters, especially Anna, your ass-kicking wife. The game does such a good job at truly making you feel the love between her and Artyom, with their interactions coming off as being very honest and sincere. The story is very interesting and unique, and I found myself to be genuinely interested in seeing what would happen next. There are a number of lengthy cutscenes, which I found to be well-done and important to the story, but I feel it is worth mentioning as I know this is not for everyone. You will have chances to return to the train which is carrying you and your crew, a feature I greatly enjoyed. I really loved taking these opportunities to explore how the train had grown and changed, as well as interacting with the other passengers. This really helped give a feeling of realism to the characters, making you care about them and their fate.Overall I really enjoyed my time playing Metro Exodus, but there are a few glaring issues that need to be addressed. First and foremost, the optimization is absolutely terrible. Instead of being offered the ability to individually mess with each setting you are forced to pick from presets: Low, Medium, High, Ultra, and Extreme. This essentially forces you to pick whatever setting your rig can best handle, which means you will most likely be forced into a setting that is actually below the capability of your PC, simply because the next preset enables just one setting that is just slightly too much for your setup. Had there been more customization offered with graphics settings this could have been easily avoided.Another issue I had with Exodus are the completely random obstacles and/or invisible walls that I would run into and get stuck on. On quite a few occasions when exploring (or even worse, during a fight) I’d find myself randomly unable to walk over an area that looked as if you should be able to walk through it. While I love and appreciate the huge amount of detail in this game, it’s very frustrating to lose a fight simply because you found yourself caught on a twig.I also encountered a few bugs, mostly entertaining (like trying to leave my cabin on the train only to find myself soaring high above the map). But there were a few bugs that messed with my gameplay, most notably being an enemy that was somehow able to stick their gun through the wall to shoot at me. Exodus is a wonderful game that will greatly benefit from some patching. Had its release not been cast in a bad light due to a questionable business move then I feel it would be highly beloved right now. But those who are forced to wait until its return to Steam next year might actually find that this worked in their favor, as it will provide time for some final kinks to be worked out so that they may enjoy a great game the way it was meant to be played

reviews.text: You know an ending is good when you think "No. No. That can't be it. There's no way." and then the reality hits you. That was it. And that was the ending you got. Wow. I have nothing but praise for this game, especially in the story aspects. I've seen the Metro series before on Steam, just browsing, but I dismissed it for whatever reason. At the time of writing this, I've only played Exodus, but if this one game is anything to go by, I wish I hadn't dismissed it so quickly. It's... I've gone speechless again. It's amazing. The chapters each have good and bad endings, another thing I didn't expect, and it made the game feel...surreal, the way it judges you, if that makes sense. The characters feel... like family. Like you have to protect them, even if it means putting your life and your beautiful,Russian-man body on the line. There's moral dilemmas that I didn't realize I made a bad decision on until it was way, way too late. ().The gunplay is phenomenal. It feels... not realistic, that's impossible for a video game, in my opinion... It feels way more realistic than anything I've ever played, though. The way the guns are loud, a sharp crack in the silence, it's incredibly immersing. There are several guns, but I'll focus on the AK (Or Kalash/Kalashnikov, as it's called in this game). I haven't shot an AK, I've shot everything from pellet guns to AR's, but the way Artyom fires his AK is exactly what I expect it to be. A loud, sudden, sharp crack, followed by either a pained scream from the person or animal you just royally pissed off, or the deafening silence from whatever is on the recieving end of that barrel. Guns get dirty, and jam, too. It makes sense, to an extent, but it bothered me a little that Artyom could wipe blood or spider-goop off his visor easily in one swift *wipe*, but dusting that little bit of mud off the gun with his sleeve, his glove, or even a rag he may keep in his backpack? Heavens no, comrade. That's too nasty, even for big, strong, Vodka-loving Russian man.Stealth matters too. It can change the ending of the game. I usually stealth through everything, until I get shot at, then I fire back. It's not boring stealth though. There's elements like light exposure, your position, enemy lines of sight, sound, all making it very engaging in practice. The enemy AI isn't completely retarded either. It can pass as realistic.Easy 94/100. I cannot praise this game enough. There were only a few minor details, like the previously mentioned gun cleaning, that annoyed me in any way, shape, or form. I got it for $15.99 on sale on a whim because I was bored, and I found myself lying awake late last night, 7 hours into the story, thinking "I want to keep playing Exodus, but I need to go to bed already."

reviews.text: I played this excellent game not too long after release, and really loved every minute of it. Metro Exodus takes everything that was great about Last Light (which took everything that was great about 2033) and made it even better by opening up the world and sending you on a pretty  adventure lol. The story of Metro Exodus is most decidedly one of hope. While I'm sure you can get a less than good feeling ending, I think I got pretty much the best one in my estimation. It really left me wanting more Metro, but also gave me the sense that the world was about to start changing for the better.I'd also note that the writers did an excellent job of humanizing pretty much every character in the game. Even the least human of them lol. Everyone had motivations that made sense, and your merry band of train dwellers were especially easy to grow attached to.Speaking of trains, you probably already know the gist of the story. Seeing the end of the Metro system is clearly in sight, Artyom and crew embark upon a journey to see if there are any habitable places left in the land above. The journey really ends up being a captivating ride across the Russian post apocalypse, with memorable quests and some nice story twists. Plus, how you interact with the story will directly impact the outcome of your playthrough.Honestly, the gameplay was consistent with Last Light, if refined a bit. They abridged the currency system. Crafting also has seen a nice upgrade. The weapons are of course very customizable and the specifics will be largely dependent on how you choose to play this or the needs of the moment.While the classic claustrophobic Metro gameplay is still there, it isn't as pervasive, and of course, as I'm sure you know, a lot of the game is spent aboveground (although missions still tend to end up underground in creepy as hell locations). Some of the classic enemies make their notorious return in Exodus, but there are also new enemies to reflect the new circumstances. One minor gripe: the developers do love those light hating spiders, but me personally, I find them annoying.Anyway, the game is also a limited open world, with a few different regions and terrains. There are also people living above ground, and in fact, many of them never had a chance to get to a Metro system to avoid the nuclear apocalypse. Overall, with the notable exception of this being more of an open world game, I think fans of the series will find a lot they are already familiar with, but with some nice upgrades.Yeah, these are the type of graphics that never cease to impress. Seriously, the game is pretty stunning in every way. Set pieces, character animations...this game has it all. It will also definitely let you know where your rig stands lol. Personally, I played using a 1050ti on Medium to High settings, and it definitely struggled at times (typically when there were a LOT of enemies on screen at one time), but outside of those moments, the game handled fine in my estimation. The game crashed four times during my playthrough, which, given how much this game can stress a system, seemed like a mild victory lol.Yeah. This game definitely features some unforgettable scenes, graphics, and artwork. Also, the cutscenes were top tier. Truly evocative and imaginative imagery.Again, this game really utilizes everything available, from excellent ambient sounds to the sounds of interaction and combat, to the actual conversations. Everything was particularly well done, and that voice acting? I think all the actors should feel proud of their work here. Not only were they on point, but they really convey emotion, and a wide range of such. This game runs the gamut of emotion, and the actors did a spectacular job of recognizing, honoring, and then actually pulling it off in such a way as to really make you care about each and every character.Oh..and that soundtrack. So diverse and emotional! Excellence bar none. Enjoy!For me, the Metro series is and will continue to be one of my all time favorites, and Exodus only served to strengthen my love for it. This is one hell of a game, with a ton of replay value, so many feels, and excellent gripping gameplay.  It is however also worth noting that you don't necessarily need to have played the previous games to both enjoy and understand this one. They do a great job of filling in the blanks, in my opinion.

reviews.text: Metro games are made with passion. The series expounds on what was previously derived from the novel  by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky, that was later produced into a movie, , by Andrei Tarkovsky, that inspired the Metro book series, before it finally making its way into video games. Metro Exodus is the third entry in this series. And it might be the greatest.Whether it checks that box for the consumer depends on if returning players, or newcomers, can handle the holistic changes that come packaged within Exodus. It’s a different game from its progenitors. It provides fundamental Metro gameplay, but it is now expanded within the context of open-sandbox environments. Which is a stark contrast from the on-the-rails story beats returning players might expect. Metro Exodus elected to give the player the power to create their own set pieces. And it was a risk, but a calculated one.The creators were most certainly attempting to broaden their consumer base while also being mindful of those returning (although Epic Store–timed exclusivity kind of screwed that up anyway). But alterations from the norm were a success. Metro Exodus is fantastic.  In the wake of apocalyptic nuclear war, the Metro series follows the surviving inhabitants living in the old Moscow Metro, or subway system. Metro stations have become towns and the remaining populace has formed collectivist ownership over these towns. Over time, each station established its own unique identity. Some friendly, some not. Previous Metro titles (Metro 2033 and Metro: Last Light) tasked the player with navigating the metro, warring with self-radicalized stations, and dealing with irradiated monsters that now stalk the tunnels.Exodus is about Artyom, the series’s protagonist, leaving Moscow with a squad of series regulars on a year-long journey across Russia. The game opens remarkably similar to previous entries. The player traverses a frozen Moscow landscape, journeys through a metro station, and is otherwise exposed to linear narrative threads. None of this is tedious though. The Metro series has already showcased how adept it is at handling linearity. Mostly, it does it through atmosphere and mood, which continues to be exhibited in Exodus. Artyom has always been a silent protagonist, the exception being his journal entries that are voiced during loading screens. Exodus keeps the same format, and in doing so, handles expository information well. It is difficult to competently and realistically disseminate exposition in a meaningful way with a mute character, so it’s amazing how effortlessly Exodus does it. The player naturally learns of the events that happened between Last Light and this current story, the most important of which is that Artyom’s lover, Anna, remains as such.Events take place that cause Artyom and his crew to leave Moscow for the Russian countryside via locomotive. After that, familiar linearity of old metro systems is mostly abandoned in favor of successive, unique sandboxes that change as each chapter progresses. And they’re all astounding.After leaving Moscow, the story proceeds through four unique chapters that all feature different playscapes. Mostly these areas offer aesthetic differences that revolve around the seasons in which your crew visits them. Basically, expect the summer area to feel hotter and the autumn area to feel colder. The first three sandboxes, in particular, elect to give up control to the player to create their own action within the various locations constructed. It is obviously an enormous risk to create a Metro game that doesn’t take place in, well, a metro. But they had reason to bet on themselves.The creators were able to split the difference between their typical, linear narrative structure and popular open-world exploration. This was achieved by not making any one area have  much to do or be  big to explore. Artyom has a map of each region, and that map is highlighted with areas of importance. Some of these highlights feature a monster’s nest to destroy or a bandit’s camp to clear, while others contain pertinent story points.  It really works.  Exodus swapped tunnels for open landscapes featuring a day-and-night cycle. The same emotions that the player previously felt exploring the darkness of the metro is again achieved through this approach. It is still extremely immersive, and surprisingly eerie, to traverse Exodus’s landscapes in intense darkness, surrounded by things that want to kill you. The environments are different. The atmosphere is the same.An absolute must when developing sandboxes is that there exists an inherent mechanical reason for the player to explore them, in addition to narrative motivations. If not, the game is just as on-the-rails as before, only now watered down with unnecessary fluff. Fortunately, Exodus does provide a reason. Not only do the environments look interesting, they usually contain important crafting materials within. These resources are used to upgrade, modify, and clean Artyom’s equipment. And equipment can degrade rapidly depending on the situation. Which means nearly every collapsed building, dark tunnel, or campfire in the distance is worth checking out. Occasionally Artyom will run into members of his own squad while exploring these ruins, which adds to player immersion. The world just feels alive.Exodus tells a wonderful story. It features terrific characters, some of which were introduced in the previous games, and expands on their personas. There is, admittedly, a trope-ish element that exists here somewhat—there are tough characters, funny characters, and sweet characters. But if the player spends enough time listening to their conversations, they will eventually observe personalities that exist beyond their archetypes. Especially with Anna. Anna engenders immense pathos by the story’s conclusion, partly because the player is granted so many different, immersive ways to interact with her. All of which are extraordinarily additive. Maybe you’ll put your arm around her, or hold her hand, or brush her hair back. And while all of this is completely optional, it is hard to imagine any Metro player electing not to. Their relationship feels honest. Which is doubly an achievement when you consider that Artyom never utters a word. When certain circumstances arise that place Anna in extreme danger, there is an emergent need for the player to deliver her safely and as quickly as possible. By the time Exodus’s train reaches its final destination, the player will have experienced one of the more immersive stories in recent years. A story that, much to its credit, features multiple endings to increase replayability. I have beaten the game twice (once on console), and both endings were different, excellent finales. One of the endings was the  ending. But it didn’t seem bad to me; more like good storytelling.Metro Exodus is the third part in the Metro series. It is a mechanically sound, first-person shooter that takes place across a litany of areas that the player will explore. It is a blast to play. It contains a strong story that perfectly balances gameplay with narrative beats. While it may lack some of the spectacle seen in more well-known franchises, it more than makes up for it in its polish and atmosphere. In fact, Metro Exodus surpasses nearly all of its contemporaries with relative ease.

reviews.text: Fantastic Game, i personally felt the chapterwise divison and inclusion of a few open world levels in between linear levels really made the gameplay shockingly refresing, especially since almost no area overstays its welcome and most encounters are well designed and varied mini sandboxes inside the giant sandbox of the level itself, except for the final are but that's to be expected, and it stays far more ludonarratively coherent compared to games like Far Cry and most other open world games. Having a small ragtag team go on a Train Trip is as fun as it sounds. My favourite part was the train rides section between missions - Very nostalgic, the scenes were very similar to what i used to see when i used to travel a lot on trains as a kid and i loved every second of those looped scenes. For those scenes alone in various different biomes, i feel like the price i paid was justified. This was a Constructively short review based on a Purchase of the "Gold Edition" of the game at 75% off on a steam sale, that would be about $10(US). After completing only the base game as of now, i can recommend anyone to pick this game at nothing less than a 40% discount, ideally 75% or more. reviews.text: Metro Exodus is a first person shooter set in the aftermath of a nuclear war, where a small group of survivors live in Moscow’s underground rail network. This is the third game in the franchise, following Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light. The player once again controls Artyom, as he leads a squad of soldiers on a quest across the country.• Combat is enjoyable and fairly challenging on normal difficulty.• First 90 minutes feels very restrictive, with lots of lengthy dialogue scenes broken up by a few short combat sequences, during which you have an AI partner constantly saying “hey go over there, do this”. Thankfully, when you reach the open world sections, the game finally backs off and allows you to explore at your own pace.• The world is a dangerous place, inhabited by several different types of enemies including Human bandits, Humanoid mutants, dogs, Watchmen (large wolf-like creatures that hunt in packs), flying demons, giant shrimp that live in lakes, giant spiders hiding in dark tunnels, and some boss level creatures that I won’t spoil. Occasionally you’ll notice the bandits and monsters attacking each other.• Weapons feel great to fire, and include pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle, crossbow and the Tikhar, which uses air pressure to silently fire metal balls. Each weapon can be upgraded with mods to improve damage, accuracy, clip size, as well as changing how they function, such as different types of zoom sights or silencers. You can carry three weapons, which allows your loadout to have a nice mix of short range, long range and stealth.• Its often a good idea to use stealth if possible, take out enemies silently, or avoid them completely to conserve ammo. Going loud usually attracts more enemies, and you can’t recover ammo from looting monster corpses, so you could quickly run out of ammo. You can craft more ammo, but crafting resources are limited and probably better spent on medkits and gas mask filters.• Open world has a day/night cycle, and weather conditions like rain and sandstorms, which reduces visibility both for you and your enemies. Some areas are heavily irradiated, requiring you to wear a gas mask and change the filter periodically to avoid suffocating.• Main story took 19 hours to finish. There are two different endings depending on your actions during the game. (I got the good ending :D)• Main story is mostly well written.• Voice acting is fine, but I’ve heard better. • Your squadmates don’t just exist to shoot stuff, they’re living their own lives.• Artyom is a silent protagonist like Half-Life’s Gordon Freeman, which feels very weird because the other characters constantly talk to him during cutscenes. Its especially ridiculous every time they try to call him over a radio while on a mission. “Hey, Artyom, are you okay?”. Do they expect him to answer?• I suffered some frequent stuttering, even though my PC (i7 6700K @ 4ghz, 16GB ram, GTX 1080) is comfortably above the recommended spec shown on the store page. After adjusting some settings I had a constant 60 FPS, but occasionally it would freeze for half a second, which was very noticeable when turning my mouse sideways. Strangely, this was worse in the narrow underground tunnels at the start and end of the game, and it actually performed better in the open world areas. It never hurt me during combat, but it was annoying while exploring.• Controls are fully rebindable, however there is a quite annoying bug. I prefer to use arrow keys for movement (yes, we still exist), but there are some scenes where you sit down while listening to an NPC talk and you have to use WASD to interact with objects, or to leave the conversation, meaning that I had to change my keybindings back and forth several times.• When exiting back to main menu I frequently got a message suggesting that my saved games had been corrupted. I never actually lost any progress so I always just ignored the message, however you might want to research this further before purchasing. Maybe I just got lucky.• There are two DLC missions where the player controls different characters. The first takes place during the last mission of Artyom’s story, the second is set after the end of the main story.• Combat is the same high quality as the main story. The first mission adds a flamethrower to the player’s arsenal.• The stories are less detailed compared to the main story.• The first mission is quite linear and lasts around 2 hours, while the second mission contains a new open world area and took me around 7 hours to finish.Metro Exodus has enjoyable combat and a good story, but is let down by some technical problems. As the game has already been out for a year on the Fortnite Kids’ Anti Consumer Store, I doubt these problems will be fixed now.Still, its worth playing for fans of the FPS genre, and the Metro franchise. I bought the game plus DLC for 40% off, which feels like a fair price. If you’ve never played Metro before, I’d recommend picking up 2033 and Last Light, because they’re also really good.

reviews.text: Metro Exodus is overall a positive experience, but not without flaws.The biggest selling points are still here, the lore, the narrative, the characters and the story. It all clicks and it's the core foundation of Metro for me, as it's what keeps the game in shape despite its flaws.I didn't enjoy a lot of new aspects which differ Exodus from previous games. The "open world" looks more like the one we got from Mafia 1 - sure, you can divert a little from the path and explore, but that's it, the linear progress is still here and will close behind you almost all the exits, you can't just "go back" and collect missing stuff or finish open cases. Speaking of those, there are no side quests of any kind, the "best" you can have are a few small activities which all look the same - go kill/knock out everybody around and retrieve an item or pull a lever, that's it.The open world on the other hand is completely empty, the only thing that exists are enemy encounters, you can't get rid of them even on the easiest difficulties where they just spawn and you have to kill or sneak past them, there is very little opportunity to explore, it feels more like a chore of the main quest that makes you visit almost all of the point of interests that are interesting, because everything else is not. I think I found literally ONE location at caspian sea which looked interesting yet the main quest didn't make me go there, and I explored whole map on each level.Personally I enjoyed the linear story of the first metros more, the "affair" with the open world didn't end well in my eyes, yes, the game is indeed located mostly in open areas as opposed to claustrophobic metro tunnels, but that's pretty much everything the game has to offer - the locations are indeed designed well and unique as the places you find yourself in, but the moment you start exploring you notice that it's all empty world that tells no story at all, even Fallout 4 did better job here by having a lot of locations that were simply interesting to explore without any quest forcing you to go inside.I'm still leaving Exodus a positive note, because it's still the Metro universe I love and it'd be unfair to put equality sign between badly designed "open world" or underwhelming crafting mechanics and the excellent narrative, story and the lore. It's still a very good game to play, but personally I enjoyed the claustrophobic prequels far more, where you could feel the struggle of living and explored locations were polished to perfection, as opposed to the "open world" we got that feels rushed and boring.If you've enjoyed previous Metro games and you're into the lore, you certainly won't be disappointed. As a starting point, I discourage, you'll get thrown into the middle of action with characters you don't know, and the mechanics won't keep you for much longer alone.---If you liked my review, you can find more of them on  and on my .

reviews.text: I feel Metro Exodus is a step forwards and two step back....For those who love open world exploring then you're in a treat, because Metro Exodus offers that. But at the same time I feel this in't Metro anymore. When I first play Metro, it's because it's literally inside a Metro, it was so unique and mind blowing how people built their new life inside a Metro system. There was nothing like this even till today. Only Metro game you get to see it. Now having an open world is nice, but I feel the developers were lazy, because the world is fun to explore yet at times feel dead and dull, since there's no real form of missions or any sense of requirement for you to explore. Sure it's better to explore it and get all the best equipment, but you don't actually need it to complete the game. It's like you have to use your own imagination to have fun with it....if I were to do that I wouldn't be playing a game, I would learn to be a game developer instead. Battles / gunfights are lot more mediocre too....even on the Main Story line, It's not as epic and engaging as the previous two games. Hard to put it into words, but as I said when I play Metro Exodus it doesn't give me that sort of engaging and sense of a SP, but rather more like a MMO RPG Online game...It feels " dull " yet the game have so much potential....I actually had more fun in the DLC called Two Colonel...that's the easiest way I can explain my dissatisfaction with Metro Exodus. In a Nutshell, the game is great, I had fun, but It could have been better. And If I were to recommend a Metro game, I most likely would easily recommend Last Light / 2033 Redux instead, not because those are the Prequel, but I find those overall a better Metro games. Even when it lack the mechanic and gameplay Exodus offers. But I'm still gonna thumb it up. It's a Good game, but definitely not a Masterpiece or the Sequel I was expecting.

reviews.text: + Absolutely stunning graphics+ Perfectly executed animation+ Unforgettable opening titles+ Variety of different locations through the game+ Pretty unusual experience compared to the previous games of the series because of the road trip on the Soviet train+ Much more mindblowing action scenes+ The gunplay is purely amazing+ The atmosphere and tone of this game are very unique + Very emotional and captivating story+ Detailed weapon customization options   - Too much of QTE, that feels annoying and out of place from time to time- It can be hardly called open world game in the usual sense of this expression- Minor bugs here and there After the decision of the publishers to take the game away from Steam to make is Epic Store exclusive at the eleventh hour, I was put in a tricky position. Either I just turn my back to the game series or I purchase the game while I still able to do it on Steam. There is no need to discuss something that has been said a million times already regarding this situation. So this review is for the people who care about the game series and Metro universe in general instead of focusing on the Epic Store drama aspect.My biggest fear was that Metro Exodus would lose its soul and atmosphere of the claustrophobic sense, in those narrow subway tunnels, full of bandits and creepy monsters, because of the developers’ decision to make a road trip game. Luckily, they were managed to keep the needed atmosphere despite the fact that all the events take place on a surface. However, I still have kind of mixed feelings about this game, simply because of the weird mixture of different locations and incessant feelings that Metro Exodus tries to refer to some other popular representatives of the genre. Metro Exodus starts with a short monologue of Artyom, briefly telling the players about what happened to him and his life during the events of the previous games. At the end of this monologue, he says he is not going to stop until he finds a way to stop this madness to come back to the normal life. During one of his regular raids, he finds a Soviet-era steam train called the Aurora. From that point, Artyom and a few Spartan soldiers begin a long journey across post-apocalyptic Russia to get the answers on the most important questions and find a good place to start a new life.Of course, the major innovation for the game series is that Artyom finally leaves Metro and goes on a big road trip alongside with his squad and beloved woman. During this road trip, they will make a series of different stops to complete certain objectives like finding a fuel, water or even a trolley to continue their journey. The diversity of landscapes and locations is absolutely amazing: first, you see an abandoned village full of crazy religious fanatics, then you end up in the desert with neverending sandstorms and in the next scene you are fighting against the wild forest people, etc. However, it’s really important to state that this game is not a classical open world game. Basically, it still remains the same linear game as it was before, the only difference is that the train makes stops from time to time and during these stops you have the ability to explore these lands. Don’t expect to see enormous maps with tons of different stuff to do: usually, it’s a pretty limited map with the main objective and a few side quests where you have to find some lost goods, get rid of the bandits or help someone who is in trouble. First I was excited and promised myself to finish all these side quests, but then I just got bored with them and focused on the main quest primarily, simply because they were not that special or interesting enough. You can clearly feel how Metro Exodus has been supported with a much bigger budget and it looks much more polished but still feels like the original Metro games. Now it’s simply stuffed with actions scenes with QTE and some breathtaking cutscenes during the most dramatic moments. At some point, there were too much of these scenes that I felt like I was already tired of those QTE and neverending madness on the screen. Following the traditions of previous games in the series, Artyom is always one step away from death. It happens so often that it just becomes funny at the end and the player starts to believe that this guy is simply immortal and extra lucky. I lost my account of how many times I was unarmed simply because someone attacked the protagonist again and he was able to survive or run away at the very last second. The game is much more improved in terms of the combat as well. At the very first moment when I got the chance to kill a monster from my AK-47, I felt a huge difference comparing to the previous games. Metro can be played in a stealth mode as well, where Artyom can turn off the lights, blow out the candles and shoot the lanterns to avoid getting caught. All these weapons can be modified and upgraded, this is something that has been improved as well. Now every single weapon slot has a preset, where you can choose which weapon you want to take for the next mission. Every single modifier that you find on the enemies’ dead bodies will be added to your inventory so you can attach them to your weapons next time you are near the workbench. The worst thing that Metro Exodus has from the previous games is bugs and glitches alongside with a not so clever AI. Sometimes enemies can just look in your direction and wait for a few seconds before start shooting and mutants can act really weird, especially at some absolutely dark levels. Not to mention texture stuck issues and some voice stuttering during the dialogues.        Metro Exodus is absolutely gorgeous in terms of graphics. Through the whole journey, you will see the astonishing desert with the dried-out Caspian Sea, dull and atmospheric village full of crazy fanatics, beautiful sceneries of the frozen rivers and snowy mountains. I couldn’t stop admiring the detailing of each location and how they managed to work on them to bring us such quality content in the end. Like every single game of the series, Metro Exodus is provided with a high-quality voice dubbing and atmospheric ambient sounds. It has some minor issues with stuttering and voices laying over each other from time to time, but it doesn’t happen that often to strongly focus on this.Metro Exodus is a massive project that has been developed with a soul and it tells you a great story about the journey, family and how it’s important to fight for yourself and for your happiness. The developers took a chance by creating a completely different game bringing the protagonists out of Metro on the surface and they didn’t fail. Highly recommended for every single Metro series fan.

Tired of being in underground Moscow, after Soviet Russia faced nuclear destruction, our main character, Artyom, sets out in search for an oasis among the radiated, post apocalypse Russia. While the game is some-what linear, it plays very much like a movie and breaks from the cinema enough for you to feel as though you have the freedom to roam and create your own story.

reviews.text: Metro Exodus is the last game of the Metro trilogy and rightfully acclaimed as one of the best games of 2019. The gun combat was enhanced into a more satisfying yet unforgiving system, where the true felling of "post-apocalyptic survival shooter" comes into play, especially on higher difficulties (fighting several enemies at the same time will often result on the player's death). Pros: - Interesting places to explore with many secondary locations.-Excellent narrative and character building, culminating on the ending of the game (the game has 2 different endings which will depend on the player's choices throughout the game).- Lots of guns/bullets crafting.- Very atmospheric scenarios and sounds (typical of the Metro series).Cons: - Despite having big areas for exploration the game is not really open world. The player progresses in a train an can't go back to previous explored areas.- The game pacing changes because the player will mostly be exploring open areas and no longer Metro areas (due to how the story develops). Depending on the player this could be either a good or a bad new setting, though.

reviews.text: If you find this review to be helpful, my curators page is here: This is the third game in the Metro series, and is an easy sell for previous fans. It's the same mixture of environmental hazards, scavenging, melee and ranged combat, tense set-pieces, and boisterous OTT story-telling that the series has consistently delivered. The open world setting does make levels freer to explore, and allows for the game to expand in a pleasant way that doesn't dilute it's best qualities. It's not fundamentally all that different to play, but it does freshen up those aspects that were perhaps in danger of getting stale, and without sacrificing their talents at making intense or scary directed moments.For those who are unfamiliar with the Metro games: They take place in Russia, after a nuclear war has left the landscape uninhabitable and the survivors have fled underground into the train tunnels. Life is tough, and above ground has radiation and mutants, but there are relatively comfortable communities making it from day to day. You play as Artyom, an optimistic every-man who gets drawn into the fight for survival against foes that range from men to monsters, to advanced beings with control of time and space. Y'know...the usual post-apocalyptic USSR stuff, which is solidly constructed rather than anything ground-breaking.It's voice-acting is usually overdone, and the characterisation can be a tad iffy (most Russians are apparently a bit loud and blustery?) so it has never been totally convincing on the narrative front. However, it has also never failed  to deliver an engaging mixture of FPS combat, survival elements, and exciting sequences of tension and terror. You're not a cyborg super soldier, or roided up bad-ass military guy, and this is a world where your gun is powered by a bicycle pump, and whether or not you have any ammo for it will depend on if you want to eat your last potato for health, or use it as a projectile to try and brain someone with it.I'm kidding about the potato, but bullets are both your money, and...uh...well, things you shoot with. The most potent weapons will be guns, and so are costly to actually fire, or you can have air-powered weapons that are cheaper to produce ammo for, but don't pack as much punch. It's a game where lots of little touches add up to a fairly unique flavour: some areas require using a gas mask, and finding top-ups for it's filters. You can get dirt and blood splattered over the visor, and will have to wipe it off. Your torch is powered by cranking the handle, and bringing up the map is an actual "physical" object Artyom retrieves and looks at.This isn't Fallout, or Dying Light, when it comes to it's crafting mechanics. You don't just get some wires, a few Duracell batteries, some double-sided sticky tape, and a gun, then slap it all together A-Team style to make a rail-gun that shoots beams of energy. It's not Call Of Duty where you're firing off a gun so powerful that it takes bionic arms just to carry it, and then you call in a death-beam strike from an outer-space satellite. Generally you'll probably be going down the stealth route, and are shooting them with a cobbled together air-rifle that sounds like a duck politely farting, or getting up close for some stabbing / neck-breaking.Fire-fights are for bourgeoisie capitalist pig-dogs, with money to almost literally burn, as it goes up in smoke with every bullet fired. It's a balancing act trying to get by with the cheaper, less effective weapons, so you can eventually afford to purchase upgrades to improve them, or save up for something better, but that is also more costly to use. On the higher difficulty levels it's a tough enough challenge that in the first game of the series, I couldn't ever afford to buy a new weapon throughout the entire campaign. On this third game they've softened that challenge a little bit (in some ways, at least) and searching every nook and cranny will yield all the items, or all the bits and pieces for crafting useful additions. It's smoother to progress, but limits to your inventory, relatively scarce resources, and the levels of enemy opposition, mean it's still not easy.It can be played as a run-and-gunner, and the combat is slick enough to satisfy. Though stealth is a viable option too, and enemies have varying states of alertness and responsiveness to threats. Mechanically this is very polished across all of its elements, and by now is super-slick with it's set-pieces. With plenty of capacity for tension, scares, and thrills, these nicely break up the "loose" action for more tightly controlled sequences.Story-wise it's engaging enough, but I'd be lying if I said this was ever it's strongest suit. This is about immersion in it's world, the sense of place and atmosphere that the excellent graphics and soundscape help to convey, and all those things that ground you in it. The involvement with your weapons and utilities, as you pump them up in the heat of battle, or furiously wind up your torch to see in pitch-black locations. Hearing your character desperately sucking in handfuls of corrupt air as your last filter runs out, and you're stumbling around searching for another before suffocating. Around you there's weird phantoms of long-dead people going about their business in an echo of the distant past, and there's no time to pay this bizarre anomaly much mind when there's the somewhat more pressing matter of ensuring you can breathe.The adrenaline rush of hard-fought encounters, or nervously creeping through the shadows unseen. That huge sigh of relief as you make it to a quiet moment after all that tension. There's a stretch where mutants aren't trying to tear your face off, and people aren't shooting at you, and the only thing you have to pay any mind to is the hum of a geiger counter. Just as you get comfortable, something bursts out of a nearby lake, or out of the ground, or from the sky, and you are reminded that you can never be truly at ease in this world. It is possible to appreciate this without playing the previous games, as it doesn't riff particularly heavily on events from the first two. Though some familiarity, and connection to the characters, will make it's twists and turns that extra bit more poignant or involving. For the most part this release is a very enjoyable final to the trilogy (the voice-work, whilst not bad, isn't great either, but that's it's main flaw), and I highly recommend it.

reviews.text: As a fan of the original Stalker and the Metro games following it, I loved the Slavic take on the post apocalyptic world-building compared to that of the rest of Europe and America with it's mostly Happy-Go-Lucky games like Fallout, Borderlands (not in America but an American developer anyways). Something about the cold nuclear winters, frost kicking onto your visor as  you wipe it off with a dedicated hand button and the constant ticking of the Gieger counter firmly reminded you that the world with the now-deranged mother nature is far more dangerous foe than anything you will face. When it is shown that the new Metro game will take place mostly outside of Metro, fans were rightly skeptical as one of the core series strength was always the dark interconnected tunnels of the Metro stations of Moscow which drenched in atmosphere which other games in the genre could hardly come even close to. After having played this game in hardcore difficulty, which took me around 30 hours as I took my time as I usually do in these sort of games; I am happy to say that the new open environments are not detrimental to the series core, in fact the the claustrophobic metro sections are still there in the game and elevated up several notches in atmosphere.This game at its heart is probably the closest to Half-Life 3 and a true Crysis sequel we are ever going to it. The one year journey as the game takes you across the desolate Russia with your wife and the people of your ‘Order’ evoked me feels of Half-Life which I have not gotten for so many years, damn I missed that. The maps are not open world, but many are very large, giving you multiple ways to tackle problems, just like Crysis. Also debuting is a on-site attachment system, again similar to Crysis in many ways. That is not to say the game simply borrows everything and calls it a day, there is still the Metro atmosphere which really gels everything together. You have a mobile hub, a train called the Aurora. Here the game becomes a little bit like immersive sims like Deus Ex. Here you get to talk with your crew and play with the weapon modifications. I was surprised how lengthy dialogue can get with you or when the crew is talking amongst themselves. It is a non-issue as you are forced to listen to everything, but I like how the dialogs were often long and felt ‘real’ as opposed to a minute or two conversations. These Aurora sections bring the much needed downtime, especially when you consider how brutal the game can get at times. The thing which bothers me a lot unfortunately is the English voice acting, it is simply not good most the time, minus your wife Anna. It feels like an amatuer person reading off the script, also the voice writing is off for me as well. I heard it sounds a lot better in Russian and it does, however it hurts my gameplay as I constantly checking the subtitles will force you to the bottom third of the screen a lot of the time as you would be missing out a lot in front of you. You don’t want to miss out on that one as Metro Exodus, just like it’s peers, is gorgeous. It now has a dynamic day/night cycle and RTX users can enjoy true Global Illumination which makes the game look even more realistic. Even if you don’t have RTX GPU, the game is absolutely jaw dropping on my GTX 970. I get a good 45-60fps on high settings and the frame rate mostly stays high during combat so it doesn’t bother me. Although bear in mind that the frame rate can vary a lot depending on the location you are in and what you are looking in front of you. There are some off low resolution textures on certain objects here and there, which is a shame but not a deal breaker but overall though, this game is a stunner and easily one of the best looking games out there on the PC.I played it Hardcore difficulty and I suggest everyone to start playing from this difficulty as it tunes the game the way it is meant to be played. Ammo and crafting supplies will be scarce, I had to make difficult decisions like breaking down my ammo for some materials to craft a filter for my mask for example. On this difficulty, you will regularly making such decisions, although it never it felt like it is the focus like a disaster management game. It made me appreciate the gameplay systems even more. The gunfights can be very lethal on hardcore difficulty. 2-3 shots or a shotgun blast can kill you, same rule applies to the enemies. The enemies are challenging because of this, but unfortunately the AI isn’t that good. They take cover and aim pretty good but they never force you to fall back rethink your move. Careful planning and the right gear with the right modifications can make all the difference.Speaking of gear, the weapons and items in metro exodus looks and feels very real. It has that raw look which tech and junk strapped together to make it function which I love. Weapons will degrade overtime in the weather, and will cause it to jam or shoot off the mark when it happens. So it is always a good idea to take note of your gear before heading out. There are also crafting stations outside of the Aurora which will allow you to make ammo and clean the weapons.I did not feel much for the story but in the end it truly grabbed me. It shows the desperation of how far we will go for the people we love. As someone who lost the love of his life very recently, it teared me up. Rachaelle my love, if you read this, I am sorry I failed you.They simply do not make games like this anymore. It was longer than I expected as it took me around 30 hrs to beat in my own pace. It is very unfortunate the steam/epic thing blew to the point the game suffered in the public view. For those are waiting for the steam version of the game, trust me this game will be worth the wait. Make no mistake, this is a great game...one which I wish my girl friend watched me play from...wherever she is...=========My System=========Windows 10 proIntel Core i5 4570GTX 970 OCed16GB RAMSamsung 840 EVO SSDGame installed on a Western Digital Green HDD
